And then they asked for a king, and God gave to them Saul, son of Kis, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, during forty years. @ Hlăk anŭn gơñu kiăng hmâo sa čô pơtao. Ơi Adai brơi kơ gơñu Sôl ană đah rơkơi Kis, sa čô mơ̆ng kơnŭng djuai Benjamin, jing pơtao wai lăng ƀing gơñu amăng pă pluh thŭn. 
And having removed him he raised up to them David for king, of whom also bearing witness he said, I have found David, the son of Jesse, a man after my heart, who shall do all my will. @ Giơ̆ng anŭn Ơi Adai lui hĭ Sôl, Ñu yŏng đĭ Đawit brơi jing pơtao kơ ƀing gơñu; kơ pô anŭn Ñu gơ̆ng jơlan tui anai: ‘Kâo hmâo ƀuh laih Đawit ană đah rơkơi Yêsê jing sa čô mơnuih bơmơak pran jua Kâo jing pô či ngă abih tơlơi Kâo kiăng.’ 
Of this man's seed according to promise has God brought to Israel a Saviour, Jesus; @ Mơ̆ng ană tơčo Đawit, Ơi Adai hmâo yŏng đĭ laih kơ ƀing ană Israel sa čô Pô Pơklaih, anŭn jing Yêsu tui hăng tơlơi Ñu hmâo ƀuăn laih. 
John having proclaimed before the face of his entry [among the people] [the] baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel. @ Hlâo kơ Yêsu čơdơ̆ng bruă, Yôhan hmâo pơtô laih kơ abih bang ƀing Israel tơlơi ƀatem kơhmal kơ tơlơi soh. 
And as John was fulfilling his course he said, Whom do ye suppose that I am? *I* am not [he]. But behold, there comes one after me, the sandal of whose feet I am not worthy to loose. @ Tơ Yôhan giăm ngă pơgiơ̆ng bruă ñu, ñu laĭ: ‘Hlơi ƀing gih pơmĭn kâo jing? Kâo ƀu djơ̆ jing Pô ƀing gih dŏ čang tơguan anŭn ôh. Samơ̆ hmư̆ bĕ, hmâo sa čô rai tơdơi kơ kâo, kâo ƀu lăp ôh kleh brơi klĭ juă Ñu.’
Brethren, sons of Abraham's race, and those who among you fear God, to you has the word of this salvation been sent: @ Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, ƀing ană tơčo kơnŭng djuai Abraham, laih anŭn abih bang ƀing mơnuih tuai hwĭ pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai, kơ ƀing ta yơh Ơi Adai hmâo brơi rai laih hiăp pơtô tơlơi pơklaih anai. 
for those who dwell in Jerusalem, and their rulers, not having known him, have fulfilled also the voices of the prophets which are read on every sabbath, [by] judging [him]. @ Yua kơ ƀing dŏ amăng plei Yêrusalem hăng ƀing khua gơñu ƀu thâo krăn ôh Yêsu anai, kŏn thâo hluh lơi khul boh pơhiăp ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo, gơñu đŏk rĭm hrơi Saƀat. Hnŭn yơh tơdang gơñu klă kơđi kơ Yêsu gơñu hmâo ngă hĭ hơdôm boh pơhiăp ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo anŭn dưi krĕp djơ̆. 
And having found no cause of death [in him], they begged of Pilate that he might be slain. @ Wơ̆t dah gơñu kơčut kơ Ñu tơlơi ƀu lăp dưi pơdjai ôh, gơñu ăt rơkâo Pilat pơdjai hĭ Ñu. 
And when they had fulfilled all things written concerning him, they took him down from the cross and put him in a sepulchre; @ Giơ̆ng gơñu hmâo ngă krĕp djơ̆ abih tơlơi arăng hmâo čih djơ̆ kơ Ñu, gơñu pơtrŭn Ñu mơ̆ng kơyâo bơrơkal hăng dơr hĭ Ñu amăng pơsat. 
but God raised him from among [the] dead, @ Samơ̆ Ơi Adai hmâo pơhơdip glaĭ Ñu mơ̆ng mơnuih djai, 
who appeared for many days to those who had come up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are now his witnesses to the people. @ laih anŭn tơdang lu hrơi Ñu bơrơđah Ñu pô kơ ƀing hyu hrŏm hơbĭt hăng Ñu mơ̆ng tring Galilê truh pơ plei Yêrusalem. Ƀing anŭn yơh ră anai leng kơ jing ƀing ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơhaih kơ ană plei pla. 
And *we* declare unto you the glad tidings of the promise made to the fathers, @ Gah kơ ƀing gơmơi anai, ră ruai kơ ƀing gih Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam, hơgĕt Ơi Adai hmâo ƀuăn laih kơ ơi adon ƀing ta, 
that God has fulfilled this to us their children, having raised up Jesus; as it is also written in the second psalm, *Thou* art my Son: this day have *I* begotten thee. @ Ơi Adai hmâo ngă krĕp djơ̆ laih tơlơi ƀuăn anŭn kơ ƀing ta jing ƀing ană tơčo gơñu, hăng tơlơi Ñu hmâo pơhơdip glaĭ Yêsu, kar hăng arăng hmâo čih laih mơ̆n amăng Hră Adoh Hơđăp mrô dua:
‘Ih jing ană đah rơkơi Kâo,
hrơi anai Kâo tơkeng kơ Ih.’
But that he raised him from among [the] dead, no more to return to corruption, he spoke thus: I will give to you the faithful mercies of David. @  Ơi Adai hmâo pơhơdip glaĭ Yêsu kiăng kơ Ñu ƀu glaĭ kơ tơlơi brŭ rai dơ̆ng ôh ră anai. Yua kơ anŭn yơh Ơi Adai hmâo laĭ tui anai,
‘Kâo či brơi kơ ƀing gih tơlơi mơyun hiam hơčih laih anŭn sĭt Kâo hmâo ƀuăn laih kơ Pơtao Đawit.’
Wherefore also he says in another, Thou wilt not suffer thy gracious one to see corruption. @  Yua kơ anŭn yơh, kar kaĭ mơ̆n amăng Hră Adoh Hơđăp pơkŏn laĭ,
‘Ih ƀu či brơi ôh Pô Rơgoh Hơčih Ih ƀuh tơlơi brŭ rai.’
For David indeed, having in his own generation ministered to the will of God, fell asleep, and was added to his fathers and saw corruption. @ Yua kơ giơ̆ng mă bruă amăng rơnŭk ñu tui hăng Ơi Adai kiăng, Đawit djai laih anŭn arăng dơr ñu hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ƀing ơi adon ñu, laih anŭn hmâo ƀuh laih tơlơi brŭ rai. 
But he whom God raised up did not see corruption. @ Samơ̆ Pô Ơi Adai hmâo pơhơdip glaĭ, Ñu ƀu ƀuh tơlơi brŭ rai ôh. 
Be it known unto you, therefore, brethren, that through this man remission of sins is preached to you, @ Tui anŭn ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, brơi ƀing gih thâo yua mơ̆ng Pô anŭn yơh tơlơi pap brơi tơlơi soh hmâo pơhaih brơi laih kơ ƀing gih. 
and from all things from which ye could not be justified in the law of Moses, in him every one that believes is justified. @ Laih anŭn yua mơ̆ng Ñu yơh, abih bang hlơi pô đaŏ leng kơ dưi hmâo tơlơi rơngai mơ̆ng abih bang tơlơi soh, jing tơlơi juăt Môis ƀu dưi pơrơngai brơi ƀing gih ôh. 
See therefore that that which is spoken in the prophets do not come upon [you], @ Yua kơ anŭn yơh, răng bĕ, hwĭ tơlơi anai truh djơ̆ kơ ƀing gih kar hăng tơlơi ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo hmâo laĭ laih:
Behold, ye despisers, and wonder and perish; for *I* work a work in your days, a work which ye will in no wise believe if one declare it to you. @  ‘Lăng bĕ, Ơ ƀing djik djak!
Hwĭ bral bĕ laih anŭn răm rai hĭ!
Yua kơ amăng rơnŭk ƀing gih, Kâo či ngă sa mơta bruă,
Wơ̆t dah hmâo mơnuih ruai glaĭ, ƀing gih ăt ƀu đaŏ ôh!’”
And as they went out they begged that these words might be spoken to them the ensuing sabbath. @ Tơdang Pôl hăng Barnabas tơbiă mơ̆ng sang bơjơnum, ƀing ană plei kơwưh rơkâo kơ gơñu pơtô tơlơi anŭn dơ̆ng ƀơi hrơi Saƀat tơdơi. 
And the congregation of the synagogue having broken up, many of the Jews and of the worshipping proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas, who speaking to them, persuaded them to continue in the grace of God. @ Tơ tơlơi bơjơnum giơ̆ng hĭ laih, lu ƀing Yuđa hăng ƀing djuai tuai tui tơlơi đaŏ Yuđa, gơñu đuaĭ tui Pôl hăng Barnabas. Dua gơñu pơhiăp ră ruai hăng ƀing gơñu, hăng alum pơđur kơ ƀing gơñu brơi dŏ kơjăp amăng tơlơi pap Ơi Adai.
And on the coming sabbath almost all the city was gathered together to hear the word of God. @ Hrơi Saƀat tơdơi, ƀiă giăm kơ abih mơnuih amăng plei pơtŭm glaĭ kiăng hmư̆ tơlơi Ơi Adai pơhiăp. 
But the Jews, seeing the crowds, were filled with envy, and contradicted the things said by Paul, [contradicting and] speaking injuriously. @ Samơ̆ tơ ƀing Yuđa ƀuh ƀing mơnuih lu anŭn, gơñu bă hăng tơlơi moañ nač, pơgăl glaĭ hăng tơlơi Pôl pơhiăp, laih anŭn hơtoh djraĭ gơ̆. 
And Paul and Barnabas spoke boldly and said, It was necessary that the word of God should be first spoken to you; but, since ye thrust it from you, and judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, lo, we turn to the nations; @ Samơ̆ Pôl hăng Barnabas pơhiăp kơ gơñu hăng tơlơi khĭn hăng laĭ: “Tui hăng tơlơi djơ̆, blŭng hlâo gơmơi khŏm pơtô tơlơi Ơi Adai pơhiăp kơ ƀing gih. Samơ̆ yua kơ ƀing gih hơngah tơlơi anŭn laih anŭn yap ƀing gih pô ƀu lăp mă tŭ tơlơi hơdip hlŏng lar ôh, tui anŭn ră anai gơmơi anăp nao kơ ƀing djuai tuai. 
for thus has the Lord enjoined us: I have set thee for a light of the nations, that thou shouldest be for salvation to the end of the earth. @ Yua kơ Khua Yang hmâo pơtă kơ ƀing gơmơi, laĭ,
‘Kâo hmâo pơjing ih tơlơi bơngač kơ ƀing djuai tuai,
kiăng kơ ih dưi ba tơlơi pơklaih truh pơ rơnuč lŏn tơnah.’”
And [those of] the nations, hearing it, rejoiced, and glorified the word of the Lord, and believed, as many as were ordained to eternal life. @ Tơ ƀing djuai tuai hmư̆ tơlơi pơhiăp anŭn, gơñu hơ̆k kơdơ̆k pơpŭ bơni hơơč boh pơhiăp Khua Yang. Laih anŭn hơdôm ƀing mơnuih hmâo ruah brơi laih kơ tơlơi hơdip hlŏng lar leng kơ mă tŭ tơlơi đaŏ.
And the word of the Lord was carried through the whole country. @ Tơlơi Khua Yang pơhiăp lar hyu tar ƀar čar anŭn. 
But the Jews excited the women of the upper classes who were worshippers, and the first people of the city, and raised a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and cast them out of their coasts. @ Samơ̆ ƀing Yuđa pơsur pơtrŭt ƀing đah kơmơi arăng pơpŭ thâo kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai hăng ƀing khua wai lăng plei anŭn pơsur ƀing anai ngă sat kơ Pôl hăng Barnabas laih anŭn puh pơđuaĭ dua gơ̆ mơ̆ng čar gơñu. 
But they, having shaken off the dust of their feet against them, came to Iconium. @ Pôl hăng Barnabas pruh ƀruih lŏn mơ̆ng tơkai gơñu, pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng ƀing gơñu, giơ̆ng anŭn nao pơ plei Ikôni. 
And the disciples were filled with joy and [the] Holy Spirit. @ Bơ ƀing ding kơna bă hăng tơlơi hơ̆k mơak laih anŭn hăng Yang Bơngăt Hiam.
And it came to pass in Iconium that they entered together into the synagogue of the Jews, and so spake that a great multitude of both Jews and Greeks believed. @ Pơ plei Ikôni Pôl hăng Barnabas mŭt amăng sang bơjơnum ƀing ană Yuđa, gơñu pơtô ngă brơi lu mơnuih Yuđa wơ̆t hăng ƀing Grek đaŏ. 
But the Jews who did not believe stirred up the minds of [those of] the nations and made [them] evil-affected against the brethren. @ Samơ̆ ƀing mơnuih Yuđa ƀu đaŏ pơsur pơtrŭt ƀing djuai tuai brơi gơñu hil kơ ƀing adơi ayŏng. 
They stayed therefore a good while, speaking boldly, [confiding] in the Lord, who gave witness to the word of his grace, giving signs and wonders to be done by their hands. @ Wơ̆t tui anŭn, Pôl hăng Barnabas dŏ sui pơ anŭn pơtô boh pơhiăp Ơi Adai hăng tơlơi khĭn, laih anŭn Khua Yang yua tơngan gơñu ngă tơlơi gru kơnăl mơyang hăng tơlơi mơsêh mơyang kiăng ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ tơlơi pap Khua Yang. 
And the multitude of the city was divided, and some were with the Jews and some with the apostles. @ Samơ̆ ƀing mơnuih amăng plei anŭn hmâo tơlơi pơkah pha phung; hmâo mơnuih dŏ gah kơ ƀing Yuđa, hmâo mơnuih dŏ gah kơ dua čô khua ding kơna. 
And when an assault was making, both of [those of] the nations and [the] Jews with their rulers, to use [them] ill and stone them, @ Hlăk anŭn ƀing djuai tuai hrŏm hăng ƀing Yuđa hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ƀing khua gơñu hơduah tơlơi mơneč ngă sat laih anŭn glŏm boh pơtâo kơ dua čô khua ding kơna, 
they, being aware of it, fled to the cities of Lycaonia, Lystra and Derbe, and the surrounding country, @ Hmư̆ tơlơi pơthâo anŭn, dua gơñu đuaĭ kơdŏp hĭ pơ Listrơ hăng Derbơ amăng čar Likaoni, laih anŭn tring jum dar. 
and there they were announcing the glad tidings. @ Pơ anŭn gơñu pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam.
And a certain man in Lystra, impotent in his feet, sat, [being] lame from his mother's womb, who had never walked. @ Pơ plei Listrơ hmâo sa čô đah rơkơi rơwen tơkai, mơ̆ng hrơi amĭ tơkeng, ñu aka ƀu thâo rơbat djơ̆ ôh. 
This [man] heard Paul speaking, who, fixing his eyes on him, and seeing that he had faith to be healed, @ Ñu dŏ ber hăng dŏ hmư̆ Pôl pơtô. Pôl lăng kơ ñu ƀu ƀleh mơta ôh, hăng thâo kơ ñu hmâo tơlơi đaŏ dưi pơsuaih ñu. 
said with a loud voice, Rise up straight upon thy feet: and he sprang up and walked. @ Tui anŭn Pôl laĭ hăng asăp kraih: “Tơgŭ dŏ dơ̆ng tơpă bĕ tơkai ih.” Ñu tơgŭ plŏng kơdăt hăng yak rơbat nao rai. 
But the crowds, who saw what Paul had done, lifted up their voices in Lycaonian, saying, The gods, having made themselves like men, are come down to us. @ Tơ ƀing mơnuih lu ƀuh tơlơi Pôl hmâo ngă, gơñu ur kraih hăng tơlơi pơhiăp Likaoni: “Ƀing yang truă rup mơnuih trŭn rai pơ ƀing ta yơh!” 
And they called Barnabas Jupiter, and Paul Mercury, because he took the lead in speaking. @ Gơñu pơanăn Barnabas jing Yupitê, laih anŭn pơanăn Pôl jing Merkurơ, yua kơ Pôl jing pô pơtô phŭn, 
And the priest of Jupiter who was before the city, having brought bulls and garlands to the gates, would have done sacrifice along with the crowds. @ Khua ngă yang kơ yang Yupitê hmâo sang kơkuh pơpŭ ƀơi anăp plei, dui ba rơmo hăng djă guang bơnga nao pơ amăng jang hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ană plei pla kiăng pơyơr mơnơ̆ng ngă yang kơ dua čô khua ding kơna. 
But the apostles Barnabas and Paul, having heard [it], rent their garments, and rushed out to the crowd, crying @ Samơ̆ tơ dua čô khua ding kơna, Pôl hăng Barnabas thâo tơlơi anŭn, gơñu hek sum ao gơñu hăng nao ur tơ̆ng krah ƀing lu tui anai, 
and saying, Men, why do ye these things? *We* also are men of like passions with you, preaching to you to turn from these vanities to the living God, who made the heaven, and the earth, and the sea, and all things in them; @ “Ơ ƀing gơyut! Hyư̆m ƀing gih ngă tui anŭn lĕ? Gơmơi kơnơ̆ng jing ƀing mơnuih kar hăng ƀing gih đôč, gơmơi pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam kơ ƀing gih kiăng kơ ƀing gih lui hĭ yang ƀu tŭ yua adih hăng wơ̆t glaĭ kơ Ơi Adai Pô hơdip, Pô hmâo pơjing lŏn adai, ia rơsĭ hăng abih bang mơnơ̆ng amăng anŭn. 
who in the past generations suffered all the nations to go in their own ways, @ Amăng khul rơnŭk rơgao laih, Ñu lui hĭ abih bang djuai mơnuih ngă tui hăng jơlan gơñu pô kiăng; 
though indeed he did not leave himself without witness, doing good, and giving to you from heaven rain and fruitful seasons, filling your hearts with food and gladness. @ Wơ̆t tui anŭn, Ơi Adai ăt ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơhaih kơ Ñu pô, jing hăng tơlơi Ñu ăt brơi tơlơi hiam, brơi ia hơjan mơ̆ng adai kơ ƀing gih, brơi bơyan hmâo lu boh troh, pơhrăp pran jua ƀing gih hăng mơnơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă laih anŭn tơlơi hơ̆k mơak.” 
And saying these things, they with difficulty kept the crowds from sacrificing to them. @ Wơ̆t dah pơhiăp abih tơlơi tui anŭn, ăt gleh glăn mơ̆n gơñu dưi khă ƀing ană plei pơyơr mơnơ̆ng ngă yang kơ gơñu.
But there came Jews from Antioch and Iconium, and having persuaded the crowds and stoned Paul, drew him out of the city, supposing him to have died. @ Hlăk anŭn ƀing Yuđa rai mơ̆ng Antiôs hăng plei Ikôni. Gơñu pơtrŭt pơsur pran jua ƀing ană plei, gơñu glŏm boh pơtâo kơ Pôl, gơñu mĭn dah Pôl djai laih, hnŭn yơh gơñu dui ba hĭ gơ̆ pơ gah rơngiao plei. 
But while the disciples encircled him, he rose up and entered into the city. And on the morrow he went away with Barnabas to Derbe. @ Samơ̆ tơdang ƀing ding kơna pơtŭm glaĭ jum dar Pôl, gơ̆ tơgŭ dơ̆ng hăng mŭt glaĭ amăng plei. Hrơi tơdơi, Pôl hăng Barnabas nao pơ plei Derbơ.
And having announced the glad tidings to that city, and having made many disciples, they returned to Lystra, and Iconium, and Antioch, @ Tơ Pôl hăng Barnabas pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam amăng plei anŭn laih anŭn pơjing lu mơnuih jing ding kơna, gơñu wơ̆t glaĭ pơ plei Listrơ, plei Ikôni laih anŭn plei Antiôs, 
establishing the souls of the disciples, exhorting them to abide in the faith, and that through many tribulations we must enter into the kingdom of God. @ ngă pơkơtang pran jua ƀing ding kơna, pơtrŭt pơđur gơñu brơi dŏ kơjăp amăng tơlơi đaŏ, laih anŭn laĭ pơthâo kơ gơñu khŏm găn lu tơlơi tơnap tap kah kiăng dưi mŭt amăng dêh čar pơtao Ơi Adai. 
And having chosen them elders in each assembly, having prayed with fastings, they committed them to the Lord, on whom they had believed. @ Tơdơi kơ dua gơñu pơdŏ bruă brơi ƀing kŏng tha kơ rĭm Phung Sang Ơi Adai, dua gơñu iâu laĭ, ư̆ ƀơ̆ng huă, gơñu jao ƀing anŭn kơ Khua Yang, Pô ƀing gơñu hmâo đaŏ kơnang.
And having passed through Pisidia they came to Pamphylia, @ Laih anŭn dua gơñu găn hĭ čar Pisidi truh pơ čar Pamphili. 
and having spoken the word in Perga, they came down to Attalia; @ Giơ̆ng gơñu pơtô tơlơi Ơi Adai pơhiăp amăng Pergi, gơñu trŭn nao pơ čar Atali. 
and thence they sailed away to Antioch, whence they had been committed to the grace of God for the work which they had fulfilled. @ Mơ̆ng anŭn dua gơñu đĭ kompăn glaĭ pơ Antiôs, jing anih hlâo adih arăng hmâo jao brơi gơñu kơ tơlơi pap Ơi Adai, kiăng ngă bruă gơñu phrâo pơgiơ̆ng laih.
And having arrived, and having brought together the assembly, they related to them all that God had done with them, and that he had opened a door of faith to the nations. @ Tơ gơñu truh, gơñu pơƀŭt Phung Sang Ơi Adai laih anŭn ră glaĭ abih bruă Ơi Adai hmâo ngă hrŏm hơbĭt hăng gơñu, laih anŭn hyư̆m Ơi Adai hmâo pŏk laih bah amăng tơlơi đaŏ kơ ƀing djuai tuai. 
And they stayed no little time with the disciples. @ Dua gơñu dŏ glaĭ pơ anŭn sui hrơi ƀiă hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ƀing ding kơna.
And certain persons, having come down from Judaea, taught the brethren, If ye shall not have been circumcised according to the custom of Moses, ye cannot be saved. @  Hmâo đơđa ƀing mơnuih trŭn rai mơ̆ng Yuđa nao pơ Antiôs hăng pơtô kơ ƀing adơi ayŏng tui anai: “Tơdah ƀing gih ƀu tŭ tơlơi khăt klĭ tui hăng tơlơi phiăn Môis pơtă laih, ƀing gih ƀu dưi klaih ôh.” 
A commotion therefore having taken place, and no small discussion on the part of Paul and Barnabas against them, they arranged that Paul and Barnabas, and certain others from amongst them, should go up to Jerusalem to the apostles and elders about this question. @ Pôl hăng Barnabas hmâo tơlơi ƀu tŭ ư, hăng hmâo tơlơi pơrơjah, pơgăl kơtang hăng ƀing anŭn, Phung Sang Ơi Adai khư̆p ư ruah Pôl hăng Barnabas hrŏm hơbĭt hăng đơđa ƀing pơkŏn nao pơ ƀing khua ding kơna hăng ƀing kŏng tha pơ plei Yêrusalem kiăng kơsem tơña kơ tơlơi anŭn. 
They therefore, having been set on their way by the assembly, passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, relating the conversion of [those of] the nations. And they caused great joy to all the brethren. @ Tui anŭn, giơ̆ng kơ Phung Sang Ơi Adai pơkiaŏ nao gơñu, gơñu găn čar Phênisi hăng tring Samari ră ruai glaĭ tơlơi ƀing djuai tuai đaŏ. Tơlơi anŭn ngă kơ abih bang ƀing adơi ayŏng mơak biă mă. 
And being arrived at Jerusalem, they were received by the assembly, and the apostles, and the elders, and related all that God had wrought with them. @ Tơ gơñu truh pơ plei Yêrusalem, gơñu hmâo Phung Sang Ơi Adai, ƀing khua ding kơna, hăng ƀing kŏng tha čơkă jum gơñu. Giơ̆ng anŭn gơñu ră ruai glaĭ abih bang tơlơi Ơi Adai hmâo ngă găn mơ̆ng gơñu. 
And some of those who were of the sect of the Pharisees, who believed, rose up from among [them], saying that they ought to circumcise them and enjoin them to keep the law of Moses. @ Samơ̆ hmâo đơđa ƀing đaŏ amăng ƀing gah Pharisi tơgŭ hăng laĭ: “Khŏm ngă tơlơi khăt klĭ wơ̆t kơ ƀing djuai tuai laih anŭn pơtă kơ gơñu khŏm gưt tơlơi juăt Môis.”
And the apostles and the elders were gathered together to see about this matter. @ Ƀing khua ding kơna hăng ƀing kŏng tha pơƀŭt glaĭ kiăng kơsem lăng tơlơi anŭn. 
And much discussion having taken place, Peter, standing up, said to them, Brethren, *ye* know that from the earliest days God amongst you chose that the nations by my mouth should hear the word of the glad tidings and believe. @ Giơ̆ng hmâo tơlơi črŏng sai klă ten, Pêtrôs tơgŭ laih anŭn laĭ hăng gơñu: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, ƀing gih thâo laih mơ̆ng khul hrơi blŭng hlâo Ơi Adai hmâo ruah kâo mơ̆ng tơ̆ng krah ƀing gih, kiăng kơ mơ̆ng amăng bah kâo pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam kơ ƀing djuai tuai, gơñu dưi hmư̆ laih anŭn đaŏ. 
And the heart-knowing God bore them witness, giving [them] the Holy Spirit as to us also, @ Ơi Adai, Pô thâo pran jua rĭm čô mơnuih, hmâo ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơsĭt kơ tơlơi Ñu tŭ mă ƀing djuai tuai hăng tơlơi Ñu brơi Yang Bơngăt Hiam kơ ƀing gơñu, kar hăng Ñu hmâo brơi laih kơ ƀing ta. 
and put no difference between us and them, having purified their hearts by faith. @ Ơi Adai ƀu pơkah phara ôh ƀing ta hăng ƀing gơñu, samơ̆ Ñu pơrơgoh pran jua ƀing gơñu mơ̆ng tơlơi gơñu đaŏ. 
Now therefore why tempt ye God, by putting a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we have been able to bear? @ Tui anŭn ră anai, hyư̆m ngă ƀing gih khĭn lông lăng Ơi Adai hăng tơlơi ƀing gih pơđua brơi ač ƀơi tơkuai ƀing ding kơna? Ač anŭn ƀing ơi adon ƀing ta wơ̆t ƀing ta pô kŏn dưi glăm lơi. 
But we believe that we shall be saved by the grace of the Lord Jesus, in the same manner as they also. @ Kơđai glaĭ, ƀing ta đaŏ yua mơ̆ng tơlơi pap Khua Yang Yêsu Krist, ƀing ta dưi klaih ăt kar hăng ƀing gơñu mơ̆n.”
And all the multitude kept silence and listened to Barnabas and Paul relating all the signs and wonders which God had wrought among the nations by them. @ Abih bang ƀing bơjơnum leng kơ dŏ rơiăt, gơñu dŏ hmư̆ Barnabas hăng Pôl ră ruai glaĭ abih bang tơlơi gru kơnăl mơyang hăng tơlơi mơsêh mơyang Ơi Adai yua gơñu hmâo ngă laih tơ̆ng krah ƀing djuai tuai. 
And after they had held their peace, James answered, saying, Brethren, listen to me: @ Tơ gơñu pơhiăp giơ̆ng laih, Yakơ pơhiăp: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng dŏ hmư̆ kâo bĕ! 
Simon has related how God first visited to take out of [the] nations a people for his name. @ Simôn hmâo ruai glaĭ laih hyư̆m blŭng hlâo Ơi Adai hmâo čuă ngui laih ƀing djuai tuai, kiăng ruah mă mơ̆ng ƀing gơñu sa phung ană plei pla pioh brơi kơ anăn Ñu. 
And with this agree the words of the prophets; as it is written: @ Tơlơi anŭn hmâo krĕp djơ̆ laih tui hăng tơlơi ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo hmâo čih laih,
After these things I will return, and will rebuild the tabernacle of David which is fallen, and will rebuild its ruins, and will set it up, @  ‘Khua Yang laĭ, giơ̆ng tơlơi anai Kâo či wơ̆t glaĭ dơ̆ng,
Laih anŭn Kâo či pơdơ̆ng glaĭ sang Đawit hmâo tơglưh laih;
Kâo či pơkra glaĭ hơdôm anih răm rai ñu,
Laih anŭn ngă pơkơtang glaĭ ñu.
so that the residue of men may seek out the Lord, and all the nations on whom my name is invoked, saith [the] Lord, who does these things @ Kiăng kơ hơdôm ƀing mơnuih dŏ glaĭ
Laih anŭn abih bang ƀing djuai tuai arăng hmâo iâu laih hăng anăn Kâo, leng kơ hơduah sem Khua Yang.
Khua Yang jing Pô hmâo ngă abih tơlơi anŭn, laĭ tui anŭn.
known from eternity. @ Anŭn jing khul bruă arăng hmâo thâo laih mơ̆ng rơnŭk đưm.’
Wherefore *I* judge, not to trouble those who from the nations turn to God; @ Tui anŭn yơh, tui hăng tơlơi pơmĭn kâo, ƀing ta anăm ngă pơgleh ôh ƀing djuai tuai hlăk wơ̆t glaĭ hăng Ơi Adai. 
but to write to them to abstain from pollutions of idols, and from fornication, and from what is strangled, and from blood. @ Samơ̆ brơi ƀing ta čih hră pơtă kơ ƀing gơñu răng wai gơñu pô mơ̆ng mơnơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă grĭ grañ yua kơ hmâo pơyơr laih kơ rup trah, tơlơi klĕ pyu, ƀơ̆ng hlô mơnơ̆ng djai hơngơ̆t laih anŭn drah. 
For Moses, from generations of old, has in every city those who preach him, being read in the synagogues every sabbath. @ Yua kơ čơdơ̆ng mơ̆ng rơnŭk đưm amăng rĭm boh plei leng kơ hmâo mơnuih pơtô tơlơi juăt Môis, laih anŭn arăng đŏk nanao tơlơi juăt anŭn amăng rĭm sang bơjơnum rĭm hrơi saƀat.”
Then it seemed good to the apostles and to the elders, with the whole assembly, to send chosen men from among them with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch, Judas called Barsabas and Silas, leading men among the brethren, @ Giơ̆ng anŭn ƀing khua ding kơna, ƀing kŏng tha, hrŏm hơbĭt hăng abih bang Phung Sang Ơi Adai khư̆p ư ruah mơ̆ng amăng ƀing gơñu, hăng pơkiaŏ nao ƀing gơ̆ pơ plei Antiôs hrŏm hăng Pôl laih anŭn Barnabas. Anăn ƀing gơñu, Yut pơanăn dơ̆ng Barsabas, laih anŭn Silas, dua čô hmâo tơlơi arăng pơpŭ biă mă amăng ƀing adơi ayŏng. 
having by their hand written [thus]: The apostles, and the elders, and the brethren, to the brethren who are from among [the] nations at Antioch, and [in] Syria and Cilicia, greeting: @ Gơñu brơi ƀing gơ̆ djă ba sa pŏk hră čih tui anai: “Ƀing adơi ayŏng gơmơi jing ƀing khua ding kơna wơ̆t hăng ƀing kŏng tha, mơit tơlơi kơkuh čuă ngui hăng ƀing gih, adơi ayŏng amăng ƀing djuai tuai pơ plei Antiôs, čar Siri, hăng čar Silisi. 
Inasmuch as we have heard that some who went out from amongst us have troubled you by words, upsetting your souls, [saying that ye must be circumcised and keep the law]; to whom we gave no commandment; @ Yua kơ ƀing gơmơi hmâo hmư̆ laih hmâo đơđa mơ̆ng ƀing gơmơi, wơ̆t dah ƀu hmâo ôh tơlơi pơtă hơgĕt mơ̆ng ƀing gơmơi, hmâo pơhiăp hơdôm tơlơi ngă brơi ƀing gih sŭl kŭl, laih anŭn pơrŭng tơlơi pơmĭn ƀing gih, 
it seemed good to us, having arrived at a common judgment, to send chosen men to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul, @ Yua kơ anŭn, ƀing gơmơi pơƀŭt glaĭ hăng hmâo sa tơlơi pơmĭn ruah ƀing mơnuih hăng pơkiaŏ nao ƀing gơ̆ nao pơ ƀing gih hrŏm hơbĭt hăng pô ƀing gơmơi khăp biă mă, Barnabas hăng Pôl, 
men who have given up their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ. @ ƀing hmâo pơsăn laih tơlơi hơdip gơñu pô yua kơ anăn Yêsu Krist Khua Yang ƀing ta. 
We have therefore sent Judas and Silas, who themselves also will tell you by word [of mouth] the same things. @ Hnŭn yơh ƀing gơmơi pơkiaŏ nao laih Yut hăng Silas, hăng amăng bah gơñu pô pơhiăp hăng ƀing gih hơdôm tơlơi ƀing gơmơi hmâo čih laih amăng hră. 
For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay upon you no greater burden than these necessary things: @ Yua kơ Yang Bơngăt Hiam laih anŭn ƀing gơmơi hmâo tŭ ư laih ƀu kiăng pơđua brơi kơ ƀing gih boh kơtraŏ hơgĕt pơkŏn dơ̆ng ôh, gah rơngiao kơ hơdôm bruă kiăng biă mă anai: 
to abstain from things sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what is strangled, and from fornication; keeping yourselves from which ye will do well. Farewell. @ Khŏm kơ̆m ƀơ̆ng mơnơ̆ng ngă yang, drah, hlô mơnơ̆ng djai hơngơ̆t, laih anŭn kơ̆m tơlơi pyu pơde. Ƀing gih djă pioh hơdôm tơlơi kơ̆m anŭn jing hiam kơ ƀing gih yơh. Dŏ hiam hŏ!”
They therefore, being let go, came to Antioch, and having gathered the multitude delivered to [them] the epistle. @ Hnŭn yơh, tơ arăng pơkiaŏ ƀing gơñu nao, gơñu trŭn nao pơ plei Antiôs, iâu pơƀŭt abih bang mơnuih gơñu brơi hră anŭn kơ ƀing gơ̆. 
And having read it, they rejoiced at the consolation. @ Giơ̆ng gơñu đŏk hră anŭn, ƀing gơñu bă hăng tơlơi hơ̆k mơak kơ tơlơi pơtrŭt pơđĭ pran jua anŭn. 
And Judas and Silas, being themselves also prophets, exhorted the brethren with much discourse, and strengthened them. @ Yut hăng Silas ăt jing pô laĭ lui hlâo mơ̆n, yua lu tơlơi pơtô kiăng pơtrŭt pơđĭ pran jua laih anŭn pơkơtang ƀing gơ̆. 
And having passed some time [there], they were let go in peace from the brethren to those who sent them. @ Giơ̆ng kơ gơñu dŏ glaĭ sui ƀiă, ƀing adơi ayŏng đaŏ drông ba gơñu wơ̆t glaĭ hăng tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua pơ ƀing hmâo pơkiaŏ gơñu rai.
And Paul and Barnabas stayed in Antioch, teaching and announcing the glad tidings, with many others also, of the word of the Lord. @ Pôl hăng Barnabas dŏ glaĭ pơ plei Antiôs, laih anŭn hrŏm hơbĭt hăng lu mơnuih pơkŏn pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam hăng pơhrăm boh pơhiăp Khua Yang.
But after certain days Paul said to Barnabas, Let us return now and visit the brethren in every city where we have announced the word of the Lord, [and see] how they are getting on. @ Sui ƀiă kơ anŭn, Pôl laĭ hăng Barnabas: “Brơi ƀing ta wơ̆t glaĭ čuă ƀing adơi ayŏng amăng rĭm boh plei ƀing ta hmâo pơtô laih boh pơhiăp Khua Yang, kiăng thâo hyư̆m gơñu jing.” 
And Barnabas proposed to take with [them] John also, called Mark; @ Barnabas kiăng jak ba Yôhan pơanăn dơ̆ng Markôs nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ñu. 
but Paul thought it not well to take with them him who had abandoned them, [going back] from Pamphylia, and had not gone with them to the work. @ Samơ̆ Pôl pơmĭn ƀu hiam ôh jak ba hrŏm hơbĭt hăng gơñu pô lui hĭ laih gơñu amăng čar Pamphili hăng ƀu nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng gơñu amăng bruă ôh. 
There arose therefore very warm feeling, so that they separated from one another; and Barnabas taking Mark sailed away to Cyprus; @ Yua kơ anŭn, hmâo tơlơi pơrơjah kơtang biă mă, tơl dua gơñu pơčơlah hĭ. Barnabas jak ba Markôs nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ñu đĭ kompăn nao pơ plao ia Čiprơ. 
but Paul having chosen Silas went forth, committed by the brethren to the grace of God. @ Samơ̆ Pôl ruah mă Silas, giơ̆ng kơ ƀing adơi ayŏng jao gơñu kơ tơlơi pap Khua Yang, laih anŭn gơñu nao yơh. 
And he passed through Syria and Cilicia, confirming the assemblies. @ Ñu hyu djŏp djang čar Siri hăng čar Silisi, ngă brơi abih Phung Sang Ơi Adai hmâo tơlơi kơjăp kơtang.
And he came to Derbe and Lystra: and behold, a certain disciple was there, by name Timotheus, son of a Jewish believing woman, but [the] father a Greek, @ Pôl nao pơ plei Derbơ hăng plei Listrơ. Pơ anŭn hmâo sa čô ding kơna anăn ñu Timôthê, ană đah rơkơi kơ sa čô đah kơmơi Yuđa hmâo đaŏ laih, ama ñu jing sa čô mơnuih Grek. 
who had a [good] testimony of the brethren in Lystra and Iconium. @ Ƀing adơi ayŏng plei Listrơ hăng plei Ikôni leng kơ ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ ñu jing mơnuih hiam. 
Him would Paul have go forth with him, and took [him and] circumcised him on account of the Jews who were in those places, for they all knew his father that he was a Greek. @ Pôl kiăng jak ba Timôthê nao hrŏm hơbĭt; hnŭn yơh ñu ngă tơlơi khăt klĭ gơ̆ yua kơ ƀing Yuđa dŏ amăng tring anŭn, abih bang leng kơ thâo kơ ama ñu jing sa čô mơnuih Grek. 
And as they passed through the cities they instructed them to observe the decrees determined on by the apostles and elders who were in Jerusalem. @ Tơ gơñu găn amăng lu boh plei, gơñu ăt pơtă kơ ƀing adơi ayŏng đaŏ khŏm gưt tơlơi phiăn ƀing khua ding kơna hăng ƀing kŏng tha amăng plei Yêrusalem hmâo pơkă laih. 
The assemblies therefore were confirmed in the faith, and increased in number every day. @ Tui anŭn, Phung Sang Ơi Adai hmâo tơlơi kơjăp kơtang amăng tơlơi đaŏ, laih anŭn rĭm hrơi ƀing đaŏ thim đĭ jai lu tui.
And having passed through Phrygia and the Galatian country, having been forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia, @ Gơñu găn djŏp čar Phriji hăng čar Galati, yua kơ Yang Bơngăt Hiam khă gơñu pơtô tơlơi Ơi Adai pơhiăp amăng čar Asi. 
having come down to Mysia, they attempted to go to Bithynia, and the Spirit of Jesus did not allow them; @ Tơ gơñu jĕ truh čar Misia, gơñu kiăng mŭt amăng čar Bithini; samơ̆ Yang Bơngăt Hiam Yêsu ƀu brơi ôh. 
and having passed by Mysia they descended to Troas. @ Tui anŭn yơh gơñu rơbat găn čar Misia laih anŭn trŭn nao pơ plei Trôas. 
And a vision appeared to Paul in the night: There was a certain Macedonian man, standing and beseeching him, and saying, Pass over into Macedonia and help us. @ Amăng mlam Pôl hmâo ƀuh sa rup bơrơđah: Sa čô mơnuih Masêđôn dŏ dơ̆ng kơwưh kơ ñu hăng laĭ: “Rơkâo kơ ih rai pơ Masêđôn hăng djru gơmơi đa!” 
And when he had seen the vision, immediately we sought to go forth to Macedonia, concluding that the Lord had called us to announce to them the glad tidings. @ Tơ Pôl ƀuh rup bơrơđah anŭn, tañ mơtam gơmơi hơduah jơlan nao pơ čar Masêđôn, yua kơ gơmơi thâo klă laih Ơi Adai hmâo iâu gơmơi nao pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam pơ anŭn.
Having sailed therefore away from Troas, we went in a straight course to Samothracia, and on the morrow to Neapolis, @ Tui anŭn gơmơi đĭ kompăn mơ̆ng plei Trôas anăp tơpă nao pơ plao ia Samôtras, laih anŭn hrơi tơdơi kơ anŭn nao truh pơ plei Nêapôlis. 
and thence to Philippi, which is [the] first city of that part of Macedonia, a colony. And we were staying in that city certain days. @ Mơ̆ng anŭn ƀing gơmơi nao pơ plei Philip, plei phŭn kơ tring Masêđôn, anŭn jing čar lơ̆m kơ Rôm wai lăng. Gơmơi dŏ pơ plei anŭn ƀiă hrơi. 
And on the sabbath day we went outside the gate by the river, where it was the custom for prayer to be, and we sat down and spoke to the women who had assembled. @ Amăng hrơi saƀat gơmơi tơbiă nao pơ gah rơngiao amăng jang plei, nao jĕ pơ hang ia krong jing anih gơmơi pơmĭn hmâo ƀing Yuđa pơtŭm glaĭ pioh mông iâu laĭ. Gơmơi dŏ ber hăng pơtô kơ ƀing đah kơmơi hlăk dŏ pơtŭm ƀơi anŭn. 
And a certain woman, by name Lydia, a seller of purple, of the city of Thyatira, who worshipped God, heard; whose heart the Lord opened to attend to the things spoken by Paul. @ Hmâo sa čô đah kơmơi amăng ƀing dŏ hmư̆ gơmơi, anăn gơ̆ HʼLiđi mơ̆ng plei Thiatir, sĭ mơdrô khăn mriah huč, jing sa čô mơnuih hwĭ pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai. Khua Yang pŏk pran jua HʼLiđi ngă kơ ñu kơčăng hmư̆ hiăp Pôl pơtô. 
And when she had been baptised and her house, she besought [us], saying, If ye have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come into my house and abide [there]. And she constrained us. @ Giơ̆ng kơ ñu tŭ ƀatem hrŏm hơbĭt hăng sang anŏ ñu, HʼLiđi jak ƀing gơmơi hăng laĭ: “Tơdah ƀing ih yap kâo tŏng ten sĭt hăng Khua Yang, mŭt dŏ glaĭ bĕ amăng sang kâo.” Laih anŭn ñu pơđur tơl gơmơi mŭt hĭ.
And it came to pass as we were going to prayer that a certain female slave, having a spirit of Python, met us, who brought much profit to her masters by prophesying. @ Hmâo sa hrơi, tơdang gơmơi nao pơ anih iâu laĭ, gơmơi bưp sa čô đah kơmơi hlŭn hmâo yang sat ngă, ñu thâo laĭ lui hlâo tơlơi či truh pơ anăp. Mơ̆ng bruă pơjâu mơnăn anŭn, ñu ngă brơi khua ñu jing pơdrŏng. 
She, having followed Paul and us, cried saying, These men are bondmen of the Most High God, who announce to you [the] way of salvation. @ Ñu đuaĭ tui Pôl hăng ƀing gơmơi, ur kraih: “Ƀing anai jing ƀing ding kơna kơ Ơi Adai Pô Glông Hloh. Gơñu pơhaih jơlan tơlơi pơklaih kơ ƀing gih.” 
And this she did many days. And Paul, being distressed, turned, and said to the spirit, I enjoin thee in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her. And it came out the same hour. @ Ñu ngă tui anŭn amăng lu hrơi, tơl Pôl bơngơ̆t bơngañ ƀu sŭk, tui anŭn ñu wir glaĭ laĭ kơ yang sat: “Amăng anăn Yêsu Krist kâo pơđar kơ ŏng tơbiă bĕ mơ̆ng đah kơmơi anai.” Ƀơi mông anŭn mơtam yang sat tơbiă mơ̆ng ñu.
And her masters, seeing that the hope of their gains was gone, having seized Paul and Silas, dragged [them] into the market before the magistrates; @ Tơ ƀing khua đah kơmơi anŭn ƀuh gơñu rơngiă hĭ laih tơlơi čang rơmang dưi ƀơ̆ng lu prăk, gơñu mă čaŏ Pôl hăng Silas, dui ba gơñu pơ anih sang bruă kơnuk kơna, pioh gơñu ƀơi anăp ƀing khua wai lăng. 
and having brought them up to the praetors, said, These men utterly trouble our city, being Jews, @ Gơñu dui ba ƀing gơ̆ nao pơ anăp khua kơnuk kơna Rôm, gơñu laĭ: “Ƀing mơnuih anai jing ƀing Yuđa, gơñu ngă pơrŭng plei ƀing ta. 
and announce customs which it is not lawful for us to receive nor practise, being Romans. @ Gơñu pơtô tơlơi phiăn pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng tơlơi juăt, ƀing ta ƀu tŭ ôh kŏn dưi ngă tui lơi, yua kơ ƀing ta jing mơnuih Rôm.” 
And the crowd rose up too against them; and the praetors, having torn off their clothes, commanded to scourge [them]. @ Ƀing mơnuih lu tơgŭ đĭ pơgop hăng gơñu ăt pơkơdơ̆ng hăng dua čô ding kơna mơ̆n; tui anŭn yơh, ƀing khua wai lăng hek lui ao ƀing gơ̆ hăng pơđar brơi arăng taih ƀing gơ̆ hăng gai. 
And having laid many stripes upon them they cast [them] into prison, charging the jailor to keep them safely; @ Giơ̆ng arăng taih ƀing gơ̆ lu laih, gơñu krư̆ hĭ ƀing gơ̆ amăng sang mơnă, hăng pơtă kơ khua sang mơnă gak wai hăng tơlơi kơjăp. 
who, having received such a charge, cast them into the inner prison, and secured their feet to the stocks. @ Hmư̆ tơlơi pơtă anŭn, khua wai sang mơnă krư̆ ƀing gơ̆ amăng anih kơnăm mơmŏt, hăng anŭh hĭ tơkai ƀing gơ̆.
And at midnight Paul and Silas, in praying, were praising God with singing, and the prisoners listened to them. @ Hlăk tơ̆ng krah mlam, tơdang Pôl hăng Silas iâu laĭ hăng adoh bơni hơơč kơ Ơi Adai, laih anŭn ƀing mơnă leng kơ dŏ hmư̆ ƀing gơ̆. 
And suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison shook, and all the doors were immediately opened, and the bonds of all loosed. @ Blĭp hmâo tơlơi pơpư̆ lŏn tơnah kơtang biă mă, tơl atur sang mơnă pơpư̆ pơgơi; mông anŭn abih bang bah amăng leng kơ pŏk hĭ soh sel, abih bang hrĕ čuăk tơgloh hĭ mơ̆ng ƀing mơnă. 
And the jailor being awakened out of his sleep, and seeing the doors of the prison opened, having drawn a sword was going to kill himself, thinking the prisoners had fled. @ Khua wai sang mơnă pơdưh hăng ƀuh bah amăng sang mơnă leng kơ pŏk hĭ soh sel, ñu pơmĭn ƀing mơnă đuaĭ abih laih, ñu suă đao kiăng pơdjai ñu pô. 
But Paul called out with a loud voice, saying, Do thyself no harm, for we are all here. @ Samơ̆ Pôl ur iâu: “Anăm ngă pơrăm pô ih ôh, yua kơ abih bang gơmơi ăt dŏ pơ anai soh sel!” 
And having asked for lights, he rushed in, and, trembling, fell down before Paul and Silas. @ Pô wai sang mơnă iâu arăng mă apui kơđen hăng nao mŭt amăng sang mơnă. Ñu tơtư̆ drơi jan hăng tơlơi hwĭ biă mă laih anŭn bon ƀơi yŭ tơkai Pôl hăng Silas. 
And leading them out said, Sirs, what must I do that I may be saved? @ Giơ̆ng anŭn ñu ba dua gơñu tơbiă pơ gah rơngiao, hăng tơña: “Ơ ƀing khua, hơgĕt kâo khŏm ngă kiăng kơ dưi klaih?” 
And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus and thou shalt be saved, thou and thy house. @ Gơñu laĭ glaĭ: “Đaŏ bĕ kơ Khua Yang Yêsu, ih laih anŭn mơnuih amăng sang anŏ ih či klaih.” 
And they spoke to him the word of the Lord, with all that were in his house. @ Gơñu pơtô boh pơhiăp Khua Yang kơ ñu wơ̆t kơ abih bang ƀing dŏ amăng sang ñu. 
And he took them the same hour of the night and washed [them] from their stripes; and was baptised, he and all his straightway. @ Amăng mlam anŭn, ƀơi mông anŭn mơtam, khua sang mơnă ba gơñu tơbiă hăng rao nam rơka gơñu. Laih anŭn ñu hăng abih sang anŏ ñu leng kơ tŭ ƀatem mơtam. 
And having brought them into his house he laid the table [for them], and rejoiced with all his house, having believed in God. @ Pô wai sang mơnă ba gơñu mŭt amăng sang ñu, laih anŭn pŭ pơkra mơnơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă kơ dua gơñu; ñu hăng abih bang sang anŏ ñu bă hăng tơlơi hơ̆k mơak biă mă, yua kơ hmâo đaŏ laih kơ Ơi Adai.
And when it was day, the praetors sent the lictors, saying, Let those men go. @ Truh mơguah adai rơđah, ƀing khua prŏng pơkiaŏ nao ƀing tơhan gak wai laĭ kơ pô wai sang mơnă hăng laĭ: “Phư hĭ bĕ ƀing mơnuih anŭn.” 
And the jailor reported these words to Paul: The praetors have sent that ye may be let go. Now therefore go out and depart in peace. @ Tui anŭn, pô wai sang mơnă laĭ kơ Pôl: “Ƀing khua prŏng pơkiaŏ mơnuih rai laĭ brơi phư hĭ yơh ƀing gih. Tui anŭn ră anai tơbiă bĕ, laih anŭn nao hăng tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua.” 
But Paul said to them, Having beaten us publicly uncondemned, us who are Romans, they have cast us into prison, and now they thrust us out secretly? no, indeed, but let them come themselves and bring us out. @ Samơ̆ Pôl laĭ kơ gơñu: “Gơmơi jing ƀing ană plei pla Rôm; gơñu aka phat kơđi ƀing gơmơi ôh samơ̆ gơñu taih laih gơmơi hăng gai ƀơi anăp ƀing ană plei pla hăng krư̆ hĭ ƀing gơmơi amăng sang mơnă. Ră anai gơñu kiăng phư hĭ gơmơi hăng tơlơi hơgơ̆m hă? Ƀu dưi ôh! Khŏm ƀing gơñu pô rai phư gơmơi.” 
And the lictors reported these words to the praetors. And they were afraid when they heard they were Romans. @ Ƀing khua tơhan laĭ pơthâo boh pơhiăp anŭn kơ ƀing khua wai lăng, ƀing gơñu hwĭ biă mă, tơ gơñu thâo Pôl hăng Silas jing ană plei pla Rôm. 
And they came and besought them, and having brought them out, asked them to go out of the city. @ Tui anŭn, ƀing khua prŏng nao rơkâo tơlơi pap mơ̆ng gơñu. Gơñu pŏk hĭ dua gơñu hăng rơkâo dua gơñu đuaĭ mơ̆ng plei. 
And having gone out of the prison, they came to Lydia; and having seen the brethren, they exhorted them and went away. @ Tui anŭn gơñu tơbiă mơ̆ng sang mơnă hăng nao pơ sang HʼLiđi. Giơ̆ng gơñu čuă ngui hăng pơtrŭt pơđĭ pran jua ƀing adơi ayŏng, gơñu tơbiă nao yơh.
And having journeyed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where was the synagogue of the Jews. @ Pôl hăng Silas găn nao plei Amphipôlis hăng plei Apôlôni, giơ̆ng anŭn truh pơ plei Têsalônik. Pơ anŭn hmâo sa boh sang bơjơnum ƀing ană Yuđa. 
And according to Paul's custom he went in among them, and on three sabbaths reasoned with them from the scriptures, @ Tui hăng tơlơi ñu juăt ngă, Pôl mŭt amăng sang bơjơnum, amăng klâo hrơi saƀat ñu pơrơjah pơgăl hăng gơñu, mă mơ̆ng Tơlơi Ơi Adai Pơhiăp, 
opening and laying down that the Christ must have suffered and risen up from among the dead, and that this is the Christ, Jesus whom *I* announce to you. @ Pôl yua hră Ơi Adai pơhiăp pơblang bơrơđah hăng pơsĭt brơi kơ tơlơi Krist khŏm tŭ tơlơi tơnap tap laih anŭn hơdip glaĭ mơ̆ng ƀing djai. Ñu laĭ: “Yêsu pô kâo ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ ƀing gih anai, Ñu yơh jing Yang Krist.” 
And some of them believed, and joined themselves to Paul and Silas, and of the Greeks who worshipped, a great multitude, and of the chief women not a few. @ Hmâo đơđa amăng ƀing gơñu tŭ ư nao hrŏm hăng Pôl laih anŭn Silas. Laih anŭn kar kaĭ mơ̆n hmâo lu ƀing Grek kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai laih, wơ̆t hăng lu ƀing đah kơmơi arăng pơpŭ ăt đaŏ mơ̆n. 
But the Jews having been stirred up to jealousy, and taken to [themselves] certain wicked men of the lowest rabble, and having got a crowd together, set the city in confusion; and having beset the house of Jason sought to bring them out to the people; @ Samơ̆ ƀing Yuđa moañ nač, jak ƀing sat ƀai tă tăn dŏ amăng jơlan glung. Gơñu pơƀŭt pơsur mơnuih lu ngă pơrŭng pơrăng ur amăng plei, laih anŭn blŭng mŭt sang Jason, sem hơduah Pôl hăng Silas, kiăng mă gơñu ba pơ gah rơngiao ƀơi anăp ană plei pla. 
and not having found them, dragged Jason and certain brethren before the politarchs, crying out, These [men] that have set the world in tumult, are come here also, @ Samơ̆ tơ gơñu sem ƀu ƀuh ƀing anŭn ôh, gơñu mă dui ba Jason hăng đơđa ƀing adơi ayŏng đaŏ nao pơ anăp ƀing khua wai lăng plei prŏng, laih anŭn ur: “Ƀing anai hmâo ngă pơrŭng abih lŏn tơnah, ră anai gơñu truh laih pơ anai, 
whom Jason has received; and these all do contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying, that there is another king, Jesus. @ laih anŭn Jason hmâo pơdŏp gơñu amăng sang ñu. Abih bang gơñu pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng tơlơi juăt Sêsar, gơñu laĭ hmâo sa čô pơtao pơkŏn jing Yêsu.” 
And they troubled the crowd and the politarchs when they heard these things. @ Hmư̆ hơdôm tơlơi anŭn, ƀing ană plei pla hăng ƀing khua wai lăng plei prŏng hmâo tơlơi rŭng răng. 
And having taken security of Jason and the rest, they let them go. @ Giơ̆ng ƀing khua prŏng mă Jason hăng ƀing mơnuih pơkŏn kla prăk pơsir tui hăng tơlơi juăt pơkă, gơñu phư hĭ ƀing gơ̆ yơh.
But the brethren immediately sent away, in the night, Paul and Silas to Berea; who, being arrived, went away into the synagogue of the Jews. @ Amăng mlam anŭn mơtam ƀing adơi ayŏng pơkiaŏ Pôl hăng Silas nao pơ plei Bêrê. Tơ gơñu truh laih, gơñu mŭt amăng sang bơjơnum ƀing Yuđa. 
And these were more noble than those in Thessalonica, receiving the word with all readiness of mind, daily searching the scriptures if these things were so. @ Ƀing ană Yuđa pơ anai jing mơnuih hmâo pran jua hiam hloh kơ ƀing pơ plei Têsalônik, yua kơ ƀing gơñu tŭ mă boh pơhiăp Ơi Adai hăng abih pran jua kiăng biă mă, rĭm hrơi gơñu kơsem lăng hră Ơi Adai Pơhiăp kiăng thâo kơ tơlơi Pôl pơtô anŭn jing djơ̆ mơ̆. 
Therefore many from among them believed, and of Grecian women of the upper classes and men not a few. @ Yua kơ anŭn hmâo lu mơnuih amăng ƀing gơñu đaŏ kơ Khua Yang, amăng anŭn hmâo ƀing đah kơmơi Grek jing ƀing arăng pơpŭ, laih anŭn wơ̆t ƀing đah rơkơi lu mơ̆n. 
But when the Jews from Thessalonica knew that the word of God was announced in Berea also by Paul, they came there also, stirring up the crowds. @ Samơ̆ tơ ƀing Yuđa pơ plei Têsalônik thâo Pôl ăt pơtô boh pơhiăp Ơi Adai pơ plei Bêrê mơ̆n, gơñu nao pơ anŭn mơ̆n kiăng pơsur ƀing ană plei ngă pơrŭng. 
And then immediately the brethren sent away Paul to go as to the sea; but Silas and Timotheus abode there. @ Hlăk anŭn tañ mơtam ƀing adơi ayŏng pơkiaŏ Pôl nao gah ia rơsĭ. Samơ̆ Silas hăng Timôthê ăt dŏ glaĭ pơ plei Bêrê. 
But they that conducted Paul brought him as far as Athens; and, having received a commandment to Silas and Timotheus, that they should come to him as quickly as possible, they departed. @ Ƀing mơnuih ba Pôl nao truh pơ plei Athen, laih anŭn gơñu wơ̆t glaĭ pơ plei Bêrê, giơ̆ng Pôl hmâo pơtă kơ gơñu brơi laĭ kơ Silas hăng Timôthê khŏm nao pơ ñu jai tañ jai hiam hloh.
But in Athens, while Paul was waiting for them, his spirit was painfully excited in him seeing the city given up to idolatry. @ Tơdang Pôl dŏ tơguan Silas hăng Timôthê pơ plei Athen, Pôl bă hăng tơlơi hil, yua kơ ñu ƀuh plei anŭn bă hăng rup trah. 
He reasoned therefore in the synagogue with the Jews, and those who worshipped, and in the market-place every day with those he met with. @ Tui anŭn, amăng sang bơjơnum Pôl pơrơjah pơgăl hăng ƀing Yuđa wơ̆t hăng ƀing djuai tuai tui tơlơi đaŏ Yuđa, laih anŭn wơ̆t hăng ƀing mơnuih ñu bưp pơ sang sĭ mia rĭm hrơi. 
But some also of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers attacked him. And some said, What would this chatterer say? and some, He seems to be an announcer of foreign demons, because he announced the glad tidings of Jesus and the resurrection [to them]. @ Kar kaĭ mơ̆n hmâo đơđa ƀing hrăm lu amăng tơpul Êpikur laih anŭn ƀing Stôik bưp ñu. Đơđa gơñu laĭ: “Hơgĕt pô thâo pơkrưh anai kiăng laĭ?”
Ƀing pơkŏn laĭ: “Rŏ dah pô anai pơtô tơlơi ƀing yang čar tuai,” yua kơ Pôl pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam Yêsu laih anŭn tơlơi hơdip glaĭ. 
And having taken hold on him they brought [him] to Areopagus, saying, Might we know what this new doctrine which is spoken by thee [is]? @ Gơñu mă Pôl hăng ba nao pơ anih bơjơnum Arêôpa, hăng laĭ: “Dưi mơ̆ ih brơi gơmơi thâo hơgĕt tơlơi pơtô phrâo ih hmâo anŭn? 
For thou bringest certain strange things to our ears. We wish therefore to know what these things may mean. @ Yua kơ khul tơlơi ih pơtô gơmơi hmư̆ phara đơi; hnŭn yơh gơmơi kiăng thâo hơgĕt khul tơlơi anŭn kiăng laĭ.” 
Now all [the] Athenians and the strangers sojourning there spent their time in nothing else than to tell and to hear the news. @ Yua kơ abih ƀing mơnuih plei Athen hăng abih ƀing djuai tuai dŏ pơ anŭn kơnơ̆ng hơduah kiăng pơhiăp hăng hmư̆ tơlơi phrâo hling đôč.
And Paul standing in the midst of Areopagus said, Athenians, in every way I see you given up to demon worship; @ Tui anŭn Pôl dŏ dơ̆ng tơ̆ng krah ƀơi anih arăng pia Arêôpa hăng laĭ: “Ơ ƀing mơnuih plei Athen, kâo ƀuh ƀing gih hur har biă mă amăng tơlơi kơkuh pơpŭ kơ yang. 
for, passing through and beholding your shrines, I found also an altar on which was inscribed, To the unknown God. Whom therefore ye reverence, not knowing [him], him I announce to you. @ Yua kơ tơdang kâo nao djŏp amăng plei ƀing gih laih anŭn kâo lăng khul anih ƀing gih kơkuh pơpŭ, kâo ăt ƀuh mơ̆n ƀơi kơƀang ngă yang ƀing gih hmâo čih boh hră: ‘Kơkuh Yang Ƀu Thâo Krăn.’ Tui anŭn yang ƀing gih kơkuh pơpŭ samơ̆ ƀu thâo krăn ôh, kơ Pô anŭn yơh kâo pơhaih kơ ƀing gih. 
The God who has made the world and all things which are in it, *he*, being Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in temples made with hands, @ Ơi Adai, Pô hrih lŏn tơnah laih anŭn abih bang mơnơ̆ng amăng anŭn, jing Khua Yang kơ adai hăng lŏn tơnah, ƀu dŏ ôh amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ tơngan ană mơnuih ngă. 
nor is served by men's hands as needing something, himself giving to all life and breath and all things; @ Ñu ăt kŏn kiăng tơngan ană mơnuih mă bruă brơi kơ Ñu lơi, hrup hăng Ñu kơƀah mơnơ̆ng, yua kơ mơ̆ng Ñu yơh pô brơi tơlơi hơdip, tơlơi suă jua, hăng djŏp mơta mơnơ̆ng pơkŏn kơ ană mơnuih. 
and has made of one blood every nation of men to dwell upon the whole face of the earth, having determined ordained times and the boundaries of their dwelling, @ Mơ̆ng sa čô mơnuih, Ñu hmâo pơjing rai abih djuai mơnuih hăng ngă brơi gơñu dŏ tar ƀar lŏn tơnah. Ñu hmâo pơkă brơi rơnŭk ƀing gơñu hơdip hăng guai lŏn anih gơñu dŏ, 
that they may seek God; if indeed they might feel after him and find him, although he is not far from each one of us: @ Ñu ngă tui anŭn kiăng kơ gơñu ruaih sư̆, sem hơduah Ơi Adai hăng tơlơi čang rơmang dưi bưp Ñu. Wơ̆t dah Ñu ƀu dŏ ataih hăng rĭm čô amăng ƀing ta ôh. 
for in him we live and move and exist; as also some of the poets amongst you have said, For we are also his offspring. @ Yua kơ,
‘Amăng Ñu ƀing ta dưi hmâo rai, hmâo tơlơi hơdip, tơlơi pơpư̆ hyu.’
Kar hăng đơđa ƀing thâo pơrơtưh ƀing gih hmâo laĭ,
Ƀing ta ăt jing ană tơčo Ñu mơ̆n.
Being therefore [the] offspring of God, we ought not to think that which is divine to be like gold or silver or stone, [the] graven form of man's art and imagination. @ Tui anŭn, yua kơ ƀing ta jing ƀing ană Ơi Adai, anăm ƀing ta pơmĭn ôh kơ Ơi Adai jing kar hăng hơbŏ rup trah ngă hăng mah, prăk, ƀôdah boh pơtâo mơ̆ng bruă tơngan hăng tơlơi rơgơi ană mơnuih ngă. 
God therefore, having overlooked the times of ignorance, now enjoins men that they shall all everywhere repent, @ Ơi Adai ƀu tuĕn pioh ôh tơlơi soh rơnŭk mơnuih mlŭk mơgu đưm, samơ̆ ră anai Ñu pơđar kơ abih bang mơnuih dŏ tar ƀar khŏm kơhmal tơlơi soh. 
because he has set a day in which he is going to judge the habitable earth in righteousness by [the] man whom he has appointed, giving the proof [of it] to all [in] having raised him from among [the] dead. @ Yua kơ Ơi Adai hmâo pơkă laih sa hrơi Ñu či brơi sa čô pô Ñu hmâo ruah laih phat kơđi lŏn tơnah hăng tơlơi tơpă. Ñu hmâo ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơklă laih tơlơi anŭn kơ abih bang mơnuih hăng tơlơi Ñu hmâo pơhơdip glaĭ laih Yêsu mơ̆ng ƀing djai.”
And when they heard [of the] resurrection of the dead, some mocked, and some said, We will hear thee again also concerning this. @ Tơ gơñu hmư̆ Pôl pơhiăp djơ̆ kơ tơlơi hơdip glaĭ mơ̆ng ƀing djai, đơđa mơnuih djik mưč; samơ̆ ƀing pơkŏn laĭ: “Ƀing gơmơi kiăng hmư̆ ih pơhiăp kơ tơlơi anai sa wơ̆t dơ̆ng.” 
Thus Paul went out of their midst. @ Tui anŭn, Pôl tơbiă hĭ mơ̆ng gơñu. 
But some men joining themselves to him believed; among whom also was Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman by name Damaris, and others with them. @ Hmâo đơđa đuaĭ tui hăng ñu laih anŭn đaŏ, amăng ƀing anŭn hmâo Denis jing sa čô amăng tơpul ƀing khua phat kơđi Arêôpa, hăng sa čô đah kơmơi anăn gơ̆ jing HʼDamaris, laih anŭn wơ̆t hăng ƀing mơnuih pơkŏn dơ̆ng.
And after these things, having left Athens, he came to Corinth; @ Giơ̆ng kơ anŭn, Pôl mơ̆ng plei Athen nao pơ plei Kôrantô. 
and finding a certain Jew by name Aquila, of Pontus by race, just come from Italy, and Priscilla his wife, (because Claudius had ordered all the Jews to leave Rome,) came to them, @ Pơ anŭn ñu bưp sa čô mơnuih Yuđa anăn ñu Akilas mơnuih čar Pônt, mơ̆ng čar Itali hrŏm hơbĭt hăng bơnai ñu HʼPrisil phrâo truh, yua kơ pơtao Klôd hmâo pơđar laih brơi abih bang ƀing Yuđa tơbiă mơ̆ng plei Rôm. Pôl nao čuă gơñu, 
and because they were of the same trade abode with them, and wrought. For they were tent-makers by trade. @ laih anŭn yua kơ gơñu mă sa mơta bruă hrŏm hơbĭt, hnŭn yơh Pôl dŏ hrŏm amăng sang gơñu. Gơñu ngă bruă sĭt sang khăn. 
And he reasoned in the synagogue every sabbath, and persuaded Jews and Greeks. @ Rĭm hrơi saƀat, Pôl pơtô amăng sang bơjơnum, laih anŭn pơđur ƀing Yuđa hăng ƀing Grek đaŏ.
And when both Silas and Timotheus came down from Macedonia, Paul was pressed in respect of the word, testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Christ. @ Tơ Silas hăng Timôthê mơ̆ng čar Masêđôn truh, Pôl pioh hăng abih pran jua kơnơ̆ng kơ tơlơi pơtô, pơhrăm hăng ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơklă brơi kơ ƀing Yuđa kơ Yêsu jing Yang Krist. 
But as they opposed and spoke injuriously, he shook his clothes, and said to them, Your blood be upon your own head: *I* [am] pure; from henceforth I will go to the nations. @ Ƀing Yuđa pơkơdơ̆ng hăng hơtoh djraĭ kơ ñu, Pôl rơyuh ao ñu hăng laĭ kơ ƀing anŭn: “Brơi drah ƀing gih tuh glaĭ ƀơi akŏ ƀing gih pô. Kâo ƀu soh hơgĕt gĕt ôh. Mơ̆ng anai pơ anăp, kâo či nao pơ ƀing djuai tuai.” 
And departing thence he came to the house of a certain [man], by name Justus, who worshipped God, whose house adjoined the synagogue. @ Ñu tơbiă mơ̆ng anŭn hăng mŭt amăng sang sa čô đah rơkơi anăn ñu Titus Justus, sa čô mơnuih kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai; sang ñu ƀơi guai hăng sang bơjơnum. 
But Crispus the ruler of the synagogue believed in the Lord with all his house; and many of the Corinthians hearing, believed, and were baptised. @ Krispus, khua wai sang bơjơnum, hrŏm hơbĭt hăng abih sang anŏ ñu đaŏ kơ Khua Yang. Ăt hmâo mơ̆n lu ƀing Kôrantô hmư̆ Pôl pơtô, gơñu đaŏ laih anŭn tŭ ƀatem.
And the Lord said by vision in [the] night to Paul, Fear not, but speak and be not silent; @ Amăng mlam, Khua Yang laĭ kơ Pôl amăng tơlơi pơƀuh tui anai: “Anăm hwĭ ôh! Samơ̆ pơhiăp bĕ laih anŭn anăm dŏ rơiăt ôh; 
because *I* am with thee, and no one shall set upon thee to injure thee; because I have much people in this city. @ yua kơ Kâo dŏ hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ih, ƀu hmâo hlơi dưi ngă sat kơ ih ôh. Yua kơ Kâo hmâo lu mơnuih amăng plei anai.” 
And he remained [there] a year and six months, teaching among them the word of God. @ Tui anŭn Pôl dŏ pơ anŭn sa thŭn năm blan, pơtô boh pơhiăp Ơi Adai kơ ƀing gơñu.
But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews with one consent rose against Paul and led him to the judgment-seat, @ Hlăk Galiôn ngă khua wai kwar Akai, ƀing Yuđa pơgop glaĭ pơkơdơ̆ng hăng Pôl laih anŭn mă ba ñu pơ sang phat kơđi, 
saying, This [man] persuades men to worship God contrary to the law. @ Gơñu laĭ: “Pô anai pơgŏ ƀing ană plei kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai phara hăng tơlơi juăt.”
But as Paul was going to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, If indeed it was some wrong or wicked criminality, O Jews, of reason I should have borne with you; @ Tơ Pôl čơdơ̆ng ha pơhiăp, Galiôn laĭ kơ ƀing Yuđa: “Ơ ƀing Yuđa, tơdah hmâo tơlơi hơgĕt soh ƀôdah sat ƀai, sĭt kâo hmâo tơlơi klih yua gir kiăng kơ dŏ hmư̆ ƀing gih. 
but if it be questions about words, and names, and the law that ye have, see to it yourselves; [for] *I* do not intend to be judge of these things. @ Samơ̆ yua kơ anai jing tơlơi pơrơjah pơgăl kơ boh pơhiăp, kơ anăn kơnăl, laih anŭn kơ tơlơi juăt kơ pô ƀing gih, brơi ƀing gih phat kơđi mă gih pô bĕ; kâo ƀu kiăng phat kơđi tơlơi anŭn ôh.” 
And he drove them from the judgment-seat. @ Giơ̆ng anŭn Galiôn puh pơđuaĭ hĭ gơñu mơ̆ng sang phat kơđi. 
And having all laid hold on Sosthenes the ruler of the synagogue, they beat him before the judgment-seat. And Gallio troubled himself about none of these things. @ Laih anŭn abih bang ƀing anŭn mă Sôsthen khua wai sang bơjơnum, hăng taih gơ̆ ƀơi anăp sang phat kơđi, samơ̆ Galiôn ƀu bơngơ̆t kơ tơlơi anŭn ôh.
And Paul, having yet stayed [there] many days, took leave of the brethren and sailed thence to Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila, having shorn his head in Cenchrea, for he had a vow; @  Giơ̆ng tơlơi anŭn Pôl dŏ glaĭ sui hrơi dơ̆ng pơ plei Kôrantô. Laih anŭn ñu lui hĭ adơi ayŏng, đĭ kompăn nao pơ čar Siri, hrŏm hăng HʼPrisil laih anŭn Akilas, giơ̆ng ñu kuah hĭ ƀuk ñu pơ plei Sankrê, yua kơ ñu hmâo ƀuăn rơ̆ng laih. 
and he arrived at Ephesus, and left them there. But entering himself into the synagogue he reasoned with the Jews. @ Tơ gơñu truh pơ plei Êphêsô, Pôl lui hĭ HʼPrisil hăng Akilas pơ anŭn; giơ̆ng anŭn ñu mŭt amăng sang bơjơnum laih anŭn pơrơjah pơgăl hăng ƀing Yuđa. 
And when they asked him that he would remain for a longer time [with them] he did not accede, @ Ƀing gơñu rơkâo Pôl dŏ glaĭ sui ƀiă dơ̆ng, samơ̆ ñu hơngah; 
but bade them farewell, saying, [I must by all means keep the coming feast at Jerusalem]; I will return to you again, if God will: and he sailed away from Ephesus. @ ñu lui hĭ ƀing gơ̆ hăng laĭ, “Kâo či wơ̆t glaĭ pơ ƀing gih dơ̆ng tơdah Ơi Adai kiăng.” Laih anŭn ñu đĭ kompăn đuaĭ hĭ mơ̆ng plei Êphêsô.
And landing at Caesarea, and having gone up and saluted the assembly, he went down to Antioch. @ Tơ ñu trŭn mơ̆ng kompăn pơ Sêsarê, ñu nao pơ Yêrusalem, nao čuă ngui Phung Sang Ơi Adai pơ anŭn. Laih anŭn ñu trŭn nao pơ plei Antiôs. 
And having stayed [there] some time, he went forth, passing in order through the country of Galatia and Phrygia, establishing all the disciples. @ Giơ̆ng kơ ñu dŏ pơ anŭn sui ƀiă, ñu nao čuă lu anih amăng čar Galati hăng čar Phriji, ngă pơkơjăp pơkơtang abih bang ƀing ding kơna.
But a certain Jew, Apollos by name, an Alexandrian by race, an eloquent man, who was mighty in the scriptures, arrived at Ephesus. @ Hlăk anŭn hmâo sa čô mơnuih Yuđa anăn ñu Apôlôs, plei ñu pơ Aleksandri, ñu truh pơ plei Êphêsô. Ñu jing sa čô mơnuih rơgơi pơhiăp biă mă hăng thâo hluh Tơlơi Ơi Adai Pơhiăp lu. 
He was instructed in the way of the Lord, and being fervent in his spirit, he spoke and taught exactly the things concerning Jesus, knowing only the baptism of John. @ Ñu hmâo hrăm laih Jơlan Khua Yang. Hăng hmâo pran jua hur har pơtô, pơhrăm ƀlep djơ̆ hơdôm khul tơlơi djơ̆ kơ Yêsu, samơ̆ ñu kơnơ̆ng thâo kơ tơlơi ƀatem Yôhan đôč. 
And *he* began to speak boldly in the synagogue. And Aquila and Priscilla, having heard him, took him to [them] and unfolded to him the way of God more exactly. @ Ñu čơdơ̆ng pơtô hăng tơlơi khĭn biă mă amăng sang bơjơnum. Tơ HʼPrisil hăng Akilas hmư̆ ñu pơtô, gơñu jak ba gơ̆ pơ sang hăng pơblang brơi kơ ñu jơlan Ơi Adai klă rơđah hloh dơ̆ng. 
And when he purposed to go into Achaia, the brethren wrote to the disciples engaging them to receive him, who, being come, contributed much to those who believed through grace. @ Tơ Apôlôs kiăng nao pơ čar Akai, ƀing adơi ayŏng đaŏ djru ñu hăng tơlơi čih hră pơtă kơ ƀing ding kơna pơ čar anŭn brơi jum ñu hăng tơlơi klă hiam. Tơ ñu truh laih, ñu djru lu biă mă kơ ƀing mơnuih yua kơ mơ̆ng tơlơi pap Ơi Adai gơñu tŭ mă tơlơi đaŏ, 
For he with great force convinced the Jews publicly, shewing by the scriptures that Jesus was the Christ. @ yua kơ ñu pơgăl kơtang biă mă hăng ƀing ană Yuđa ƀơi anăp ƀing mơnuih lu, yua hră Ơi Adai pơhiăp pơrơđah pơsĭt Yêsu yơh jing Yang Krist.
But after the tumult had ceased, Paul having called the disciples to [him] and embraced [them], went away to go to Macedonia. @ Tơ tơlơi rŭng răng anŭn abih laih, Pôl pơkiaŏ nao arăng iâu pơƀŭt ƀing ding kơna. Giơ̆ng kơ pơtrŭt pơđĭ pran jua ƀing gơ̆, ñu lui ƀing gơ̆ hăng nao pơ čar Masêđôn. 
And having passed through those parts, and having exhorted them with much discourse, he came to Greece. @ Ñu găn djŏp tring anŭn, ñu yua lu boh pơhiăp pơtrŭt pơđĭ pran jua ƀing đaŏ, giơ̆ng anŭn ñu truh pơ čar Grek. 
And having spent three months [there], a treacherous plot against him having been set on foot by the Jews, as he was going to sail to Syria, [the] resolution was adopted of returning through Macedonia. @ Ñu dŏ pơ anŭn klâo blan. Tơdang ñu čơdơ̆ng đĭ kompăn nao pơ čar Siri, ñu thâo ƀing Yuđa dưm tơlơi mơneč ngă sat ñu. Tui anŭn ñu khư̆p ư wơ̆t glaĭ găn čar Masêđôn. 
And there accompanied him as far as Asia, Sopater [son] of Pyrrhus, a Berean; and of Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus, and Gaius and Timotheus of Derbe, and of Asia, Tychicus and Trophimus. @ Sôpatê ană đah rơkơi Pirus plei Bêrê nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ñu. Mơ̆ng ƀing Têsalônik hmâo Aristark hăng Sêkundu; Gaius plei Derbơ laih anŭn Timôthê; čar Asi hmâo Tisik hăng Trôphim. 
These going before waited for us in Troas; @ Ƀing anai nao hlâo hăng dŏ tơguan ƀing gơmơi pơ plei Trôas. 
but we sailed away from Philippi after the days of unleavened bread, and we came to them to Troas in five days, where we spent seven days. @ Giơ̆ng hrơi phĕt Ƀañ Tơpŭng Ƀu Hmâo Tơpơi, gơmơi đĭ kompăn mơ̆ng plei Philip, laih anŭn rơgao rơma hrơi gơmơi bưp ƀing gơñu pơ plei Trôas. Pơ anŭn gơmơi dŏ tơjuh hrơi.
And the first day of the week, we being assembled to break bread, Paul discoursed to them, about to depart on the morrow. And he prolonged the discourse till midnight. @ Hrơi tal sa amăng hrơi kơ̆m, tơdang ƀing gơmơi bơjơnum glaĭ kiăng wơ̆k ƀañ tơpŭng. Pôl pơtô kơ ƀing ding kơna, yua kơ hrơi pơgi gơmơi khŏm nao, hnŭn yơh Pôl pơtô tơl truh krah mlam. 
And there were many lights in the upper room where we were assembled. @ Amăng adŭ tal glong anih gơmơi bơjơnum hmâo lu apui kơđen. 
And a certain youth, by name Eutychus, sitting at the window-opening, overpowered by deep sleep, while Paul discoursed very much at length, having been overpowered by the sleep, fell from the third story down to the bottom, and was taken up dead. @ Hmâo sa čô tơdăm anăn ñu Ơtik dŏ ber ƀơi bah amăng phă. Ñu pĭt gui tơdang Pôl dŏ pơtô glong biă mă. Laih anŭn ñu pĭt wơr, mơ̆ng adŭ tal klâo ñu lĕ trŭn pơ lŏn, tơ arăng rŭ đĭ ñu ƀuh ñu djai laih. 
But Paul descending fell upon him, and enfolding [him] [in his arms], said, Be not troubled, for his life is in him. @ Samơ̆ Pôl trŭn, ñu tơkui krôp mă ñu hăng laĭ: “Anăm rŭng răng ôh, ñu ăt dŏ hơdip đôč!” 
And having gone up, and having broken the bread, and eaten, and having long spoken until daybreak, so he went away. @ Giơ̆ng anŭn Pôl đĭ glaĭ pơ adŭ tal glong dơ̆ng, ñu wơ̆k ƀañ tơpŭng hăng ƀơ̆ng. Ñu pơhiăp ră ruai hăng gơñu dơ̆ng sui tơl truh mơguah, laih anŭn ñu nao yơh. 
And they brought [away] the boy alive, and were no little comforted. @ Arăng ba pô tơdăm anŭn glaĭ pơ sang ñu ăt dŏ hơdip, hnŭn yơh ƀing gơñu hmâo tơlơi pơalum lu biă mă.
And we, having gone before on board ship, sailed off to Assos, going to take in Paul there; for so he had directed, he himself being about to go on foot. @ Gơmơi đĭ kompăn nao hlâo pơ plei Asôs. Pơ anŭn gơmơi či bưp Pôl; yua kơ Pôl kiăng nao jơlan lŏn, hnŭn yơh ñu hmâo pơkra laih tui anŭn. 
And when he met with us at Assos, having taken him on board, we came to Mitylene; @ Tơ ñu bưp laih ƀing gơmơi ƀơi plei Asôs, gơmơi čơkă ñu đĭ kompăn nao pơ plei Mitilen. 
and having sailed thence, on the morrow arrived opposite Chios, and the next day put in at Samos; and having stayed at Trogyllium, the next day we came to Miletus: @ Mơ̆ng anŭn gơmơi đĭ kompăn laih anŭn hrơi pơgi gơmơi truh pơ gah anăp plao ia Čiôs. Hrơi tơdơi gơmơi weh nao pơ plei Samôs, laih anŭn hrơi tơdơi tŏ tui anŭn gơmơi truh pơ plei Milê. 
for Paul thought it desirable to sail by Ephesus, so that he might not be made to spend time in Asia; for he hastened, if it was possible for him, to be the day of Pentecost at Jerusalem. @ Yua kơ Pôl khư̆p ư kơnơ̆ng găn lui plei Êphêsô, ƀu jưh pơ anŭn ôh hwĭ kơ rơngiă hĭ hrơi mông amăng kwar Asi. Yua kơ ñu hăt kiăng nao, tơdah dưi ñu kiăng truh pơ plei Yêrusalem amăng hrơi phĕt Pantơkôt.
But from Miletus having sent to Ephesus, he called over [to him] the elders of the assembly. @ Mơ̆ng plei Milê Pôl pơkiaŏ nao mơnuih pơ plei Êphêsô iâu ƀing kŏng tha amăng Phung Sang Ơi Adai nao pơ ñu. 
And when they were come to him, he said to them, *Ye* know how I was with you all the time from the first day that I arrived in Asia, @ Tơ gơñu truh laih, ñu pơhiăp hăng ƀing gơ̆: “Ƀing gih pô leng kơ thâo laih, hyư̆m kâo hmâo dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă hrŏm hăng ƀing gih nanao rĭm hrơi čơdơ̆ng mơ̆ng hrơi kâo truh pơ kwar Asi. 
serving the Lord with all lowliness, and tears, and temptations, which happened to me through the plots of the Jews; @ Kâo mă bruă Khua Yang hăng abih pran jua luă gŭ, hăng lu ia mơta, hăng tŭ lu tơlơi lông lăng truh kơ kâo yua mơ̆ng ƀing Yuđa dưm tơlơi mơneč ngă pơrăm kâo. 
how I held back nothing of what is profitable, so as not to announce [it] to you, and to teach you publicly and in every house, @ Ƀing gih thâo laih kâo ƀu hmâo pơdŏp ôh tơlơi tŭ yua kơ ƀing gih, ră ruai hăng pơtô kơ ƀing gih ƀơi anăp lu mơnuih ƀôdah amăng rĭm boh sang. 
testifying to both Jews and Greeks repentance towards God, and faith towards our Lord Jesus Christ. @ Kâo hmâo pơtô laĭ kơ ƀing Yuđa wơ̆t ƀing Grek kơ tơlơi kơhmal tơlơi soh hăng Ơi Adai, laih anŭn tơlơi đaŏ ƀơi Yêsu Krist Khua Yang ƀing ta. 
And now, behold, bound in my spirit *I* go to Jerusalem, not knowing what things shall happen to me in it; @ Lăng bĕ, ră anai Yang Bơngăt Hiam hmâo pơtrŭt kâo nao pơ plei Yêrusalem, ƀu thâo ôh hơgĕt tơlơi či truh kơ kâo pơ anŭn; 
only that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city, saying that bonds and tribulations await me. @ kơnơ̆ng kâo thâo Yang Bơngăt Hiam hmâo pơthâo hlâo brơi kâo amăng rĭm boh plei, hrĕ čuăk hăng tơlơi tơnap tap dŏ tơguan kâo. 
But I make no account of [my] life [as] dear to myself, so that I finish my course, and the ministry which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the glad tidings of the grace of God. @ Samơ̆ kâo ƀu yap tơlơi hơdip kâo jing yom kơ kâo pô ôh, tŭ kơ ngă pơgiơ̆ng hĭ abih bruă kâo hmâo mă tŭ laih mơ̆ng Khua Yang Yêsu, kiăng kâo pơhaih Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam kơ tơlơi pap Ơi Adai.
And now, behold, I know that ye all, among whom I have gone about preaching the kingdom [of God], shall see my face no more. @ Ră anai kâo thâo abih bang amăng ƀing gih, jing ƀing kâo hmâo pơtô laih kơ dêh čar pơtao Ơi Adai, ƀu hmâo sa čô hlơi či ƀuh ƀô̆ mơta kâo dơ̆ng ôh. 
Wherefore I witness to you this day, that I am clean from the blood of all, @ Yua kơ anŭn yơh, hrơi anai kâo pơthâo pơklă ƀơi anăp ƀing gih, kâo ƀu soh hăng drah kơ abih bang ƀing gih ôh. 
for I have not shrunk from announcing to you all the counsel of God. @ Yua kơ kâo ƀu hơngah ôh pơhaih kơ ƀing gih abih bang tơlơi Ơi Adai kơñăm. 
Take heed therefore to yourselves, and to all the flock, wherein the Holy Spirit has set you as overseers, to shepherd the assembly of God, which he has purchased with the blood of his own. @ Tui anŭn răng bĕ kơ ƀing gih pô laih anŭn kơ abih bang khul triu Yang Bơngăt Hiam hmâo pioh ƀing gih jing ƀing kiaŏ wai, kiăng čem rong Phung Sang Ơi Adai lơ̆m kơ Ơi Adai, ƀing Ñu song mă laih hăng drah Ană Ñu pô 
[For] *I* know [this,] that there will come in amongst you after my departure grievous wolves, not sparing the flock; @ Kâo thâo tơdơi kơ kâo đuaĭ, či hmâo lu asâo tan hơtai či mŭt amăng ƀing gih, gơñu ƀu hơ-ưi khul triu ôh. 
and from among your own selves shall rise up men speaking perverted things to draw away the disciples after them. @ Mơ̆ng tơ̆ng krah ƀing gih pô či hmâo mơnuih tơgŭ đĭ pơtô khul tơlơi ƀlor, kiăng dui ba ƀing ding kơna đuaĭ tui gơñu. 
Wherefore watch, remembering that for three years, night and day, I ceased not admonishing each one [of you] with tears. @ Tui anŭn, dŏ răng bĕ, hơdơr glaĭ bĕ amăng klâo thŭn kâo ƀu pơdơi ôh luh lu ia mơta, hrơi hăng mlam kâo pơtô kơ rĭm čô ƀing gih.
And now I commit you to God, and to the word of his grace, which is able to build [you] up and give [to you] an inheritance among all the sanctified. @ Ră anai kâo jao ƀing gih kơ Ơi Adai laih anŭn kơ boh pơhiăp tơlơi pap Ñu, jing boh pơhiăp dưi pơdơ̆ng hăng pha brơi kong ngăn kơ ƀing gih hrŏm hơbĭt hăng abih bang ƀing mơnuih rơgoh hiam. 
I have coveted [the] silver or gold or clothing of no one. @ Kâo ƀu hưp kơ prăk, mah, ƀôdah sum ao arăng ôh. 
Yourselves know that these hands have ministered to my wants, and to those who were with me. @ Ƀing gih pô thâo laih hăng dua ƀĕ tơngan anai yơh mă bruă hmâo mơnơ̆ng yua kơ kâo pô, laih anŭn kơ ƀing hrŏm hơbĭt hăng kâo. 
I have shewed you all things, that thus labouring [we] ought to come in aid of the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that he himself said, It is more blessed to give than to receive. @ Kâo hmâo pơtô kơčrâo brơi laih kơ ƀing gih amăng abih bang bruă, ƀing ta khŏm triăng mă bruă tui anŭn kiăng kơ gŭm djru ƀing ƀu anăm mă bruă, hăng hơdơr glaĭ boh pơhiăp Khua Yang Yêsu pô hmâo pơhiăp: ‘Pha brơi jing hmâo tơlơi mơyun hloh kơ mă tŭ.’”
And having said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all. @ Giơ̆ng Pôl pơhiăp khul tơlơi anŭn, ñu tŏ tơŭt iâu laĭ hrŏm hơbĭt hăng abih bang ƀing gơ̆. 
And they all wept sore; and falling upon the neck of Paul they ardently kissed him, @ Abih bang gơñu leng kơ hia soh sel, hăng kuar mă tơkuai Pôl laih anŭn čŭm. 
specially pained by the word which he had said, that they would no more see his face. And they went down with him to the ship. @ Gơñu ruă rơngot hloh dơ̆ng, yua kơ tơlơi Pôl laĭ ƀing gơñu ƀu či ƀuh ƀô̆ mơta ñu dơ̆ng ôh. Giơ̆ng anŭn gơñu drông ba Pôl truh pơ kompăn.
And when, having got away from them, we at last sailed away, we came by a direct course to Cos, and on the morrow to Rhodes, and thence to Patara. @ Ƀing gơmơi čơlah mơ̆ng gơñu, gơmơi đĭ kompăn hăng nao tơpă pơ plei Kôs. Hrơi tơdơi gơmơi truh pơ plei Rôt, hăng mơ̆ng anŭn gơmơi nao truh pơ plei Patara. 
And having found a ship passing over into Phoenicia, we went on board and sailed; @ Gơmơi ƀuh pơ anŭn sa boh kompăn nao pơ čar Phênisi, tui anŭn gơmơi đĭ kompăn hăng nao yơh. 
and having sighted Cyprus, and left it on the left hand, we sailed to Syria, and made the land at Tyre, for there the ship was to discharge her cargo. @ Tơ gơmơi ƀuh plao ia Čiprơ, gơmơi găn nao gah dơnŭng kơ plao anai hlŏng truh pơ čar Siri, laih anŭn gơmơi trŭn ƀơi hang plei Tir; yua kơ pơ anŭn arăng khŏm pơtrŭn hĭ gơnam mơ̆ng kompăn. 
And having found out the disciples, we remained there seven days; who said to Paul by the Spirit not to go up to Jerusalem. @ Giơ̆ng gơmơi hơduah ƀuh laih ƀing ding kơna, gơmơi dŏ pơ anŭn tơjuh hrơi. Ƀing đaŏ hmâo Yang Bơngăt Hiam pơtrŭt, gơñu laĭ kơ Pôl anăm đĭ nao pơ Yêrusalem ôh. 
But when we had completed the days, we set out and took our journey, all of them accompanying us, with wives and children, till [we were] out of the city. And kneeling down upon the shore we prayed. @ Samơ̆ tơ hrơi gơmơi dŏ jưh pơ anŭn abih laih, gơmơi nao dơ̆ng. Abih ƀing đaŏ hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ană bơnai gơñu drông ba gơmơi truh pơ gah rơngiao plei, abih bang gơmơi tŏ tơŭt ƀơi hang ia rơsĭ hăng iâu laĭ. 
And having embraced one another, we went on board ship, and they returned home. @ Giơ̆ng pơhiăp tơlơi pơčơlah, gơmơi đĭ kompăn laih anŭn gơñu wơ̆t glaĭ hĭ pơ sang.
And we, having completed the voyage, arrived from Tyre at Ptolemais, and having saluted the brethren, we remained one day with them. @ Mơ̆ng plei Tir gơmơi đĭ kompăn nao truh pơ plei Pôtôlêmê. Gơmơi čuă ngui ƀing adơi ayŏng đaŏ hăng dŏ hrŏm hơbĭt hăng gơñu sa hrơi. 
And leaving on the morrow, we came to Caesarea; and entering into the house of Philip the evangelist, who was of the seven, we abode with him. @ Hrơi tơdơi gơmơi nao pơ plei Sêsarê, gơmơi mŭt dŏ amăng sang Philip pô pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam. Ñu jing sa čô amăng tơjuh čô ƀing tha sang yang pơ plei Yêrusalem. 
Now this man had four virgin daughters who prophesied. @ Ñu hmâo pă čô ană dra aka dŏ rơkơi, gơñu hmâo tơlơi pha brơi thâo pơhiăp laĭ lui hlâo. 
And as we stayed there many days, a certain man, by name Agabus, a prophet, came down from Judaea, @ Tơdang ƀing gơmơi dŏ pơ anŭn ƀiă hrơi, hmâo sa čô pô laĭ lui hlâo anăn ñu Agabus trŭn rai mơ̆ng Yuđa. 
and coming to us and taking the girdle of Paul, and having bound his own hands and feet, said, Thus saith the Holy Spirit, The man whose this girdle is shall the Jews thus bind in Jerusalem, and deliver him up into the hands of [the] Gentiles. @ Ñu truh pơ ƀing gơmơi, ñu mă hơdrăng kơiăng Pôl, akă tơkai tơngan pô ñu hăng laĭ: “Anai jing boh pơhiăp Yang Bơngăt Hiam laĭ: ‘Kar hăng anai yơh ƀing Yuđa pơ Yêrusalem či čăp hĭ pô hơdrăng kơiăng anai laih anŭn gơñu či jao hĭ gơ̆ amăng tơngan ƀing djuai tuai.’” 
And when we heard these things, both we and those of the place besought [him] not to go up to Jerusalem. @ Tơ gơmơi hmư̆ hơdôm tơlơi anŭn, gơmơi hăng ƀing đaŏ pơ anŭn kơwưh kơ Pôl anăm đĭ nao pơ plei Yêrusalem ôh. 
But Paul answered, What do ye, weeping and breaking my heart? for *I* am ready not only to be bound, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus. @ Samơ̆ Pôl laĭ glaĭ: “Ƀing gih ngă hơgĕt, ƀing gih hia tui anŭn ngă pơruă pran jua kâo? Yua kơ kâo prăp pre ƀu djơ̆ kơnơ̆ng tŭ tơlơi arăng čăp đôč ôh, samơ̆ wơ̆t kơ tŭ tơlơi djai pơ Yêrusalem yua kơ anăn Khua Yang Yêsu mơ̆n.” 
And when he would not be persuaded, we were silent, saying, The will of the Lord be done. @ Yua kơ ñu ƀu tŭ ôh kơ tơlơi ƀing gơmơi pơđur, gơmơi ƀu thâo pơgŏ ñu dơ̆ng ôh, laih anŭn laĭ: “Brơi tơlơi Khua Yang kiăng dưi jing.”
And after these days, having got our effects ready, we went up to Jerusalem. @ Tơdơi kơ khul hrơi anŭn, ƀing gơmơi prăp rơmet gơnam hăng đĭ nao pơ Yêrusalem. 
And [some] of the disciples from Caesarea went with us, bringing [with them] a certain Mnason, a Cyprian, an old disciple, with whom we were to lodge. @ Hmâo đơđa ƀing ding kơna mơ̆ng plei Sêsarê nao hrŏm hăng gơmơi. Gơñu ba gơmơi pơ sang Manasôn mơnuih plao ia Čiprơ, sa čô ƀing ding kơna đaŏ mơ̆ng blŭng hlâo, laih anŭn gơmơi dŏ amăng sang gơ̆.
And when we arrived at Jerusalem the brethren gladly received us. @ Tơ gơmơi truh pơ Yêrusalem, ƀing adơi ayŏng nao čơkă jum gơmơi hăng tơlơi mơak mơai. 
And on the morrow Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders came there. @ Hrơi tơdơi, Pôl hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ƀing gơmơi nao čuă Yakơ; abih bang ƀing kŏng tha hmâo ƀô̆ mơta pơ anŭn. 
And having saluted them, he related one by one the things which God had wrought among the nations by his ministry. @ Giơ̆ng kơkuh tơña hăng ƀing gơñu, Pôl ră ruai abih tơlơi Ơi Adai hmâo ngă laih tơ̆ng krah ƀing Djuai Tuai găn mơ̆ng bruă mơnuă ñu. 
And they having heard [it] glorified God, and said to him, Thou seest, brother, how many myriads there are of the Jews who have believed, and all are zealous of the law. @ Tơ gơñu hmư̆ giơ̆ng tơlơi anŭn, abih gơñu pơpŭ bơni hơơč kơ Ơi Adai. Hnŭn yơh gơñu laĭ hăng Pôl: “Ơ Ayŏng, ih ƀuh yơh, hmâo lu rơbâo ƀing Yuđa đaŏ laih; abih bang gơñu hur har kơ Tơlơi Juăt. 
And they have been informed concerning thee, that thou teachest all the Jews among the nations apostasy from Moses, saying that they should not circumcise their children, nor walk in the customs. @ Gơñu hmâo hmư̆ hing arăng laĭ kơ ih pơtô abih bang ƀing Yuđa dŏ amăng ƀing čar Djuai Tuai brơi lui hĭ tơlơi juăt Môis, pơtă kơ ƀing gơñu anăm khăt klĭ ƀing ană gơñu ôh, kŏn djă pioh tơlơi phiăn lơi. 
What is it then? a multitude must necessarily come together, for they will hear that thou art come. @ Tui anŭn, hyư̆m či ngă? Sĭt yơh ƀing gơñu hmư̆ kơ ih hmâo truh laih pơ anai. 
This do therefore that we say to thee: We have four men who have a vow on them; @ Tui anŭn, brơi ih ngă bĕ tui hăng tơlơi gơmơi pơtă kơ ih. Gơmơi hmâo pă čô hlăk đom hăng tơlơi ƀuăn. 
take these and be purified with them, and pay their expenses, that they may have their heads shaved; and all will know that [of those things] of which they have been informed about thee nothing is [true]; but that thou thyself also walkest orderly, keeping the law. @ Ba bĕ ƀing anŭn hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ih, ngă phĕt pơrơgoh ih pô hrŏm hăng ƀing gơñu tui hăng tơlơi juăt laih anŭn kla prăk brơi kơ ƀing gơñu kuah ƀuk. Tui anŭn abih bang či thâo tơlơi arăng ruai djơ̆ kơ ih ƀu jing sĭt ôh, samơ̆ ih pô ăt dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă djơ̆ hăng tơlơi juăt mơ̆n. 
But concerning [those of] the nations who have believed, we have written, deciding that they should [observe no such thing, only to] keep themselves both from things offered to idols, and from blood, and from things strangled, and from fornication. @ Bơ kơ ƀing djuai tuai hmâo đaŏ laih, gơmơi hmâo mơit laih hră čih tơlơi gơmơi khư̆p ư, brơi kơ̆m ƀơ̆ng mơnơ̆ng ngă yang, kơ̆m ƀơ̆ng drah ƀôdah hlô mơnơ̆ng djai hơngơ̆t, hăng kơ̆m klĕ pyu.” 
Then Paul, taking the men, on the next day, having been purified, entered with them into the temple, signifying the time the days of the purification would be fulfilled, until the offering was offered for every one of them. @ Tui anŭn Pôl jak ba ƀing mơnuih anŭn, laih anŭn hrơi tơdơi hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ƀing anŭn ngă phĕt pơrơgoh, laih anŭn ñu mŭt amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, brơi gơñu thâo hơbin hrơi phĕt pơrơgoh či giơ̆ng tum laih anŭn mơnơ̆ng ngă yang rĭm čô amăng ƀing gơñu khŏm pơyơr.
And when the seven days were nearly completed, the Jews from Asia, having seen him in the temple, set all the crowd in a tumult, and laid hands upon him, @ Tơ tơjuh hrơi anŭn giăm abih laih, ƀing Yuđa mơ̆ng kwar Asi ƀuh Pôl amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, gơñu pơsur ƀing ană plei pla ngă tơlơi pơrŭng laih anŭn mă Pôl. 
crying, Israelites, help! this is the man who teaches all everywhere against the people, and the law, and this place, and has brought Greeks too into the temple, and profaned this holy place. @ Gơñu ur kraih: “Ơ ană plei pla Israel hơi, rai djru ƀing gơmơi đa! Pô anai yơh hyu pơtô tar ƀar anih, pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng ană plei pla Israel, hăng tơlơi juăt Môis laih anŭn hăng anih anai mơ̆n. Hloh kơ anŭn dơ̆ng, ñu ăt hmâo ba laih mơ̆n ƀing Grek mŭt amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, ngă pơgrĭ hĭ anih rơgoh hiam anai.” 
For they had before seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, whom they supposed that Paul had brought into the temple. @ Kơlih yua hlâo kơ anŭn gơñu hmâo ƀuh Trôphim, mơnuih Êphêsô, dŏ hrŏm hơbĭt hăng Pôl amăng plei anŭn, hnŭn yơh gơñu pơmĭn dah Pôl hmâo jak ba pô anŭn mŭt amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ. 
And the whole city was moved, and there was a concourse of the people; and having laid hold on Paul they drew him out of the temple, and immediately the doors were shut. @ Abih bang ană plei hmâo tơlơi rŭng răng, laih anŭn abih bang ană plei hrŏm hơbĭt đuaĭ nao. Gơñu mă Pôl hăng dui hrơ̆t gơ̆ tơbiă mơ̆ng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, laih anŭn arăng krư̆ hĭ bah amăng mơtam. 
And as they were seeking to kill him, a representation came to the chiliarch of the band that the whole of Jerusalem was in a tumult; @ Tơdang gơñu hơduah jơlan kiăng pơdjai hĭ Pôl, tơlơi arăng laĭ pơthâo truh pơ khua tơhan Rôm thâo kơ abih amăng plei Yêrusalem hmâo tơlơi rŭng răng. 
who, taking with him immediately soldiers and centurions, ran down upon them. But they, seeing the chiliarch and the soldiers, ceased beating Paul. @ Tañ mơtam, ñu ba tơhan wơ̆t ƀing khua tơhan kơ sa rơtuh čô, hăng nao pơ ƀing mơnuih lu. Tơ ƀing mơnuih lu anŭn ƀuh khua tơhan hăng ƀing tơhan, gơñu ƀu taih Pôl dơ̆ng tah. 
Then the chiliarch came up and laid hold upon him, and commanded [him] to be bound with two chains, and inquired who he might be, and what he had done. @ Khua tơhan nao giăm, mă Pôl hăng pơtă arăng čăp hĭ gơ̆ hăng dua ară hrĕ jal. Giơ̆ng anŭn ñu tơña hlơi ih jing, laih anŭn hơgĕt ih hmâo ngă laih? 
And different persons cried some different thing in the crowd. But he, not being able to know the certainty on account of the uproar, commanded him to be brought into the fortress. @ Amăng ƀing mơnuih lu, đơđa mơnuih ur tui anai, đơđa ur tui anŭn; laih anŭn yua kơ tơlơi pơrơông pơrơang, khua tơhan ƀu thâo sĭt ôh hyưm tơlơi anŭn jing, hnŭn yơh ñu pơđar arăng ba Pôl nao pơ kơđông. 
But when he got upon the stairs it was so that he was borne by the soldiers on account of the violence of the crowd. @ Tơ Pôl truh ƀơi rơñan, ƀing tơhan čơkung ñu đĭ, yua kơ ƀing lu anŭn sat ƀai biă mă. 
For the multitude of the people followed, crying, Away with him. @ Ƀing mơnuih lu đuaĭ tui klon ur laĭ: “Pơdjai hĭ ñu!”
But as he was about to be led into the fortress, Paul says to the chiliarch, Is it allowed me to say something to thee? And he said, Dost thou know Greek? @ Tơ arăng giăm ba ñu mŭt amăng kơđông, Pôl laĭ hăng khua tơhan: “Dưi mơ̆ kâo pơhiăp ƀiă hăng ih?” Khua tơhan laĭ: “Ih thâo pơhiăp tơlơi Grek hă? 
Thou art not then that Egyptian who before these days raised a sedition and led out into the wilderness the four thousand men of the assassins? @ Tui anŭn ih ƀu djơ̆ sa čô ƀing Êjip ôh hă, hlâo anŭn sui ƀiă jing pô pơsur tơlơi krŭ pơkơdơ̆ng hăng djă ba amăng tơdrŏn har pă rơbâo čô ƀing pơrai klĕ?” 
But Paul said, *I* am a Jew of Tarsus, citizen of no insignificant city of Cilicia, and I beseech of thee, allow me to speak to the people. @ Pôl laĭ glaĭ: “Kâo jing sa čô Yuđa mơ̆ng plei Tars čar Silisi sa čô ană plei amăng sa boh plei prŏng yom. Rơkâo kơ ih brơi kâo pơhiăp hăng ană plei.” 
And when he had allowed him, Paul, standing on the stairs, beckoned with his hand to the people; and a great silence having been made, he addressed them in the Hebrew tongue, saying, @ Khua tơhan brơi Pôl pơhiăp, Pôl dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơi rơñan, yơr tơngan kơ ƀing ană plei; tơ abih mơnuih dŏ rơiăt laih, ñu pơhiăp hăng tơlơi Hêbrơ, tui anai:
Brethren and fathers, hear my defence which I now make to you. @ “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng hăng ƀing ama, dŏ hmư̆ bĕ tơlơi kâo pơhiăp pơgang kâo pô ƀơi anăp ƀing gih.” 
And hearing that he addressed them in the Hebrew tongue, they kept the more quiet; and he says, @ Tơ gơñu hmư̆ Pôl pơhiăp hăng tơlơi Hêbrơ, gơñu dŏ rơiăt hloh dơ̆ng. Pôl laĭ:
*I* am a Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this city, at the feet of Gamaliel, educated according to [the] exactness of the law of [our] fathers, being zealous for God, as *ye* are all this day; @  “Kâo jing sa čô Yuđa, arăng tơkeng kâo pơ plei Tars amăng čar Silisi, samơ̆ kâo rai kơ prŏng amăng plei anai jing sa čô hrăm mơ̆ng Gamaliel djơ̆ tui hăng Tơlơi Juăt ơi adon ƀing ta, hur har hăng Ơi Adai, ăt kar hăng abih bang ƀing gih hrơi anai.
