who have persecuted this way unto death, binding and delivering up to prisons both men and women; @ Kâo ngă sat tơl pơdjai ƀing đuaĭ tui jơlan anai, mă čaŏ hăng krư̆ amăng sang mơnă wơ̆t đah rơkơi laih anŭn đah kơmơi. 
as also the high priest bears me witness, and all the elderhood: from whom also, having received letters to the brethren, I went to Damascus to bring those also who were there, bound, to Jerusalem, to be punished. @ Kơ tơlơi anŭn khua ngă yang prŏng hloh hăng wơ̆t ƀing kŏng tha phat kơđi dui ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơsĭt brơi kơ kâo. Kâo hmâo mă tŭ hră mơ̆ng ƀing anŭn mơit kơ ƀing adơi ayŏng pơ plei Damas laih anŭn kâo hmâo nao pơ plei anŭn kiăng mă čăp ƀing đaŏ pơ anŭn hăng dui ba ƀing gơñu pơ plei Yêrusalem kiăng pơkơhmal ƀing gơñu.”
And it came to pass, as I was journeying and drawing near to Damascus, that, about mid-day, there suddenly shone out of heaven a great light round about me. @ “Tơdang kâo rơbat giăm truh pơ plei Damas, amăng kơplah wah yang hrơi dơ̆ng, blĭp hmâo tơlơi bơngač kơmlă mơ̆ng adai pơčrang jum dar kâo. 
And I fell to the ground, and heard a voice saying to me, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? @ Kâo rơbuh lĕ pơ lŏn hăng hmư̆ asăp pơhiăp hăng kâo: ‘Ơ Sôl, Ơ Sôl, hyư̆m ih ngă sat kơ Kâo?’ 
And *I* answered, Who art thou, Lord? And he said to me, *I* am Jesus the Nazaraean, whom *thou* persecutest. @ Kâo laĭ glaĭ: ‘Ơ Khua, hlơi Ih?’ Ñu laĭ kơ kâo: ‘Kâo jing Yêsu plei Nasaret, Pô ih hlăk dŏ ngă sat.’ 
But they that were with me beheld the light, [and were filled with fear], but heard not the voice of him that was speaking to me. @ Ƀing nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng kâo ƀuh tơlơi bơngač anŭn samơ̆ ƀu hmư̆ ôh asăp pô dŏ pơhiăp hăng kâo. 
And I said, What shall I do, Lord? And the Lord said to me, Rise up, and go to Damascus, and there it shall be told thee of all things which it is appointed thee to do. @ Kâo tơña: ‘Ơ Khua Yang, Hơgĕt kâo či ngă?’ Laih anŭn Khua Yang laĭ kơ kâo: ‘Tơgŭ bĕ nao pơ plei Damas, laih anŭn pơ anŭn či hmâo tơlơi laĭ brơi abih tơlơi Kâo hmâo ruah brơi laih kơ ih khŏm ngă.’ 
And as I could not see, through the glory of that light, being led by the hand of those who were with me, I came to Damascus. @ Yua kơ tơlơi bơngač kơmlă kơtang anŭn ngă kơ mơta kâo ƀu thâo ƀuh tah, ƀing nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng kâo djă tơngan hăng dui ba kâo truh pơ plei Damas.
And a certain Ananias, a pious man according to the law, borne witness to by all the Jews who dwelt [there], @ Hmâo sa čô anăn ñu Ananias, jing mơnuih tơpă hiam hur har ngă tui hăng tơlơi juăt, hmâo tơlơi ngă gơ̆ng jơlan hiam mơ̆ng abih bang ƀing Yuđa dŏ pơ plei Damas. 
coming to me and standing by me, said to me, Brother Saul, receive thy sight. And *I*, in the same hour, received my sight and saw him. @ Ñu rai dŏ jĕ kâo hăng laĭ ‘Ơ ayŏng Sôl, mơta ih rơđah glaĭ bĕ!’ Hlăk anŭn mơtam kâo ƀuh rơđah glaĭ dơ̆ng laih anŭn lăng ƀuh Ananias. 
And he said, The God of our fathers has chosen thee beforehand to know his will, and to see the just one, and to hear a voice out of his mouth; @ Ñu laĭ: ‘Ơi Adai kơ ơi adon ƀing ta hmâo ruah ih kiăng ih thâo tơlơi Ñu kiăng, ƀuh Pô Tơpă, hăng brơi ih hmư̆ boh pơhiăp mơ̆ng amăng bah Ñu. 
for thou shalt be a witness for him to all men of what thou hast seen and heard. @ Yua kơ ih či jing pô ngă gơ̆ng jơlan brơi kơ Ñu ƀơi anăp abih bang mơnuih kơ khul tơlơi ih hmâo ƀuh hăng hmư̆ laih. 
And now why lingerest thou? Arise and get baptised, and have thy sins washed away, calling on his name. @ Ră anai, hơgĕt ih dŏ tơguan dơ̆ng? Tơgŭ bĕ laih anŭn tŭ ƀatem, pơrơgoh tơlơi soh ih, laih anŭn iâu laĭ kơ anăn Khua Yang.’”
And it came to pass when I had returned to Jerusalem, and as I was praying in the temple, that I became in ecstasy, @ “Kâo wơ̆t glaĭ pơ Yêrusalem laih anŭn hlăk kâo dŏ iâu laĭ amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, kâo hmâo tơlơi pơƀuh, 
and saw him saying to me, Make haste and go quickly out of Jerusalem, for they will not receive thy testimony concerning me. @ Kâo ƀuh Khua Yang pơhiăp hăng kâo: ‘Tơbiă tañ bĕ mơ̆ng plei Yêrusalem, yua kơ gơñu ƀu či tŭ ôh tơlơi ih ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ kâo.’ 
And *I* said, Lord, they themselves know that *I* was imprisoning and beating in every synagogue those that believe on thee; @ Kâo laĭ: ‘Ơ Khua Yang, gơñu pô yơh hmâo thâo laih kơ tơlơi kâo mă krư̆ hăng taih amăng ƀing đaŏ kơ Ih amăng rĭm boh sang bơjơnum. 
and when the blood of thy witness Stephen was shed, I also myself was standing by and consenting, and kept the clothes of them who killed him. @ Laih anŭn dơ̆ng tơ Êtiên jing pô ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ Ih hmâo tuh drah, kâo kar kaĭ mơ̆n dŏ jĕ pơ anŭn tŭ ư hrŏm hơbĭt hăng tơlơi gơñu ngă, laih anŭn dŏ wai sum ao ƀing pơdjai ñu.’ 
And he said to me, Go, for *I* will send thee to the nations afar off. @ Khua Yang laĭ kơ kâo: ‘Nao bĕ, yua kơ Kâo či pơkiaŏ ih nao pơ ƀing djuai tuai pơ ataih.’”
And they heard him until this word, and lifted up their voice, saying, Away with such a one as that from the earth, for it was not fit he should live. @ Gơñu dŏ hmư̆ Pôl truh dơ̆ boh pơhiăp anŭn, hlăk anŭn gơñu čơdơ̆ng ur kraih: “Pơrơngiă hĭ bĕ mơnuih kar hăng anŭn mơ̆ng lŏn tơnah! Ñu ƀu lăp dŏ hơdip dơ̆ng ôh!” 
And as they were crying, and throwing away their clothes, and casting dust into the air, @ Tơdang gơñu ur hrek, glŏm sum ao laih anŭn kuaĭ ƀruih lŏn sai đĭ hăng ngŏ. 
the chiliarch commanded him to be brought into the fortress, saying that he should be examined by scourging, that he might ascertain for what cause they cried thus against him. @ Khua tơhan pơđar arăng ba Pôl mŭt amăng kơđông, yua gai hnuăt hrĕ taih kiăng thâo yua kơ hơgĕt ƀing mơnuih lu ur pơkơdơ̆ng hăng ñu tui anŭn. 
But as they stretched him forward with the thongs, Paul said to the centurion who stood [by], Is it lawful for you to scourge a man [who is] a Roman and uncondemned? @ Samơ̆ tơ arăng akă dăng ñu kiăng kơ taih ñu, Pôl laĭ hăng sa čô khua kơ sa rơtuh čô dŏ jĕ ƀơi anŭn: “Phiăn mơ̆ kơ ƀing gih taih sa čô mơnuih Rôm tơdang akă phat kơđi ñu ôh?”
And the centurion, having heard it, went and reported it to the chiliarch, saying, What art thou going to do? for this man is a Roman. @ Tơ khua tơhan hmư̆ tơlơi Pôl pơhiăp tui anŭn, ñu nao tơña khua prŏng wai tơhan hăng laĭ: “Hyư̆m ih či ngă tơlơi anai? Yua kơ pô anai jing mơnuih Rôm.”
And the chiliarch coming up said to him, Tell me, Art *thou* a Roman? And he said, Yes. @ Tui anŭn khua prŏng nao pơ Pôl hăng laĭ: “Laĭ brơi kâo bĕ, ih jing mơnuih Rôm hă?”
Pôl laĭ glaĭ: “Ơ, djơ̆ yơh.”
And the chiliarch answered, *I*, for a great sum, bought this citizenship. And Paul said, But *I* was also [free] born. @ Khua prŏng laĭ: “Kâo blơi tơlơi dưi jing ană plei Rôm hăng nua prăk yom biă mă.”
Pôl laĭ: “Samơ̆ kâo jing sa čô mơnuih Rôm čơdơ̆ng mơ̆ng amĭ tơkeng.”
Immediately therefore those who were going to examine him left him, and the chiliarch also was afraid when he ascertained that he was a Roman, and because he had bound him. @ Tui anŭn ƀing kiăng kơsem tơña Pôl leng kơ đuaĭ mơ̆ng ñu mơtam; laih anŭn khua prŏng hwĭ biă mă, tơ ñu thâo pô ñu hmâo čăp laih, anŭn jing sa čô mơnuih Rôm.
And on the morrow, desirous to know the certainty [of the matter] why he was accused of the Jews, he loosed him, and commanded the chief priests and all the council to meet, and having brought Paul down set him before them. @ Tơ truh hrơi pơgi, khua prŏng kiăng thâo sĭt yua kơ tơlơi hơgĕt ƀing Yuđa phong kơ Pôl, hnŭn yơh ñu kleh hĭ gơ̆, laih anŭn pơtă kơ ƀing khua ngă yang prŏng hăng abih bang ƀing khua phat kơđi bơjơnum glaĭ, laih anŭn ba Pôl dŏ ƀơi anăp ƀing anŭn.
And Paul, fixing his eyes on the council, said, Brethren, I have walked in all good conscience with God unto this day. @ Pôl lăng tơpă nao pơ ƀing bơjơnum, hăng laĭ: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, kâo dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă ƀơi anăp Ơi Adai hăng abih pran jua tơpă hiam klă bơngač truh pơ hrơi anai.” 
But the high priest Ananias ordered those standing by him to smite his mouth. @ Khua ngă yang prŏng hloh Ananias pơđar kơ ƀing dŏ jĕ Pôl pah hĭ amăng bah gơ̆. 
Then Paul said to him, God will smite thee, whited wall. And *thou*, dost thou sit judging me according to the law, and breaking the law commandest me to be smitten? @ Pôl laĭ kơ ñu: “Ơ pơnăng pik čur kŏ anŭn hơi, Ơi Adai či taih hĭ ih. Ih dŏ ber kiăng phat kơđi kâo tui hăng tơlơi juăt samơ̆ ih ngă gao tơlơi juăt, pơđar arăng taih kâo!”
And those that stood by said, Dost thou rail against the high priest of God? @ Ƀing dŏ dơ̆ng jĕ ñu laĭ: “Hyư̆m ih djik djak khua ngă yang prŏng hloh Ơi Adai?”
And Paul said, I was not conscious, brethren, that he was high priest; for it is written, Thou shalt not speak evilly of the ruler of thy people. @  Pôl laĭ: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, kâo ƀu thâo ôh kơ ñu jing khua ngă yang prŏng hloh; yua kơ hơdrôm Hră Ơi Adai Pơhiăp hmâo čih tui anai: ‘Anăm pơhiăp sat ôh kơ khua wai lăng ană plei ih.’”
But Paul, knowing that the one part [of them] were of the Sadducees and the other of the Pharisees, cried out in the council, Brethren, *I* am a Pharisee, son of Pharisees: *I* am judged concerning the hope and resurrection of [the] dead. @  Tơ Pôl thâo amăng ƀing gơñu hmâo đơđa jing ƀing Sadusi laih anŭn đơđa ƀing pơkŏn jing ƀing Pharisi, ñu ur kraih ƀơi anăp ƀing phat kơđi: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, kâo jing sa čô Pharisi, ană đah rơkơi sa čô Pharisi. Yua kơ tơlơi čang rơmang kơ tơlơi hơdip glaĭ mơ̆ng tơlơi djai, hnŭn yơh arăng phat kơđi kâo.”
And when he had spoken this, there was a tumult of the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the multitude was divided. @ Giơ̆ng ñu pơhiăp tơlơi anŭn, ƀing Pharisi pơrơjah hăng ƀing Sadusi, laih anŭn ƀing bơjơnum pơčơlah pơpha hĭ. 
For Sadducees say there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit; but Pharisees confess both of them. @ Yua kơ ƀing Sadusi laĭ ƀu hmâo tơlơi hơdip glaĭ ôh, kŏn hmâo ling jang ƀôdah bơngăt mơyang lơi. Samơ̆ ƀing Pharisi đaŏ kơ abih tơlơi anŭn. 
And there was a great clamour, and the scribes of the Pharisees' part rising up contended, saying, We find nothing evil in this man; and if a spirit has spoken to him, or an angel @ Tui anŭn hmâo asăp ur prŏng. Hmâo đơđa ƀing nai pơtô tơlơi juăt amăng ƀing Pharisi tơgŭ hăng pơgăl kơtang biă mă: “Gơmơi ƀu ƀuh sa mơta tơlơi soh hơgĕt ôh amăng mơnuih anai. Hyư̆m dưi thâo, năng ai bơngăt mơyang ƀôdah ling jang Ơi Adai hmâo pơhiăp laih hăng ñu tơlơi hơgĕt thâo?”
And a great tumult having arisen, the chiliarch, fearing lest Paul should have been torn in pieces by them, commanded the troop to come down and take him by force from the midst of them, and to bring [him] into the fortress. @ Tơlơi pơrơjah anŭn jai kơtang hloh dơ̆ng, khua gĭt gai tơhan hwĭ kơ arăng hek hĭ drơi jan Pôl, tui anŭn yơh ñu pơđar ƀing tơhan trŭn sua mă Pôl mơ̆ng ƀing gơñu ba mŭt amăng kơđông.
But the following night the Lord stood by him, and said, Be of good courage; for as thou hast testified the things concerning me at Jerusalem, so thou must bear witness at Rome also. @ Mlam tơdơi kơ anŭn, Khua Yang dŏ dơ̆ng jĕ Pôl hăng laĭ: “Anăm tơdu pran jua ôh, yua kơ kar hăng ih hmâo ngă gơ̆ng jơlan laih kơ Kâo pơ plei Yêrusalem, tui anŭn ih či ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ Kâo pơ plei Rôm kar kaĭ mơ̆n.”
And when it was day, the Jews, having banded together, put themselves under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink till they should kill Paul. @ Tơ truh mơguah ƀing Yuđa pơƀŭt hrŏm hơbĭt, dưm tơlơi mơneč hăng ƀuăn rơ̆ng hăng tơdruă gơñu ƀu ƀơ̆ng huă kŏn mơñum lơi tơl gơñu dưi pơdjai hĭ Pôl. 
And they were more than forty who had joined together in this oath; @ Ƀing hrŏm hơbĭt ngă tơlơi anŭn hmâo rơbeh kơ pă pluh čô. 
and they went to the chief priests and elders, and said, We have cursed ourselves with a curse to taste nothing until we kill Paul. @ Gơñu nao pơ ƀing khua ngă yang prŏng hăng ƀing kŏng tha, hăng laĭ: “Gơmơi hmâo ƀuăn rơ̆ng laih hăng tơdruă ƀu či ƀơ̆ng huă ôh tơl gơmơi dưi pơdjai hĭ Pôl. 
Now therefore do ye with the council make a representation to the chiliarch so that he may bring him down to you, as about to determine more precisely what concerns him, and we, before he draws near, are ready to kill him. @ Tui anŭn ră anai, rơkâo kơ ƀing gih hăng ƀing khua phat kơđi rơkâo kơ khua gĭt gai tơhan ba rai Pôl pơ anăp ƀing gih, ngă mă kar hăng ƀing gih kiăng kơsem phat brơi kơđi ñu klă ten hloh. Samơ̆ ƀing gơmơi dŏ krăp kiăng pơdjai hĭ ñu hlâo kơ ñu truh pơ anai.”
But Paul's sister's son, having heard of the lying in wait, came and entered into the fortress and reported [it] to Paul. @ Samơ̆ ană đah rơkơi amai Pôl thâo hĭ tơlơi dưm mơneč anŭn, tui anŭn ñu nao mŭt amăng kơđông, hăng laĭ brơi Pôl thâo. 
And Paul, having called one of the centurions, said, Take this youth to the chiliarch, for he has something to report to him. @ Pôl iâu sa čô khua tơhan hăng laĭ: “Ba nao bĕ tơdăm anai pơ khua gĭt gai tơhan, yua kơ gơ̆ hmâo tơlơi kiăng pơthâo kơ ñu.” 
He therefore, having taken him with [him], led him to the chiliarch, and says, The prisoner Paul called me to [him] and asked me to lead this youth to thee, who has something to say to thee. @ Tui anŭn khua tơhan ba tơdăm anŭn pơ khua gĭt gai tơhan hăng laĭ: “Pôl, pô jing mơnă iâu kâo hăng rơkâo kơ kâo ba tơdăm anai pơ ih, yua kơ ñu hmâo tơlơi kiăng pơhiăp hăng ih.”
And the chiliarch having taken him by the hand, and having gone apart in private, inquired, What is it that thou hast to report to me? @ Khua gĭt gai tơhan djă tơngan ñu, ba gơ̆ pơ anih hơjăn hăng tơña kơ ñu: “Hơgĕt tơlơi ih kiăng laĭ pơthâo hăng kâo?”
And he said, The Jews have agreed together to make a request to thee, that thou mayest bring Paul down to-morrow into the council, as about to inquire something more precise concerning him. @ Ñu laĭ: “Ƀing Yuđa sa pran jua kiăng rơkâo kơ ih ba Pôl nao pơ anăp ƀing khua phat kơđi hrơi pơgi, gơñu ngă kar hăng gơñu kiăng kơsem kơ tơlơi Pôl ten klă hloh. 
Do not thou then be persuaded by them, for there lie in wait for him of them more than forty men, who have put themselves under a curse neither to eat nor drink till they kill him; and now they are ready waiting the promise from thee. @ Samơ̆ anăm ih hmư̆ ƀing anŭn ôh, yua kơ hmâo rơbeh kơ pă pluh čô amăng ƀing gơñu dŏ krăp kiăng ngă kơ Pôl. Gơñu hmâo ƀuăn rơ̆ng ƀu ƀơ̆ng huă kŏn mơñum lơi tơl gơñu hmâo pơdjai hĭ Pôl. Ră anai gơñu dŏ krăp laih kơnơ̆ng dŏ tơguan tơlơi ih tŭ ư đôč.”
The chiliarch then dismissed the youth, commanding [him], Utter to no one that thou hast represented these things to me. @ Tui anŭn, khua tơhan brơi tơdăm anŭn glaĭ hăng khă anăm laĭ kơ hlơi hlơi ôh abih tơlơi gơ̆ hmâo laĭ kơ ñu.
And having called to [him] certain two of the centurions, he said, Prepare two hundred soldiers that they may go as far as Caesarea, and seventy horsemen, and two hundred light-armed footmen, for the third hour of the night. @ Giơ̆ng anŭn khua gĭt gai tơhan iâu dua čô khua tơhan khul sa rơtuh hăng laĭ: “Ƀơi dua rơpăn mông mlam anai, prăp rơmet hăng pre lui bĕ dua rơtuh čô tơhan rơbat, tơjuh pluh čô tơhan đĭ aseh hăng dua rơtuh čô tơhan djă tơbăk kiăng kơ nao pơ Sêsarê. 
And [he ordered them] to provide beasts, that they might set Paul on them and carry [him] safe through to Felix the governor, @ Ăt khŏm prăp rơmet pioh mơ̆n sa drơi aseh kơ Pôl đĭ laih anŭn ba nao gơ̆ hăng tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua pơ ơi Phêlik khua čar.” 
having written a letter, couched in this form: @ Ñu čih mơit sa pŏk hră tui anai: 
Claudius Lysias to the most excellent governor Felix, greeting. @ “Klôd Lisias čih mơit kơ Ơi Phêlik Khua Čar, kơkuh kơ ih. 
This man, having been taken by the Jews, and being about to be killed by them, I came up with the military and took out [of their hands], having learned that he was a Roman. @ Ƀing Yuđa hmâo mă laih mơnuih anai, laih anŭn ƀiă či pơdjai hĭ gơ̆ yơh. Samơ̆ kâo hơmao ba tơhan truh pơ anŭn hăng pơklaih hĭ gơ̆, yua kơ kâo thâo ñu jing sa čô ană plei pla Rôm. 
And desiring to know the charge on which they accused him, I brought him down to their council; @ Kâo kiăng thâo klih yua hơgĕt gơñu phong gơ̆, hnŭn yơh kâo ba ñu nao ƀơi anăp ƀing khua phat kơđi ƀing Yuđa. 
whom I found to be accused of questions of their law, but to have no charge laid against him [making him] worthy of death or of bonds. @ Kâo ƀuh tơlơi ƀing gơñu phong kơ gơ̆ djơ̆ kơ tơlơi juăt ƀing gơñu pô đôč, samơ̆ ƀu hmâo tơlơi soh hơgĕt lăp kơ pơdjai ƀôdah lăp krư̆ ôh. 
But having received information of a plot about to be put in execution against the man [by the Jews], I have immediately sent him to thee, commanding also his accusers to say before thee the things that are against him. [Farewell.] @ Laih anŭn tơ kâo hmư̆ arăng laĭ brơi kâo thâo tơlơi arăng dưm tơlơi mơneč krăp ngă sat kơ gơ̆, kâo pơkiaŏ nao gơ̆ pơ ih mơtam, laih anŭn kâo ăt pơđar kơ ƀing phong kơ gơ̆ brơi gơñu nao ruai pơrơđah tơlơi soh gơ̆ ƀơi anăp ih.”
The soldiers therefore, according to what was ordered them, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris, @ Tui anŭn ƀing tơhan ngă tui hăng tơlơi pơđar, gơñu mă Pôl hlăk amăng mlam ba gơ̆ truh pơ plei Antipatris. 
and on the morrow, having left the horsemen to go with him, returned to the fortress. @ Hrơi tơdơi gơñu wơ̆t glaĭ pơ kơđông, kơnơ̆ng brơi ƀing tơhan đĭ aseh nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng Pôl. 
And these, having entered into Caesarea, and given up the letter to the governor, presented Paul also to him. @ Tơ gơñu truh pơ plei Sêsarê, gơñu brơi hră kơ khua čar, hăng pơdah Pôl ƀơi anăp ñu mơ̆n. 
And having read [it], and asked of what eparchy he was, and learned that [he was] of Cilicia, @ Giơ̆ng lăng hră, khua čar tơña Pôl dŏ pơ kwar pă, laih anŭn tơ ñu thâo kơ Pôl jing mơnuih mơ̆ng čar Silisi, 
he said, I will hear thee fully when thine accusers also are arrived. And he commanded him to be kept in Herod's praetorium. @ ñu laĭ: “Tơ ƀing phong truh pơ anai kâo či kơsem kơđi ih.” Hnŭn yơh ñu pơđar arăng gak wai Pôl amăng sang pơtao Hêrôt.
And after five days came down the high priest Ananias, with the elders, and a certain orator called Tertullus, and laid their informations against Paul before the governor. @ Giơ̆ng kơ rơma hrơi rơgao, khua ngă yang prŏng hloh Ananias nao pơ Sêsarê hrŏm hơbĭt hăng đơđa ƀing kŏng tha, laih anŭn sa čô nai tơlơi juăt anăn ñu Tertulus. Gơñu pơdah brơi kơ Phêlik jing khua čar tơlơi gơñu phong kơ Pôl. 
And he having been called, Tertullus began to accuse, saying, Seeing we enjoy great peace through thee, and that excellent measures are executed for this nation by thy forethought, @ Tơ arăng iâu Pôl mŭt laih, Tertulus čơdơ̆ng phong kơ gơ̆ tui anai: “Ơ khua čar, ơi Phêlik, yua kơ mơ̆ng ih gơmơi hmâo lu tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua, laih anŭn yua mơ̆ng tơlơi thâo mĭn ih, čar anai hmâo lu tơlơi pơplih hiam. 
we receive [it] always and everywhere, most excellent Felix, with all thankfulness. @ Tui anŭn amăng abih hrơi mông, laih anŭn amăng djŏp djang anih, ƀing gơmơi leng kơ mă tŭ hơdôm tơlơi anŭn hăng pran jua hơdơr tơngia bơni hơơč lu biă mă. 
But that I may not too much intrude on thy time, I beseech thee to hear us briefly in thy kindness. @ Samơ̆ kiăng kơ ƀu ngă pơgŭn ih sui ôh, kâo rơkâo ih yua pran jua hiam klă ih, hmư̆ tơlơi gơmơi ruai pơrơđah ber ƀiă đôč. 
For finding this man a pest, and moving sedition among all the Jews throughout the world, and a leader of the sect of the Nazaraeans; @ Yua kơ gơmơi ƀuh pô anai jing kar hăng mơnơ̆ng kheng klin, ñu hmâo ngă pơrŭng pơrăng tơ̆ng krah ƀing Yuđa amăng djŏp lŏn tơnah, laih anŭn ñu jing sa čô khua kơ ƀing Nasaret. 
who also attempted to profane the temple; whom we also had seized, [and would have judged according to our law; @ Ñu hmâo ngă pơgrĭ hĭ laih wơ̆t sang kơkuh pơpŭ mơ̆n, hnŭn yơh gơmơi hmâo mă čăp ñu laih. 
having commanded his accusers to come to thee;] of whom thou canst thyself, in examining [him], know the certainty of all these things of which we accuse him. @ Tơdah ih tơña kơsem ñu, ih pô či thâo yơh mơ̆ng ñu abih tơlơi gơmơi phong kơ ñu.” 
And the Jews also joined in pressing the matter against [Paul], saying that these things were so. @ Ƀing mơnuih Yuđa ăt sa pran jua hrŏm hơbĭt hăng tơlơi phong anŭn, laih anŭn khŭt khăt tơlơi anŭn jing sĭt.
But Paul, the governor having beckoned to him to speak, answered, Knowing that for many years thou hast been judge to this nation, I answer readily as to the things which concern myself. @ Tơ khua čar yơr tơngan ngă gru brơi Pôl pơhiăp, Pôl laĭ glaĭ:
“Kâo thâo kơ ih jing khua phat kơđi amăng čar anai sui thŭn laih, hnŭn yơh kâo mơak pơhiăp pơgang kơ kâo pô ƀơi anăp ih. 
As thou mayest know that there are not more than twelve days since I went up to worship at Jerusalem, @ Kar hăng ih hmâo thâo laih, kâo đĭ nao pơ plei pơ Yêrusalem kiăng kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai. Aka ƀu rơgao pluh dua hrơi anai ôh. 
and neither in the temple did they find me discoursing to any one, or making any tumultuous gathering together of the crowd, nor in the synagogues, nor in the city; @ Gơñu aka ƀu ƀuh ôh kâo pơrơjah hăng arăng ƀôdah pơsur ƀing ană plei pla ngă pơrŭng, thâo dah amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, thâo dah amăng sang bơjơnum, ƀôdah amăng plei prŏng. 
neither can they make good the things of which they now accuse me. @ Ră anai, gơñu ăt kŏn hmâo hơgĕt lơi tơlơi pơsĭt kơ tơlơi gơñu pơčŭt kơ kâo. 
But this I avow to thee, that in the way which they call sect, so I serve my fathers' God, believing all things which are written throughout the law, and in the prophets; @ Samơ̆ kâo tŭ ư tơlơi anai ƀơi anăp ih, kâo kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai ƀing ơi gơmơi tui Jơlan gơñu laĭ jing soh, samơ̆ kâo đaŏ abih tơlơi hmâo čih laih amăng hơdrôm hră tơlơi Juăt Môis hăng hơdrôm hră ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo. 
having hope towards God, which they themselves also receive, that there is to be a resurrection both of just and unjust. @ Kâo hmâo tơlơi čang rơmang amăng Ơi Adai kar hăng ƀing gơñu pô ăt hmâo laih mơ̆n, jing tơlơi ƀing tơpă hiam wơ̆t ƀing wĕ wŏ či hơdip glaĭ. 
For this cause I also exercise [myself] to have in everything a conscience without offence towards God and men. @ Ăt yua kơ tơlơi anŭn, nanao kâo gir tui hơduah kiăng hmâo pran jua tơpă rơgoh hiam, ƀu hmâo hlơi dưi ƀuah ƀơi anăp Ơi Adai laih anŭn ƀơi anăp ană mơnuih. 
And after a lapse of many years I arrived, bringing alms to my nation, and offerings. @ Tơdơi kơ lu thŭn kâo dŏ ataih, ră anai kâo wơ̆t glaĭ pơ lŏn čar kâo pô, kiăng kơ ba gơnam djru gŭm kơ kơnŭng djuai kâo laih anŭn pơyơr mơnơ̆ng ngă yang. 
Whereupon they found me purified in the temple, with neither crowd nor tumult. But it was certain Jews from Asia, @ Gơñu ƀuh kâo hlăk dŏ ngă phĕt pơrơgoh amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, ƀu hmâo pơƀŭt mơnuih lu ƀôdah ngă tơlơi pơrŭng hơgĕt ôh. 
who ought to appear before thee and accuse, if they have anything against me; @ Samơ̆ đơđa ƀing Yuđa mơ̆ng čar Asi hmâo pơ anŭn; tơdah gơñu hmâo tơlơi hơgĕt phong kơ kâo, khŏm gơñu rai ƀơi anăp ih phong kâo bĕ, 
or let these themselves say what wrong they found in me when I stood before the council, @ ƀôdah ƀing mơnuih dŏ pơ anai khŏm laĭ brơi bĕ hơgĕt tơlơi soh kâo hmâo ngă, hlăk kâo dŏ ƀơi anăp tơpul phat kơđi. 
[other] than concerning this one voice which I cried standing amongst them: I am judged this day by you touching [the] resurrection of [the] dead. @ Tơdah hmâo kơnơ̆ng sa tơlơi anai kâo pơhiăp kơtang tơdang kâo dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơi anăp gơñu: ‘Yua kơ tơlơi ƀing djai či hơdip glaĭ yơh, arăng phat kơđi kâo ƀơi anăp ƀing gih hrơi anai.’”
And Felix, knowing accurately the things concerning the way, adjourned them, saying, When Lysias the chiliarch is come down I will determine your affair; @ Samơ̆ Phêlik, hmâo thâo rơđah mơ̆n kơ Jơlan anai, pơhrưĭ glaĭ hrơi phat kơđi hăng laĭ: “Tơ Lisias khua gĭt gai tơhan rai amơĭ, kâo či khư̆p ư bruă anai.” 
ordering the centurion to keep him, and that he should have freedom, and to hinder none of his friends to minister to him. @ Giơ̆ng anŭn ñu pơđar kơ khua tơhan kơ̆ng wai Pôl, samơ̆ khŏm brơi kơ gơ̆ tơlơi rơngai ƀiă, laih anŭn anăm khă ôh ƀing giăng mah ñu rai ba mơnơ̆ng djru.
And after certain days, Felix having arrived with Drusilla his wife, who was a Jewess, he sent for Paul and heard him concerning the faith in Christ. @ Giơ̆ng kơ ƀiă hrơi mơ̆ng anŭn, Phêlik hrŏm hơbĭt hăng bơnai ñu HʼDrusil, mơnuih Yuđa rai; laih anŭn ñu pơkiaŏ nao arăng iâu Pôl kiăng kơ hmư̆ ñu pơtô tơlơi đaŏ amăng Yêsu Krist. 
And as he reasoned concerning righteousness, and temperance, and the judgment about to come, Felix, being filled with fear, answered, Go for the present, and when I get an opportunity I will send for thee; @ Samơ̆ tơ Pôl pơtô hiăp djơ̆ kơ tơlơi tơpă, tơlơi djơ̆ hơnơ̆ng laih anŭn kơ tơlơi phat kơđi hrơi tơdơi, Phêlik hwĭ hăng laĭ: “Ră anai ih tơbiă bĕ; Dơ̆ kâo wăn kâo či iâu ih dơ̆ng.” 
hoping at the same time that money would be given him by Paul: wherefore also he sent for him the oftener and communed with him. @ Tơdang anŭn Phêlik čang rơmang kơ Pôl brơi prăk apah hơgơ̆m kơ ñu, hnŭn yơh ñu iâu nanao Pôl nao pơ ñu hăng pơhiăp hăng gơ̆.
But when two years were completed, Felix was relieved by Porcius Festus as his successor; and Felix, desirous to oblige the Jews, to acquire their favour, left Paul bound. @ Rơgao dua thŭn mơ̆ng anŭn, Pôrtus Phêtus nao plih Phêlik. Yua kơ Phêlik kiăng ngă bơmơak kơ ƀing Yuđa, hnŭn yơh ñu ăt dŏ brơi arăng krư̆ Pôl.
Festus therefore, being come into the eparchy, after three days went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea. @ Klâo hrơi tơdơi Phêtus truh pơ kwar anŭn, mơ̆ng plei Sêsarê ñu đĭ nao pơ plei Yêrusalem. 
And the chief priests and the chief of the Jews laid informations before him against Paul, and besought him, @ Ƀing khua ngă yang prŏng hăng ƀing khua wai lăng ƀing Yuđa phong kơ Pôl ƀơi anăp Phêtus. Gơñu rơkâo kơwưh Phêtus 
asking as a grace against him that he would send for him to Jerusalem, laying people in wait to kill him on the way. @ rơkâo kơ ñu ngă tơlơi pap brơi arăng ba Pôl pơ plei Yêrusalem, yua kơ gơñu hmâo dưm laih tơlơi mơneč krăp pơdjai Pôl rŏk jơlan. 
Festus therefore answered that Paul should be kept at Caesarea, and that he himself was about to set out shortly. @ Phêtus laĭ glaĭ arăng krư̆ Pôl pơ plei Sêsarê, laih anŭn ñu pô mơ̆n či wơ̆t glaĭ tañ pơ anŭn. 
Let therefore the persons of authority among you, says he, going down too, if there be anything in this man, accuse him. @ Phêtus laĭ: “Tui anŭn brơi ƀing khua wai lăng kơ ƀing gih nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng kâo pơ plei Sêsarê, laih anŭn tơdah mơnuih anŭn hmâo tơlơi soh hơgĕt, phong ñu bĕ.”
And having remained among them not more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea; and on the next day, having sat down on the judgment-seat, commanded Paul to be brought. @ Phêtus dŏ hăng gơñu pơ anŭn năng ai sapăn ƀôdah pluh hrơi, ñu trŭn nao pơ plei Sêsarê. Hrơi tơdơi, ñu dŏ ber ƀơi gre phat kơđi laih anŭn ñu pơtă arăng ba Pôl mŭt nao pơ ñu. 
And when he was come, the Jews who were come down from Jerusalem stood round, bringing many and grievous charges which they were not able to prove: @ Tơ Pôl truh laih, ƀing Yuđa mơ̆ng plei Yêrusalem dŏ dơ̆ng jum dar gơ̆ hăng phong kơ gơ̆ lu tơlơi soh prŏng, samơ̆ gơñu ƀu hmâo tơlơi hơgĕt dưi pơsĭt ôh. 
Paul answering for himself, Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar, have I offended [in] anything. @ Pôl pơhiăp pơgang kơ ñu pô: “Kâo ƀu hmâo ngă tơlơi soh hơgĕt pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng Tơlơi Juăt ƀing Yuđa, ƀôdah pơkơdơ̆ng hăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ, kŏn pơkơdơ̆ng hăng Sêsar lơi.”
But Festus, desirous of obliging the Jews, to acquire their favour, answering Paul, said, Art thou willing to go up to Jerusalem, there to be judged before me concerning these things? @ Samơ̆ Phêtus kiăng ngă bơmơak kơ ƀing Yuđa, ñu laĭ kơ Pôl: “Ih kiăng đĭ nao pơ Yêrusalem hăng tŭ tơlơi phat kơđi kơ tơlơi arăng phong anai ƀơi anăp kâo pơ anŭn mơ̆?”
But Paul said, I am standing before the judgment-seat of Caesar, where I ought to be judged. To the Jews have I done no wrong, as *thou* also very well knowest. @ Pôl laĭ glaĭ: “Kâo dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơi anăp sang phat kơđi Sêsar. Jing anih kâo khŏm tŭ tơlơi phat kơđi. Kâo ƀu hmâo ngă soh hăng ƀing Yuđa ôh, kar hăng ih thâo laih. 
If then I have done any wrong and committed anything worthy of death, I do not deprecate dying; but if there is nothing of those things of which they accuse me, no man can give me up to them. I appeal to Caesar. @ Tơdah sĭt kâo hmâo tơlơi soh hăng tơlơi juăt ƀôdah ngă tơlơi soh hơgĕt lăp kơ djai, kâo ƀu hơngah ôh tŭ tơlơi djai. Samơ̆ tơdah tơlơi gơñu phong kơ kâo ƀu hmâo tơlơi sĭt ôh, ƀu hmâo hlơi dưi jao kâo kơ gơñu. Kâo iâu đĭ Sêsar phat kơđi kâo.”
Then Festus, having conferred with the council, answered, Thou hast appealed to Caesar. To Caesar shalt thou go. @ Tui anŭn, giơ̆ng kơ Phêtus črŏng sai hăng ƀing khua kơčĕ ñu pô, Phêtus laĭ glaĭ kơ Pôl: “Ih iâu đĭ Sêsar phat kơđi; ih či nao pơ Sêsar yơh.”
And when certain days had elapsed, Agrippa the king and Bernice arrived at Caesarea to salute Festus. @ Rơgao ƀiă hrơi mơ̆ng anŭn, pơtao Agripa hăng HʼBêrênis nao pơ Sêsarê kiăng čuă kơkuh kơ Phêtus. 
And when they had spent many days there, Festus laid before the king the matters relating to Paul, saying, There is a certain man left prisoner by Felix, @ Gơñu dŏ glaĭ pơ anŭn sui hrơi, Phêtus ba kơđi Pôl anŭn ruai pơrơđah kơ pơtao Agripa hăng laĭ: “Pơ anai hmâo sa čô mơnă mơ̆ng Phêlik pioh glaĭ. 
concerning whom, when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews laid informations, requiring judgment against him: @ Hlăk kâo truh pơ Yêrusalem, ƀing khua ngă yang prŏng hăng ƀing kŏng tha amăng ƀing Yuđa phong kơ gơ̆ hăng rơkâo kơ kâo klă kơđi kơ gơ̆. 
to whom I answered, It is not [the] custom of the Romans to give up any man before that the accused have the accusers face to face, and he have got opportunity of defence touching the charge. @ Samơ̆ kâo laĭ glaĭ kơ ƀing gơñu ƀing Rôm ƀu phiăn ôh jao brơi sa čô mơnuih hlâo kơ ñu hmâo mông dŏ ƀơi anăp ƀing phong kơ ñu, kiăng pơhiăp pơgang kơ tơlơi arăng phong kơ ñu. 
When therefore they had come together here, without putting it off, I sat the next day on the judgment-seat and commanded the man to be brought: @ Tui anŭn yơh, tơ ƀing gơñu rai pơ anai, kiăng kơ huaĭ rơngiă mông, hrơi tơdơi kâo dŏ ber ƀơi gre phat kơđi pơđar arăng ba rai gơ̆ pơ sang phat kơđi mơtam. 
concerning whom the accusers, standing up, brought no such accusation of guilt as *I* supposed; @ Ƀing phong kơ Pôl leng kơ dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơi anăp gre phat kơđi, samơ̆ gơñu ƀu dưi klă kơđi sa mơta tơlơi soh hơgĕt ôh tui hăng kâo pơmĭn. 
but had against him certain questions of their own system of worship, and concerning a certain Jesus who is dead, whom Paul affirmed to be living. @ Ƀing gơñu kơnơ̆ng pơrơjah kơ đơđa mơta tơlơi đaŏ gơñu pô đôč, laih anŭn kơ sa čô pô anăn Yêsu anŭn hmâo djai laih, samơ̆ Pôl khŭt khăt laĭ ăt dŏ hơdip. 
And as I myself was at a loss as to an inquiry into these things, I said, Was he willing to go to Jerusalem and there to be judged concerning these things? @ Yua kơ kâo ƀu thâo ôh hyư̆m khŏm pơkra tơlơi anŭn, hnŭn yơh kâo tơña Pôl tơdah ñu kiăng nao brơi arăng phat kơđi kơ tơlơi anŭn pơ plei Yêrusalem. 
But Paul having appealed to be kept for the cognisance of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept till I shall send him to Caesar. @ Samơ̆ tơ Pôl rơkâo dŏ glaĭ amăng sang mơnă anŭn dơ̆ng, kiăng kơ Sêsar phat kơđi brơi kơ ñu, hnŭn yơh kâo pơđar arăng wai ñu tơl kâo dưi ba nao ñu pơ Sêsar.”
And Agrippa [said] to Festus, I myself also would desire to hear the man. To-morrow, said he, thou shalt hear him. @ Agripa laĭ kơ Phêtus: “Kâo pô ăt kiăng hmư̆ ñu mơ̆n.” Phêtus laĭ glaĭ: “Pơgi ih či hmư̆ ñu.”
On the morrow therefore, Agrippa being come, and Bernice, with great pomp, and having entered into the hall of audience, with the chiliarchs and the men of distinction of the city, and Festus having given command, Paul was brought. @ Tui anŭn, hrơi tơdơi, pơtao Agripa hăng HʼBêrênis rai hăng tơlơi kơdrưh kơdrŏm, mŭt amăng anih phat kơđi hrŏm hăng ƀing khua gĭt gai tơhan, laih anŭn ƀing khua amăng plei anŭn. Tui hăng Phêtus pơđar, arăng ba rai Pôl. 
And Festus said, King Agrippa, and all men who are here present with us, ye see this person, concerning whom all the multitude of the Jews applied to me both in Jerusalem and here, crying out against [him] that he ought not to live any longer. @ Phêtus laĭ: “Ơ Pơtao Agripa hăng abih bang mơnuih dŏ pơ anai. Ƀing gih ƀuh mơnuih anai, yua kơ ñu yơh abih bang ƀing ană plei Yuđa, wơ̆t pơ plei Yêrusalem hăng wơ̆t pơ anai, ur rơkâo kơ kâo anăm brơi ñu dŏ hơdip dơ̆ng ôh. 
But I, having found that he had done nothing worthy of death, and this [man] himself having appealed to Augustus, I have decided to send him; @ Samơ̆ kâo ƀuh gơ̆ ƀu hmâo ngă tơlơi soh hơgĕt lăp kơ djai ôh. Yua kơ gơ̆ pô hmâo rơkâo đĭ Sêsar phat kơđi gơ̆, tui anŭn kâo khư̆p ư ba jao ñu nao pơ anŭn. 
concerning whom I have nothing certain to write to my lord. Wherefore I have brought him before you, and specially before thee, king Agrippa, so that an examination having been gone into I may have something to write: @ Samơ̆ kâo ƀu thâo klă rơđah ôh kơ tơlơi ñu, kiăng kơ čih ruai pơrơđah đĭ kơ Sêsar. Yua kơ anŭn yơh kâo brơi arăng ba rai gơ̆ ƀơi anăp ƀing ih, laih anŭn biă mă ñu kơ ih, Ơ Pơtao Agripa, kiăng kơ giơ̆ng ƀing ta tơña kơsem gơ̆ laih, kâo dưi hmâo tơlơi čih ruai đĭ. 
for it seems to me senseless, sending a prisoner, not also to signify the charges against him. @ Yua kơ kâo pơmĭn ƀu gal ôh ba nao sa čô mơnă tơdah ƀu laĭ rơđah tơlơi soh arăng phong kơ gơ̆.”
And Agrippa said to Paul, It is permitted thee to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretching out his hand answered in his defence: @ Hlăk anŭn pơtao Agripa laĭ kơ Pôl: “Ih dưi pơhiăp kiăng pơgang ih pô.” Tui anŭn Pôl yơr tơngan hăng pơhiăp pơgang ñu pô tui anai:
I count myself happy, king Agrippa, in having to answer to-day before thee concerning all of which I am accused by the Jews, @ “Ơ Pơtao Agripa, kâo pơmĭn kâo hmâo tơlơi mơyun pŭn, yua kơ hrơi anai kâo dưi pơgang kâo pô ƀơi anăp ih kơ abih tơlơi ƀing Yuđa phong kơ kâo. 
especially because thou art acquainted with all the customs and questions which are among the Jews; wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently. @ Yua kơ ih thâo rơđah laih abih bang tơlơi phiăn ƀing Yuđa laih anŭn tơlơi gơñu pơrơjah. Tui anŭn kâo rơkâo kơ ih gir añ dŏ hmư̆ kâo.
My manner of life then from my youth, which from its commencement was passed among my nation in Jerusalem, know all the Jews, @ Abih bang ƀing Yuđa leng kơ thâo soh sel kơ tơlơi kâo dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă čơdơ̆ng mơ̆ng kâo čơđai ƀơi tơ̆ng krah kơnŭng djuai kâo pô laih anŭn amăng plei Yêrusalem. 
who knew me before from the outset [of my life], if they would bear witness, that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee. @ Gơñu hmâo thâo laih kâo mơ̆ng sui, tơdah gơñu kiăng ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ tơlơi anai, kâo jing sa čô Pharisi, dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng huă tui hăng ƀing khul khĭp kơtang hloh amăng tơlơi đaŏ ƀing gơmơi. 
And now I stand to be judged because of the hope of the promise made by God to our fathers, @ Laih anŭn ră anai kâo dŏ ƀơi anai tŭ tơlơi arăng phat kơđi yua kơ tơlơi kâo čang rơmang ƀơi tơlơi ƀuăn Ơi Adai hmâo brơi kơ ơi adon ƀing gơmơi. 
to which our whole twelve tribes serving incessantly day and night hope to arrive; about which hope, O king, I am accused of [the] Jews. @ Yua kơ tơlơi čang rơmang anŭn yơh pluh dua kơnŭng djuai ƀing gơmơi dŏ tơguan, hăng pran jua hur har hrơi mlam gơmơi kơkuh pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai. Ơ Pơtao, laih anŭn ăt yua kơ tơlơi čang rơmang anŭn mơ̆n ƀing Yuđa phong kâo. 
Why should it be judged a thing incredible in your sight if God raises the dead? @ Hyư̆m ƀing gih pơ anai ƀu dưi đaŏ ôh kơ Ơi Adai dưi pơhơdip glaĭ ƀing mơnuih djai?
*I* indeed myself thought that I ought to do much against the name of Jesus the Nazaraean. @  Sĭt yơh kâo pô hlâo adih hmâo pơmĭn khŏm ngă djŏp tơlơi kiăng pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng anăn Yêsu plei Nasaret. 
Which also I did in Jerusalem, and myself shut up in prisons many of the saints, having received the authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death I gave my vote. @ Kâo hmâo ngă laih tui anŭn amăng plei Yêrusalem; mơ̆ng tơlơi dưi khua ngă yang prŏng, kâo ƀu kơnơ̆ng krư̆ lu ƀing rơgoh hiam đôč ôh, samơ̆ tơdah arăng klă kơđi brơi pơdjai gơñu, kâo ăt tŭ ư hrŏm hơbĭt hăng gơñu mơ̆n. 
And often punishing them in all the synagogues, I compelled them to blaspheme. And, being exceedingly furious against them, I persecuted them even to cities out [of our own land]. @ Lu wơ̆t kâo pơkơhmal gơñu amăng lu boh sang jơnum hăng pơgŏ gơñu hơngah lui tơlơi đaŏ; kâo hil gơñu kơtang biă mă, tơl kâo nao truh pơ plei ƀing djuai tuai kiăng ngă sat ƀing gơñu.”
And when, [engaged] in this, I was journeying to Damascus, with authority and power from the chief priests, @ “Tui anŭn yơh kâo nao pơ plei Damas hăng tơlơi dưi laih anŭn tơlơi pơđar mơ̆ng ƀing khua ngă yang prŏng. 
at mid-day, on the way, I saw, O king, a light above the brightness of the sun, shining from heaven round about me and those who were journeying with me. @ Ơ Pơtao, ƀơi yang hrơi dơ̆ng tơdang kâo rơbat ƀơi jơlan, kâo ƀuh tơlơi bơngač mơ̆ng adai, kơmlă hloh kơ yang hrơi, pơčrang jum dar kâo wơ̆t ƀing mơnuih nao hrŏm hơbĭt hăng kâo. 
And, when we were all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? [it is] hard for thee to kick against goads. @ Tơ abih bang ƀing gơmơi leng kơ rơbuh pơ lŏn, kâo hmư̆ asăp pơhiăp hăng kâo amăng tơlơi Hêbrơ: ‘Ơ Sôl, Ơ Sôl, hyư̆m ih ngă sat kơ Kâo? Ruă kơ ih pô yơh, ih čưng mơnơ̆ng hñueng.’ 
And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, *I* am Jesus whom *thou* persecutest: @ Kâo tơña: ‘Ơ Khua Yang, hlơi Ih?’ Khua Yang laĭ: ‘Kâo jing Yêsu, pô ih hlăk ngă sat. 
but rise up and stand on thy feet; for, for this purpose have I appeared to thee, to appoint thee to be a servant and a witness both of what thou hast seen, and of what I shall appear to thee in, @ Samơ̆ tơgŭ hăng dŏ dơ̆ng bĕ, yua kơ Kâo hmâo pơrơđah laih kơ ih, kiăng pơjing ih jing ding kơna Kâo laih anŭn jing pô ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ abih bang tơlơi ih hmâo ƀuh ƀơi Kâo laih anŭn kơ khul tơlơi Kâo či pơrơđah brơi kơ ih. 
taking thee out from among the people, and the nations, to whom *I* send thee, @ Kâo či pơklaih ih mơ̆ng ƀing ană plei Yuđa laih anŭn mơ̆ng ƀing djuai tuai jing anih kâo pơkiaŏ ih nao, 
to open their eyes, that they may turn from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive remission of sins and inheritance among them that are sanctified by faith in me. @ kiăng kơ pŏk mơta gơñu, ba gơñu mơ̆ng tơlơi kơnăm mơmŏt nao pơ tơlơi bơngač, laih anŭn ba gơñu mơ̆ng tơlơi dưi Satan wơ̆t glaĭ pơ Ơi Adai, kiăng kơ mơ̆ng tơlơi đaŏ amăng Kâo, gơñu dưi tŭ mă tơlơi pap brơi tơlơi soh laih anŭn gơñu dưi jing sa črăn amăng ƀing rơgoh hiam.’”
Whereupon, king Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision; @ “Tui anŭn Ơ Pơtao Agripa, kâo ƀu khĭn hơngah ôh kơ tơlơi pơƀuh mơ̆ng adai anŭn. 
but have, first to those both in Damascus and Jerusalem, and to all the region of Judaea, and to the nations, announced that they should repent and turn to God, doing works worthy of repentance. @ Samơ̆ blŭng hlâo kâo pơhaih kơ ƀing dŏ pơ plei Damas, laih anŭn pơ plei Yêrusalem, hăng tar ƀar čar Yuđa, laih anŭn wơ̆t amăng ƀing djuai tuai mơ̆n, pơtô gơñu khŏm kơhmal tơlơi soh hăng wơ̆t glaĭ kơ Ơi Adai, hăng pơrơđah bruă ngă lăp hăng tơlơi gơñu hmâo kơhmal tơlơi soh. 
On account of these things the Jews, having seized me in the temple, attempted to lay hands on and destroy me. @ Yua kơ tơlơi anŭn yơh, ƀing Yuđa mă kâo amăng sang kơkuh pơpŭ hăng hơduah kiăng pơdjai kâo. 
Having therefore met with [the] help which is from God, I have stood firm unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying nothing else than those things which both the prophets and Moses have said should happen, @ Samơ̆ Ơi Adai hmâo pơgang kâo laih truh pơ hrơi anai, tui anŭn kâo dŏ dơ̆ng pơ anai ngă gơ̆ng jơlan kơ ƀing anĕt wơ̆t kơ ƀing prŏng, ƀu pơhiăp hơgĕt tơlơi pơkŏn ôh kơnơ̆ng tơlơi ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo hăng Môis hmâo pơthâo hlâo khŏm truh: 
[namely,] whether Christ should suffer; whether he first, through resurrection of [the] dead, should announce light both to the people and to the nations. @ Kiăng laĭ Yang Krist či tŭ tơlơi tơnap tap, laih anŭn yua kơ Ñu jing Pô hơdip glaĭ tal blŭng hlâo mơ̆ng ƀing djai, Ñu či pơthâo tơlơi bơngač kơ tơlơi pơklaih brơi kơ ƀing Yuđa laih anŭn kơ ƀing djuai tuai.”
And as he answered for his defence with these things, Festus says with a loud voice, Thou art mad, Paul; much learning turns thee to madness. @ Tơdang Pôl pơhiăp pơgang ñu pô tui anŭn, Phêtus pơhiăp kraih: “Ơ Pôl, ih hưt yơh! Ih hrăm lu đơi tơl ih jing hưt.” 
But Paul said, I am not mad, most excellent Festus, but utter words of truth and soberness; @ Pôl laĭ glaĭ: “Kâo ƀu hưt ôh, Ơ Ơi Khua Phêtus, kâo pơhiăp tơlơi sĭt biă mă. 
for the king is informed about these things, to whom also I speak with all freedom. For I am persuaded that of these things nothing is hidden from him; for this was not done in a corner. @ Yua kơ pơtao thâo rơđah laih hơdôm tơlơi anai, hnŭn yơh kâo khĭn pơhiăp hăng ih; kâo đaŏ sĭt ƀu hmâo tơlơi hơgĕt ôh pơtao ƀu thâo, yua kơ abih bang tơlơi anai arăng ƀu ngă amăng tơlơi hơgơ̆m ôh. 
King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest. @ Ơ Pơtao Agripa, ih đaŏ mơ̆ kơ ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo? Kâo thâo ih đaŏ.”
And Agrippa [said] to Paul, In a little thou persuadest me to become a Christian. @ Pơtao Agripa laĭ glaĭ kơ Pôl: “Kơnơ̆ng amăng ƀiă mông đôč ih pơmĭn ih dưi ngă brơi kâo jing hĭ sa čô mơnuih đaŏ kơ Krist hă?”
And Paul [said], I would to God, both in little and in much, that not only thou, but all who have heard me this day, should become such as *I* also am, except these bonds. @ Pôl laĭ glaĭ: “Wơ̆t dah ƀiă ƀôdah sui mông, kâo rơkâo kơ Ơi Adai brơi ƀu djơ̆ kơnơ̆ng hơjăn ih đôč ôh, samơ̆ wơ̆t abih bang mơnuih dŏ hmư̆ kâo hrơi anai leng kơ jing kar hăng kâo, samơ̆ kơnơ̆ng rơngiao hrĕ čuăk anai đôč.”
And the king stood up, and the governor and Bernice, and those who sat with them, @ Tui anŭn pơtao, khua čar, HʼBêrênis, laih anŭn abih bang ƀing dŏ ber hrŏm hơbĭt hăng ƀing gơñu tơgŭ dơ̆ng soh sel. 
and having gone apart, they spoke to one another saying, This man does nothing worthy of death or of bonds. @ Tơdang gơñu tơbiă, gơñu bơlaĭ tơdruă gơñu: “Pô anai ƀu hmâo ngă sa mơta tơlơi soh hơgĕt lăp kơ djai ƀôdah lăp kơ tơlơi krư̆ ôh.” 
And Agrippa said to Festus, This man might have been let go if he had not appealed to Caesar. @ Pơtao Agripa laĭ kơ Phêtus: “Tơdah ñu aka iâu đĭ tơlơi phat kơđi ƀơi anăp Sêsar, ih dưi phư hĭ ñu.”
But when it had been determined that we should sail to Italy, they delivered up Paul and certain other prisoners to a centurion, by name Julius, of Augustus' company. @ Tơ khư̆p ư laih kơ tơlơi brơi gơmơi đĭ kompăn nao pơ čar Itali, arăng jao Pôl hăng đơđa ƀing mơnă pơkŏn kơ sa čô khua tơhan wai sa rơtuh čô anăn ñu Julius amăng phung tơhan sang pơtao Ôgust. 
And going on board a ship of Adramyttium about to navigate by the places along Asia, we set sail, Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us. @ Gơmơi đĭ kompăn mơ̆ng plei Adramit či nao pơ lu drun kompăn jưh kơtuai hang ia rơsĭ kwar Asi, laih anŭn gơmơi nao, hmâo Aristark sa čô mơnuih Masêđôn mơ̆ng plei Têsalônik nao hrŏm hăng gơmơi. 
And the next day we arrived at Sidon. And Julius treated Paul kindly and suffered him to go to his friends and refresh himself. @ Hrơi tơdơi kơ anŭn gơmơi truh pơ plei Sidôn laih anŭn Julius ngă hiam kơ Pôl, brơi ñu dưi hyu čuă ƀing giăng mah ñu hăng dưi mă tŭ mơnơ̆ng gơñu djru. 
And setting sail thence we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were contrary. @ Mơ̆ng anih anŭn gơmơi đĭ kompăn, yua kơ angĭn klă anăp, gơmơi nao hluai tui ter hang plao ia Čiprơ. 
And having sailed over the waters of Cilicia and Pamphylia we came to Myra in Lycia: @ Giơ̆ng gơmơi găn hĭ ia rơsĭ Silisi hăng Pamphili, gơmơi truh pơ plei Mira amăng čar Lisi. 
and there the centurion having found a ship of Alexandria sailing to Italy, he made us go on board her. @ Ƀơi anŭn khua tơhan ƀuh kompăn mơ̆ng Aleksandri nao pơ čar Itali, hnŭn yơh ñu brơi gơmơi đĭ kompăn anŭn.
And sailing slowly for many days, and having with difficulty got abreast of Cnidus, the wind not suffering us, we sailed under the lee of Crete abreast of Salmone; @ Kompăn gơmơi nao rơnang amăng lu hrơi, hăng tơlơi gleh glăn biă mă gơmơi dưi truh plei Kơnit. Yua kơ angĭn klă anăp gơmơi ƀu dưi nao ataih hloh dơ̆ng ôh, hnŭn yơh gơmơi nao ter hang plao ia Kret găn anăp plei Salmôn. 
and coasting it with difficulty we came to a certain place called Fair Havens, near to which was [the] city of Lasaea. @ Hăng tơlơi gleh glăn biă mă gơmơi hluai tui hang kuăl ia anŭn, laih anŭn truh pơ sa anih arăng pia Drun Jưh Hiam, jĕ plei prŏng Lasê.
And much time having now been spent, and navigation being already dangerous, because the fast also was already past, Paul counselled them, @ Gơmơi hmâo rơngiă lu hrơi, laih anŭn tơlơi hyu hăng kompăn jing hĭ hyưt pưt biă mă yua kơ hrơi ƀing Yuđa ư̆ ƀơ̆ng huă rơgao hĭ laih, tui anŭn Pôl pơđur kơ gơñu hăng laĭ, 
saying, Men, I perceive that the navigation will be with disaster and much loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives. @ “Ơ ƀing khua, kâo ƀuh tơlơi ƀing ta hyu anai či hmâo tơlơi hyưt pưt laih anŭn lu tơlơi răm rai prŏng, ƀu djơ̆ kơnơ̆ng kơ dram gơnam hăng kompăn đôč ôh, samơ̆ wơ̆t kơ tơlơi hơdip ƀing ta mơ̆n.” 
But the centurion believed rather the helmsman and the shipowner than what was said by Paul. @ Samơ̆ khua tơhan gưt kơ pô găt kompăn hăng pô kompăn hloh kơ tơlơi Pôl laĭ. 
And the harbour being ill adapted to winter in, the most counselled to set sail thence, if perhaps they might reach Phoenice to winter in, a port of Crete looking north-east and south-east. @ Yua kơ anih drun jưh anŭn ƀu hiam ôh kơ kompăn dŏ amăng bơyan puih, hnŭn yơh lu mơnuih tŭ ư lui anih anŭn, brơi kompăn gir khŏm nao truh pơ plei Phênik, jing drun jưh ƀơi plao ia Kret, dŏ gah akiăng yŭ kơ dơnŭng hăng yŭ kơ kơdư, kiăng dŏ ƀơi anŭn amăng bơyan puih.
And [the] south wind blowing gently, supposing that they had gained their object, having weighed anchor they sailed close in shore along Crete. @ Hmâo angĭn rơnang čơdơ̆ng thut mơ̆ng dơnŭng, gơñu pơmĭn dưi ngă tui hăng hơdră gơñu hmâo pơkra laih, hnŭn yơh gơñu dui đĭ pơsơi kơ̆ng kompăn hăng nao hluai tui hang plao ia Kret. 
But not long after there came down it a hurricane called Euroclydon. @ Samơ̆ tañ mơtam hmâo angĭn kơtang arăng pia Ơrakilôn mơ̆ng plao ia anŭn hơprah trŭn. 
And the ship being caught and driven, and not able to bring her head to the wind, letting her go we were driven [before it]. @ Angĭn pưh kompăn tơl gơmơi ƀu dưi pơkơdơ̆ng hăng angĭn ôh, tui anŭn gơmơi phư lui măk ai kompăn nao tui hăng angĭn pưh pơđung ñu. 
But running under the lee of a certain island called Clauda, we were with difficulty able to make ourselves masters of the boat; @ Gơmơi găn ƀơi anih kơđap plao ia anĕt arăng pia jing Klôda, laih anŭn hăng tơlơi gleh biă mă kah gơmơi dưi kă sŏng pơklaih. 
which having hoisted up, they used helps, frapping the ship; and fearing lest they should run into Syrtis and run aground, and having lowered the gear they were so driven. @ Giơ̆ng kơ arăng yŏng đĭ sŏng pơklaih, gơñu mă hrĕ hăng kă hĭ jum dar kompăn; laih anŭn yua kơ hwĭ či đom hĭ ƀơi hang čuah Sirtis, gơñu pơtrŭn hĭ khăn kompăn laih anŭn phư lui măk ai angĭn pưh nao. 
But the storm being extremely violent on us, on the next day they threw cargo overboard, @ Hrơi tơdơi kơ anŭn, angĭn rơbŭ ăt dŏ kơtang đôč, tui anŭn gơñu čơdơ̆ng glŏm lui hĭ gơnam tam amăng ia rơsĭ. 
and on the third day with their own hands they cast away the ship furniture. @ Hrơi tal klâo gơñu glŏm hĭ hơdôm mơnơ̆ng kơ kompăn yua amăng ia rơsĭ. 
And neither sun nor stars appearing for many days, and no small storm lying on us, in the end all hope of our being saved was taken away. @ Amăng lu hrơi ƀu ƀuh yang hrơi, kŏn ƀuh pơtŭ lơi, rơbŭ ăt thut kơtang biă mă tơl gơmơi ƀu hmâo dơ̆ng tah tơlơi čang rơmang dưi klaih.
And when they had been a long while without taking food, Paul then standing up in the midst of them said, Ye ought, O men, to have hearkened to me, and not have made sail from Crete and have gained this disaster and loss. @ Sui hrơi laih gơñu ƀu hmâo ƀơ̆ng huă ôh, Pôl tơgŭ tơ̆ng krah gơñu hăng laĭ: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, tơdah ƀing gih hmư̆ kâo mơ̆ng blŭng hlâo, anăm tơbiă ôh mơ̆ng plao ia Kret sĭt yơh ƀing ta ƀu tŭ ôh tơlơi răm rai laih anŭn tơlơi rơngiă anai. 
And now I exhort you to be of good courage, for there shall be no loss at all of life of [any] of you, only of the ship. @ Samơ̆ ră anai kâo alum pơđur ƀing ih dŏ kơjăp pran jua bĕ; yua kơ ƀu či hmâo ôh sa čô amăng ƀing gih rơngiă tơlơi hơdip, kơnơ̆ng rơngiă kompăn đôč. 
For an angel of the God, whose I am and whom I serve, stood by me this night, @ Yua kơ mlam tơ̆m brôi Ơi Adai, Pô jing khua kâo laih anŭn Pô kâo kơkuh pơpŭ, pơkiaŏ rai sa čô ling jang Ñu dŏ dơ̆ng jĕ kâo hăng laĭ, 
saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must stand before Caesar; and behold, God has granted to thee all those that sail with thee. @ ‘Ơ Pôl, anăm hwĭ ôh; ih khŏm dŏ dơ̆ng ƀơi anăp Sêsar; laih anŭn anai nê, Ơi Adai hmâo pha brơi kơ ih abih bang ƀing mơnuih đĭ kompăn hrŏm hăng ih.’ 
Wherefore be of good courage, men, for I believe God that thus it shall be, as it has been said to me. @ Tui anŭn, Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng dŏ kơjăp pran jua bĕ, yua kơ kâo đaŏ sĭt kơ Ơi Adai hơdôm tơlơi anŭn či truh tui hăng tơlơi Ñu hmâo laĭ laih kơ kâo. 
But we must be cast ashore on a certain island. @ Samơ̆ ƀing ta či đung nao đom hĭ ƀơi sa boh plao ia.”
And when the fourteenth night was come, we being driven about in Adria, towards the middle of the night the sailors supposed that some land neared them, @ Truh mlam tal pluh pă, kompăn gơmơi ăt dŏ đung hyu ƀơi ia rơsĭ Adriatik, amăng tơ̆ng krah mlam ƀing đĭ kompăn mĭn dah gơñu jĕ truh pơ hang. 
and having sounded found twenty fathoms, and having gone a little farther and having again sounded they found fifteen fathoms; @ Tui anŭn gơñu plĕ trŭn hrĕ boh pơkă laih anŭn thâo boh dlam pă pluh met. Tơdơi ƀiă kơ anŭn gơñu pơkă dơ̆ng hăng thâo boh dlam klâo pluh met. 
and fearing lest we should be cast on rocky places, casting four anchors out of the stern, they wished that day were come. @ Hwĭ jrơ̆m djơ̆ boh pơtâo, hnŭn yơh gơñu mơ̆ng klon kompăn klaih trŭn pă klŏ pơsơi kơ̆ng amăng ia rơsĭ, laih anŭn gơñu iâu laĭ kiăng adai tañ rơđah. 
But the sailors wishing to flee out of the ship, and having let down the boat into the sea under pretext of being about to carry out anchors from the prow, @ Samơ̆ ƀing găt kompăn hơduah jơlan kiăng đuaĭ mơ̆ng kompăn, gơñu pơtrŭn sŏng amăng ia rơsĭ gơñu ngă ƀlor nao glŏm pơsơi kơ̆ng ƀơi anăp akŏ kompăn, 
Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, Unless these abide in the ship *ye* cannot be saved. @ Pôl laĭ kơ khua tơhan hăng ƀing tơhan: “Tơdah ƀing anai ƀu dŏ amăng kompăn, ƀing gih ƀu dưi klaih ôh.” 
Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the boat and let her fall. @ Tui anŭn ƀing tơhan trơĭ hĭ hrĕ akă sŏng anŭn hăng brơi ñu lĕ hĭ amăng ia.
And while it was drawing on to daylight, Paul exhorted them all to partake of food, saying, Ye have passed the fourteenth day watching in expectation without taking food. @ Tơ adai jĕ rơđah, Pôl alum pơđur kơ abih bang mơnuih brơi ƀơ̆ng huă. Ñu laĭ: “Ƀing gih hmâo dŏ tơguan pluh pă hrơi laih, ư̆ ƀu ƀơ̆ng huă đơsĕt ôh. 
Wherefore I exhort you to partake of food, for this has to do with your safety; for not a hair from the head of any one of you shall perish. @ Hnŭn yơh ră anai kâo pơđur ƀing gih ƀơ̆ng huă bĕ, kiăng kơ ƀing gih dưi dŏ hơdip; yua kơ ƀu hmâo ôh sa ară ƀuk ƀơi akŏ ƀing gih či rơngiă hĭ.” 
And, having said these things and taken a loaf, he gave thanks to God before all, and having broken it began to eat. @ Giơ̆ng laĭ tui anŭn, Pôl mă ƀañ tơpŭng, bơni hơơč kơ Ơi Adai ƀơi anăp abih bang, laih anŭn čơdơ̆ng ƀơ̆ng yơh. 
And all taking courage, themselves also took food. @ Tui anŭn abih bang gơñu hmâo tơlơi pơđĭ pran jua laih anŭn ƀơ̆ng huă mơ̆n. 
And we were in the ship, all the souls, two hundred and seventy-six. @ Abih bang ƀing gơmơi amăng kompăn anŭn hmâo dua rơtuh tơjuh pluh năm čô. 
And having satisfied themselves with food, they lightened the ship, casting out the wheat into the sea. @ Giơ̆ng gơñu ƀơ̆ng huă trơi laih, gơñu mă glŏm hĭ pơdai tơpŭng amăng ia rơsĭ kiăng kơ kompăn djhul ƀiă.
And when it was day they did not recognise the land; but they perceived a certain bay having a strand, on which they were minded, if they should be able, to run the ship ashore; @ Tơ adai rơđah laih, gơñu ƀu thâo krăn ôh lŏn anŭn, samơ̆ gơñu ƀuh hmâo hŏk ia hăng hang čuah. Gơñu pơmĭn tơdah dưi brơi kompăn nao jưh pơ anŭn. 
and, having cast off the anchors, they left [them] in the sea, at the same time loosening the lashings of the rudders, and hoisting the foresail to the wind, they made for the strand. @ Tui anŭn gơñu trơĭ hĭ hrĕ akă pơsơi kơ̆ng, lui hĭ amăng ia rơsĭ, laih anŭn gơñu kleh hrĕ akă gai găt kompăn. Giơ̆ng anŭn gơñu pơđĭ khăn gah akŏ kompăn brơi angĭn thut kompăn anŭn nao pơ hang. 
And falling into a place where two seas met they ran the ship aground, and the prow having stuck itself fast remained unmoved, but the stern was broken by the force of the waves. @ Samơ̆ kompăn nao djơ̆ ƀơi anih kôl čuah amăng ia, hnŭn yơh kompăn đom hĭ ƀơi anŭn. Akŏ kompăn hơtơ̆p nao amăng čuah, ƀu thâo pơpư̆ tah, bơ kơ klon kompăn ia poh yă klă pơčah hĭ brăk brai.
And [the] counsel of the soldiers was that they should kill the prisoners, lest any one should swim off and escape. @ Ƀing tơhan pơmĭn kiăng pơdjai hĭ abih bang ƀing mơnă hwĭ kơ ƀing gơ̆ luai truh hang laih anŭn đuaĭ kơdŏp hĭ. 
But the centurion, desirous of saving Paul, hindered them of their purpose, and commanded those who were able to swim, casting themselves first [into the sea], to get out on land; @ Samơ̆ khua tơhan kiăng pơklaih Pôl, tui anŭn ñu khă tơlơi pơmĭn gơñu kiăng ngă anŭn. Ñu pơđar kơ ƀing hlơi thâo luai brơi gơñu kơdâo trŭn hlâo hăng luai nao pơ hang. 
and the rest, some on boards, some on some of the things [that came] from the ship; and thus it came to pass that all got safe to land. @ Bơ ƀing ăt dŏ glaĭ či tui klon, đơđa đĭ hơnal tơr, đơđa kuăr ƀơi hơnal kompăn pơčah. Hnŭn yơh abih bang gơñu leng kơ đĭ truh pơ hang hăng tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua.
And when we got safe [to land] we then knew that the island was called Melita. @ Giơ̆ng kơ gơmơi klaih laih, hlăk anŭn gơmơi thâo plao ia anŭn arăng pơanăn ñu Maltơ. 
But the barbarians shewed us no common kindness; for, having kindled a fire, they took us all in because of the rain that was falling and because of the cold. @ Ƀing ană plei plao ia anŭn ngă hiam biă mă kơ gơmơi. Gơñu pơtŏ apui laih anŭn tŭ jum abih bang ƀing gơmơi, yua kơ adai čơdơ̆ng hơjan laih anŭn rơŏt. 
And Paul having gathered a [certain] quantity of sticks together in a bundle and laid [it] on the fire, a viper coming out from the heat seized his hand. @ Pôl duñ sa čơnaŏ djuh glŏm amăng apui, hmâo sa drơi ala tơbăk tơbiă mơ̆ng djuh yua kơ pơ-iă laih anŭn ñu păl ƀơi tơngan Pôl. 
And when the barbarians saw the beast hanging from his hand, they said to one another, This man is certainly a murderer, whom, [though] saved out of the sea, Nemesis has not allowed to live. @ Tơ ƀing ană plei plao ia anŭn ƀuh ala păl ƀơi tơngan Pôl, gơñu pơ laĭ tơdruă: “Sĭt biă mă pô anai jing sa čô pơdjai mơnuih. Wơ̆t dah ñu klaih laih mơ̆ng ia rơsĭ tŭ mơ̆n, tơlơi tơpă ƀu brơi ñu dŏ hơdip ôh.” 
*He* however, having shaken off the beast into the fire, felt no harm. @ Samơ̆ Pôl añah hĭ ala anŭn amăng apui, laih anŭn ƀu hmâo tơlơi ruă hơgĕt ôh. 
But *they* expected that he would have swollen or fallen down suddenly dead. But when they had expected a long time and saw nothing unusual happen to him, changing their opinion, they said he was a god. @ Ƀing anŭn pơmĭn dah drơi jan Pôl či brah đĭ ƀôdah rơbuh djai mơtam. Samơ̆ tơdơi gơñu dŏ krăp lăng sui ƀiă, gơñu ƀu ƀuh tơlơi hơgĕt phara truh kơ gơ̆ ôh, gơñu pơplih glaĭ hĭ tơlơi pơmĭn hăng laĭ gơ̆ jing sa čô yang.
Now in the country surrounding that place were the lands belonging to the chief man of the island, by name Publius, who received us and gave [us] hospitality three days in a very friendly way. @ Jĕ pơ anih anŭn hmâo lŏn lơ̆m kơ khua plao ia anŭn anăn ñu Publius. Ñu jak hăng jum gơmơi hăng tơlơi hơ̆k mơak biă mă amăng klâo hrơi. 
And it happened that the father of Publius lay ill of fever and dysentery; to whom Paul entered in, and having prayed and laid his hands on him cured him. @ Hlăk anŭn, ama Publius duăm laih anŭn ruă kian juă glai drah dŏ đih ƀơi sưng. Pôl nao ngui ñu, iâu laĭ ah tơngan ƀơi gơ̆, hăng pơsuaih brơi. 
But this having taken place, the rest also who had sicknesses in the island came and were healed: @ Tơ bruă anai truh, abih bang ƀing ruă pơkŏn amăng plao ia anŭn rai pơ Pôl, laih anŭn dưi suaih soh sel. 
who also honoured us with many honours, and on our leaving they made presents to us of what should minister to our wants. @ Gơñu brơi lu mơnơ̆ng kơ gơmơi, laih anŭn tơ gơmơi đĭ kompăn đuaĭ nao, gơñu brơi kơ gơmơi djŏp mơta mơnơ̆ng gơmơi kiăng.
And after three months we sailed in a ship which had wintered in the island, an Alexandrian, with [the] Dioscuri for its ensign. @ Klâo blan tơdơi, gơmơi đĭ sa boh kompăn hmâo anăn Diôskur, kiăng laĭ: “Yang ƀă kơmar” mơ̆ng Aleksandri truh, jing kompăn hmâo kơđap tơdang bơyan puih ƀơi plao ia anai. 
And having come to Syracuse we remained three days. @ Ƀing gơmơi truh pơ plei Sirakus laih anŭn dŏ glaĭ pơ anŭn klâo hrơi. 
Whence, going in a circuitous course, we arrived at Rhegium; and after one day, the wind having changed to south, on the second day we came to Puteoli, @ Mơ̆ng anih anŭn gơmơi hluai tui hang ia rơsĭ nao truh pơ plei Rêgium. Hrơi tơdơi angĭn thut mơ̆ng dơnŭng, hnŭn yơh hrơi tal dua ƀing gơmơi truh pơ plei Pusôl. 
where, having found brethren, we were begged to stay with them seven days. And thus we went to Rome. @ Pơ anŭn ƀing gơmơi bưp ƀing adơi ayŏng, laih anŭn gơñu jak ƀing gơmơi dŏ glaĭ hăng gơñu tơjuh hrơi. Hnŭn yơh gơmơi hmâo truh pơ plei Rôm. 
And thence the brethren, having heard about us, came to meet us as far as Appii Forum and Tres Tabernae, whom when Paul saw, he thanked God and took courage. @ Ƀing adơi ayŏng pơ plei Rôm hmư̆ hing ƀing gơmơi rai, hnŭn yơh ƀing gơñu nao truh pơ Sang Sĭ Mia Apius laih anŭn anih arăng pia Klâo Sang Jưh kiăng kơ čơkă ƀing gơmơi. Tơ Pôl ƀuh ƀing gơñu, Pôl bơni hơơč kơ Ơi Adai laih anŭn hmâo tơlơi pơđĭ pran jua.
And when we came to Rome, [the centurion delivered up the prisoners to the praetorian prefect, but] Paul was allowed to remain by himself with the soldier who kept him. @ Tơ ƀing gơmơi mŭt amăng plei Rôm, arăng brơi Pôl dưi dŏ hơjăn hrŏm hăng sa čô tơhan gak wai ñu.
And it came to pass after three days, that he called together those who were the chief of the Jews; and when they had come together he said to them, Brethren, *I* having done nothing against the people or the customs of our forefathers, have been delivered a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans, @ Rơgao kơ klâo hrơi, Pôl jak iâu ƀing khua ană Yuđa rai. Tơdang gơñu pơƀŭt glaĭ, Pôl pơhiăp hăng gơñu: “Ơ ƀing adơi ayŏng, wơ̆t dah kâo ƀu ngă tơlơi hơgĕt pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng ană plei pla ƀôdah hăng tơlơi phiăn ƀing ơi adon ƀing ta, samơ̆ arăng mă kâo pơ plei Yêrusalem hăng jao hĭ kâo amăng tơngan ƀing Rôm. 
who having examined me were minded to let me go, because there was nothing worthy of death in me. @ Giơ̆ng tơña kơsem kâo, ƀing Rôm kiăng phư hĭ kâo yua kơ ƀu hmâo tơlơi hơgĕt ôh lăp kơ pơdjai kâo. 
But the Jews speaking against it, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, not as having anything to accuse my nation of. @ Samơ̆ ƀing Yuđa găng glaĭ ƀu tŭ ôh tơlơi arăng phư kâo, hnŭn yơh kâo khŏm iâu đĭ Sêsar. Ƀu djơ̆ kâo hmâo tơlơi pơmĭn phong, pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng kơnŭng djuai kâo ôh. 
For this cause therefore I have called you to [me] to see and to speak to you; for on account of the hope of Israel I have this chain about me. @ Klih yua kơ tơlơi anŭn yơh, kâo hmâo rơkâo kiăng bưp laih anŭn pơhiăp hrŏm hăng ƀing gih, yua kơ tơlơi čang rơmang kơ ƀing Israel anŭn yơh arăng akă kâo hăng hrĕ čuăk anai.”
And they said to him, For our part, we have neither received letters from Judaea concerning thee, nor has any one of the brethren who has arrived reported or said anything evil concerning thee. @ Gơñu laĭ glaĭ: “Gơmơi ƀu hmâo mă hră arăng mơit mơ̆ng čar Yuđa ră ruai kơ tơlơi ih ôh. Laih anŭn ăt kŏn hmâo sa čô amăng ƀing adơi ayŏng rai pơ anai laĭ pơthâo ƀôdah pơhiăp tơlơi sat kơ ih ôh. 
But we beg to hear of thee what thou thinkest, for as concerning this sect it is known to us that it is everywhere spoken against. @ Samơ̆ gơmơi kiăng hmư̆ mơ̆ng ih hơgĕt tơlơi ih pơmĭn; yua kơ gơmơi thâo tar ƀar anih arăng pơhiăp pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng tơlơi đaŏ anai.”
And having appointed him a day many came to him to the lodging, to whom he expounded, testifying of the kingdom of God, and persuading them concerning Jesus, both from the law of Moses and the prophets, from early morning to evening. @ Tơ truh hrơi gơñu pơkă, lu mơnuih rai pơ ñu amăng sang gơ̆ dŏ. Mơ̆ng mơguah truh pơ klam, Pôl ngă gơ̆ng jơlan hăng pơblang brơi gơñu kơ dêh čar pơtao Ơi Adai laih anŭn pơđur pơtrŭt gơñu đaŏ kơ Yêsu tui hăng tơlơi čih amăng tơlơi juăt Môis laih anŭn amăng hră ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo. 
And some were persuaded of the things which were said, but some disbelieved. @ Đơđa mơnuih đaŏ kơ tơlơi Pôl pơhiăp, đơđa ƀu đaŏ ôh. 
And being disagreed among themselves they left; Paul having spoken one word, Well spoke the Holy Spirit through Esaias the prophet to our fathers, @ Hnŭn yơh, gơñu ƀu tŭ ư tơdruă ôh laih anŭn gơñu glaĭ, yua kơ anŭn mơ̆n Pôl pơhiăp boh pơhiăp anai: “Yang Bơngăt Hiam hmâo laĭ djơ̆ biă mă, hlăk ñu yua pô laĭ lui hlâo Êsai pơhiăp hăng ơi adon ƀing gih tui anai:
saying, Go to this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear and not understand, and seeing ye shall see and not perceive. @  ‘Nao bĕ pơ ƀing ană plei pla anai hăng laĭ:
“Sĭt biă mă ƀing gih či hmư̆, samơ̆ ƀu thâo hluh ôh;
Laih anŭn sĭt biă mă ƀing gih či lăng, samơ̆ ƀu thâo ƀuh ôh.
For the heart of this people has become fat, and they hear heavily with their ears, and they have closed their eyes; lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and be converted, and I should heal them. @ Yua kơ pran jua ƀing ană plei pla anai jing kơnăm mơmŏt hĭ;
Gơñu hơkăt hĭ amăng tơngia gơñu,
Gơñu pĭt hĭ mơta gơñu,
Hwĭ dah mơta gơñu dưi ƀuh,
Tơngia gơñu dưi hmư̆,
Tơlơi pơmĭn gơñu dưi thâo hluh,
Laih anŭn gơñu či wơ̆t glaĭ pơ Kâo,
Kiăng kơ Kâo pơsuaih gơñu.”’
Be it known to you therefore, that this salvation of God has been sent to the nations; *they* also will hear [it]. @ Tui anŭn, brơi ƀing gih thâo tơlơi pơklaih Ơi Adai arăng hmâo hyu ră ruai laih kơ ƀing djuai tuai. Gơñu či hmư̆.”
And he remained two whole years in his own hired lodging, and received all who came to him, @ Pôl dŏ amăng sang ñu apah anŭn krĕp dua thŭn. Ñu jum abih bang mơnuih nao pơ ñu, 
preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching the things concerning the Lord Jesus Christ, with all freedom unhinderedly. @ pơtô kơ dêh čar Pơtao Ơi Adai laih anŭn pơhrăm arăng kơ tơlơi Khua Yang Yêsu Krist hăng tơlơi rơngai, ƀu hmâo hlơi khă găn ôh.
Paul, bondman of Jesus Christ, [a] called apostle, separated to God's glad tidings, @ Pôl jing sa čô ding kơna Yêsu Krist, Ơi Adai hmâo iâu laih kâo brơi jing khua ding kơna, pioh brơi kơ bruă pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam Ơi Adai. 
(which he had before promised by his prophets in holy writings,) @ Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam anŭn Ơi Adai hmâo ƀuăn laih mơ̆ng đưm hlâo, găn mơ̆ng ƀing pô laĭ lui hlâo Ñu hmâo čih pioh laih amăng Hră Ơi Adai Pơhiăp. 
concerning his Son (come of David's seed according to flesh, @ Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam anŭn djơ̆ kơ Ană Ñu, Yêsu Krist Khua Yang ƀing ta, gah kơ asar đeh Ñu hmâo tơkeng rai mơ̆ng kơnŭng djuai Đawit, 
marked out Son of God in power, according to [the] Spirit of holiness, by resurrection of [the] dead) Jesus Christ our Lord; @ laih anŭn gah kơ yang bơngăt rơgoh hiam, pơhaih pơrơđah kơ Ñu jing Ană Ơi Adai dưi mơyang yua kơ mơ̆ng tơlơi Ñu hơdip glaĭ mơ̆ng mơnuih djai, jing Yêsu Krist Khua Yang ƀing ta. 
by whom we have received grace and apostleship in behalf of his name, for obedience of faith among all the nations, @ Mơ̆ng Ñu yơh gơmơi hmâo mă tŭ laih tơlơi pap laih anŭn tơlơi dưi jing khua ding kơna, kiăng atăt ba mơnuih mơ̆ng abih bang djuai mơnuih truh kơ tơlơi thâo đup gưt kơ tơlơi đaŏ, yua kơ anăn Ñu. 
among whom are *ye* also [the] called of Jesus Christ: @ Amăng ƀing mơnuih anŭn, ƀing gih ăt jing ƀing Ơi Adai hmâo iâu laih kiăng jing lơ̆m kơ Yêsu Krist.
to all that are in Rome, beloved of God, called saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and [our] Lord Jesus Christ. @ Kâo čih mơit kơ abih bang ƀing Ơi Adai khăp hơeng amăng plei Rôm, ƀing Ơi Adai hmâo iâu laih brơi jing ƀing rơgoh hiam.
Rơkâo kơ Ơi Adai, Ama ƀing ta, laih anŭn Khua Yang Yêsu Krist pha brơi tơlơi pap laih anŭn tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua kơ ƀing gih!
First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is proclaimed in the whole world. @ Blŭng hlâo amăng anăn Yêsu Krist kâo bơni hơơč kơ Ơi Adai yua kơ abih bang ƀing gih, yua kơ arăng hmư̆ hing tơlơi đaŏ ƀing gih tar ƀar lŏn tơnah. 
For God is my witness, whom I serve in my spirit in the glad tidings of his Son, how unceasingly I make mention of you, @ Yua kơ Ơi Adai jing Pô kâo mă bruă hăng abih bơngăt jua hăng tơlơi pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam Ană Ñu, jing pô ngă gơ̆ng jơlan pơsĭt kơ kâo, nanao kâo hơdơr kơ ƀing gih 
always beseeching at my prayers, if any way now at least I may be prospered by the will of God to come to you. @ rĭm wơ̆t kâo iâu laĭ. Kâo rơkâo kơ Ơi Adai tui hăng Ñu kiăng brơi kơ kâo dưi nao čuă ngui ƀing gih. 
For I greatly desire to see you, that I may impart to you some spiritual gift to establish you; @ Yua kơ kâo kiăng biă mă nao čuă ngui ƀing gih, kiăng kơ dưi pơpha brơi kơ ƀing gih tơlơi pha brơi mơ̆ng Yang Bơngăt Hiam, kiăng kơ ƀing gih kơjăp kơtang; 
that is, to have mutual comfort among you, each by the faith [which is] in the other, both yours and mine. @ Tơlơi anŭn kiăng laĭ, kiăng kơ ƀing ta dưi pơđĭ pran jua tơdruă hăng tơlơi đaŏ ƀing ta, anŭn jing tơlơi đaŏ ƀing gih laih anŭn tơlơi đaŏ kâo.
But I do not wish you to be ignorant, brethren, that I often proposed to come to you, (and have been hindered until the present time,) that I might have some fruit among you too, even as among the other nations also. @  Ơ adơi ayŏng, kâo kiăng kơ ƀing gih thâo, hmâo lu wơ̆t laih kâo hmâo tơlơi pơmĭn kiăng nao čuă ƀing gih, kiăng kơ kâo dưi pĕ boh amăng ƀing gih kar hăng amăng djuai tuai pơkŏn mơ̆n; samơ̆ kâo ăt dŏ hmâo tơlơi gŭn truh kơ hrơi anai. 
I am a debtor both to Greeks and barbarians, both to wise and unintelligent: @ Kâo đom hơnưh kơ ƀing mơnuih Grek wơ̆t kơ ƀing mơnuih glai, kơ ƀing thâo lu laih anŭn kơ ƀing mlŭk mơgu. 
so, as far as depends on me, am I ready to announce the glad tidings to you also who [are] in Rome. @ Tui anŭn, kâo ăt hur har kiăng pơtô Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam wơ̆t kơ ƀing gih mơ̆n, ƀing dŏ amăng plei Rôm.
For I am not ashamed of the glad tidings; for it is God's power to salvation, to every one that believes, both to Jew first and to Greek: @  Sĭt biă mă, kâo ƀu mlâo ôh kơ Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam, yua kơ ñu jing tơlơi dưi mơyang Ơi Adai kiăng pơklaih rĭm čô hlơi pô đaŏ, blŭng hlâo kơ ƀing mơnuih Yuđa laih anŭn truh kơ ƀing mơnuih Grek mơ̆n. 
for righteousness of God is revealed therein, on the principle of faith, to faith: according as it is written, But the just shall live by faith. @ Yua kơ Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam anai bơrơđah tơlơi tơpă Ơi Adai hmâo mơ̆ng tơlơi đaŏ laih anŭn atăt kơ tơlơi đaŏ; tui hăng hmâo čih laih: “Mơnuih tơpă či hơdip hăng tơlơi đaŏ.”
For there is revealed wrath of God from heaven upon all impiety, and unrighteousness of men holding the truth in unrighteousness. @ Tơlơi hil Ơi Adai mơ̆ng adai hmâo pơrơđah kiăng pơkơdơ̆ng glaĭ hăng abih tơlơi ƀu pơpŭ kơ Ơi Adai laih anŭn tơlơi wĕ wŏ mơnuih ngă, hăng tơlơi wĕ wŏ anŭn gơñu kơ̆ng khă tơlơi sĭt. 
Because what is known of God is manifest among them, for God has manifested [it] to them, @ Yua kơ hơgĕt tơlơi arăng dưi thâo krăn Ơi Adai jing klă rơđah laih kơ gơñu, yua kơ Ơi Adai hmâo pơrơđah laih tơlơi anŭn kơ gơñu. 
for from [the] world's creation the invisible things of him are perceived, being apprehended by the mind through the things that are made, both his eternal power and divinity, so as to render them inexcusable. @ Čơdơ̆ng mơ̆ng hrơi hrih lŏn tơnah kơnuih mơyang Ñu, kiăng laĭ tơlơi dưi mơyang Ñu hlŏng lar laih anŭn tơlơi Ñu jing Ơi Adai, arăng dưi ƀuh rơđah tơ kơsem lăng mơnơ̆ng Ñu hmâo hrih laih. Tui anŭn gơñu ƀu dưi pơgăl pơgang gơñu pô ôh. 
Because, knowing God, they glorified [him] not as God, neither were thankful; but fell into folly in their thoughts, and their heart without understanding was darkened: @ Yua kơ wơ̆t dah gơñu thâo krăn laih Ơi Adai, gơñu ăt ƀu pơpŭ pơyom ôh kơ Ñu jing Ơi Adai, kŏn bơni hơơč kơ Ñu lơi; samơ̆ tơlơi pơmĭn gơñu jing hĭ đôč đač, laih anŭn pran jua mlŭk gơñu bă hăng tơlơi kơnăm mơmŏt. 
professing themselves to be wise, they became fools, @ Gơñu laĭ gơñu pô jing kơhnâo, samơ̆ gơñu jing hĭ laih mlŭk, 
and changed the glory of the incorruptible God into [the] likeness of an image of corruptible man and of birds and quadrupeds and reptiles. @ gơñu hmâo pơplih hĭ tơlơi ang yang Ơi Adai ƀu thâo brŭ rai kiăng kơ mă tŭ rup mơnuih thâo brŭ rai, thâo dah rup čĭm, rup hlô mơnơ̆ng, ƀôdah hlô mơnơ̆ng hro rui.
Wherefore God gave them up [also] in the lusts of their hearts to uncleanness, to dishonour their bodies between themselves: @ Yua kơ anŭn yơh Ơi Adai jao lui hĭ gơñu kơ tơlơi grĭ grañ tui hăng pran jua gơñu amoaih hưp, tơl gơñu yua drơi jan gơñu pô ngă tơlơi pơmlâo hañ tơdruă gơñu. 
who changed the truth of God into falsehood, and honoured and served the creature more than him who had created [it], who is blessed for ever. Amen. @ Yua kơ gơñu pơplih hĭ tơlơi sĭt Ơi Adai jing tơlơi ƀlor, laih anŭn gơñu kơkuh pơpŭ hăng mă bruă kơ mơnơ̆ng hmâo hrih laih, pơala kơ Pô Hrih Pơjing, jing Pô lăp kơ pơpŭ bơni hlŏng lar Amen!
For this reason God gave them up to vile lusts; for both their females changed the natural use into that contrary to nature; @ Yua kơ tơlơi anŭn yơh Ơi Adai hmâo jao hĭ gơñu kơ tơlơi amoaih rih mlâo hañ. Wơ̆t kơ ƀing đah kơmơi kar kaĭ mơ̆n hmâo pơplih hĭ tơlơi phiăn yang đar, samơ̆ ngă kơđai glaĭ hĭ tơlơi phiăn yang đar. 
and in like manner the males also, leaving the natural use of the female, were inflamed in their lust towards one another; males with males working shame, and receiving in themselves the recompense of their error which was fit. @ Ƀing đah rơkơi ăt kar kaĭ mơ̆n, lui hĭ tơlơi phiăn yang đar đah rơkơi hăng đah kơmơi juăt ngă, laih anŭn pơčuh tơlơi amoaih rih tơdruă, đah rơkơi hăng đah rơkơi ngă tơlơi soh mlâo hañ, laih anŭn gơñu pô tŭ mă tơlơi pơkơhmal lăp hăng tơlơi soh gơñu.
And according as they did not think good to have God in [their] knowledge, God gave them up to a reprobate mind to practise unseemly things; @ Yua kơ gơñu ƀu kiăng djă pioh ôh tơlơi thâo krăn Ơi Adai, tui anŭn Ơi Adai hmâo jao lui hĭ gơñu kơ tơlơi pơmĭn răm ƀăm tơl gơñu ngă lu tơlơi ƀu lăp. 
being filled with all unrighteousness, wickedness, covetousness, malice; full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, evil dispositions; whisperers, @ Gơñu bă hăng djŏp mơta tơlơi ƀu tơpă, tơlơi sat ƀai, tơlơi hưp ham, tơlơi hil, gơñu bă hăng tơlơi moañ, tơlơi pơdjai mơnuih, tơlơi pơrơdjơ̆ pơrơsao, tơlơi pleč ƀlor, tơlơi kreñ; tơlơi hil ruă; gơñu jing ƀing ruai tơlơi sat arăng, 
back-biters, hateful to God, insolent, proud, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents, @ pơhiăp pơčeh, bơrơmŭt kơ Ơi Adai, ƀrưh hmiah, pơgao, pơ-ư pơang pô, kơhnăk ngă soh, khăng akŏ hăng amĭ ama, 
void of understanding, faithless, without natural affection, unmerciful; @ mlŭk mơgu, ƀu tŏng ten amăng hiăp ƀuăn, ƀu hmâo tơlơi khăp, ƀu hmâo tơlơi pap drap. 
who knowing the righteous judgment of God, that they who do such things are worthy of death, not only practise them, but have fellow delight in those who do [them]. @ Gơñu thâo tơlơi juăt Ơi Adai hmâo pơkă laih, kơ hlơi pô ngă tui anŭn jing lăp kơ djai yơh. Wơ̆t dah tui anŭn, ƀu djơ̆ kơnơ̆ng gơñu pô đôč ôh ngă tơlơi anŭn, samơ̆ gơñu ăt tŭ ư brơi ƀing pơkŏn ngă dơ̆ng mơ̆n.
Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, every one who judgest, for in that in which thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself; for thou that judgest doest the same things. @  Tui anŭn, Ơ mơnuih anŭn, măk ai hlơi ih jing, tơdang ih phat kơđi kơ arăng ih ƀu dưi pơgăl pơgang kơ ih pô ôh. Yua kơ tơdang ih phat kơđi kơ arăng, ih ăt klă kơđi kơ ih pô yơh; yua kơ ih phat kơđi kơ arăng, samơ̆ ih ăt ngă kar hăng gơñu mơ̆n. 
But we know that the judgment of God is according to truth upon those who do such things. @ Ƀing ta thâo tơlơi Ơi Adai phat kơđi kơ ƀing mơnuih ngă khul bruă tui hăng anŭn jing gal djơ̆ yơh. 
And thinkest thou this, O man, who judgest those that do such things, and practisest them [thyself], that *thou* shalt escape the judgment of God? @ Ơ mơnuih anŭn, tơdang ih phat kơđi kơ ƀing ngă soh tui anŭn, samơ̆ ih pô ăt ngă kar kaĭ mơ̆n, ih pơmĭn ih či dưi klaih mơ̆ng tơlơi Ơi Adai phat kơđi hă? 
or despisest thou the riches of his goodness, and forbearance, and long-suffering, not knowing that the goodness of God leads thee to repentance? @ Ƀôdah ih mưč mač tơlơi hiam klă rơbeh blai Ơi Adai, tơlơi Ñu thâo pap, tơlơi Ñu gir? Ih ƀu thâo ôh hă tơlơi hiam klă Ơi Adai kiăng ba ih kơ tơlơi kơhmal kơ tơlơi soh? 
but, according to thy hardness and impenitent heart, treasurest up to thyself wrath, in [the] day of wrath and revelation of [the] righteous judgment of God, @ Samơ̆ ih hmâo pran jua khăng, ƀu kơhmal kơ tơlơi soh ôh, jing ih pơkom pioh tơlơi hil či truh kơ ih pô ƀơi hrơi tơlơi hil, ƀơi hrơi Ơi Adai phat kơđi tơpă hơnơ̆ng či pơrơđah. 
who shall render to each according to his works: @ Yua kơ Ơi Adai klă kơđi kơ rĭm čô mơnuih tui hăng bruă ñu ngă. 
to them who, in patient continuance of good works, seek for glory and honour and incorruptibility, life eternal. @ Ơi Adai či brơi tơlơi hơdip hlŏng lar kơ ƀing ngă tơlơi hiam nanao, hơduah tơlơi ư-ang, tơlơi pơpŭ laih anŭn tơlơi ƀu thâo djai. 
But to those that are contentious, and are disobedient to the truth, but obey unrighteousness, [there shall be] wrath and indignation, @ Bơ kơ ƀing et klih, ƀu gưt kơ tơlơi sĭt, samơ̆ gưt kơ tơlơi wĕ wŏ, Ơi Adai či tuh kơ gơñu tơlơi kreñ laih anŭn tơlơi hil. 
tribulation and distress, on every soul of man that works evil, both of Jew first, and of Greek; @ Či hmâo tơlơi tơnap hăng tơlơi rŭng răng kơ rĭm čô mơnuih ngă tơlơi sat ƀai, blŭng hlâo kơ ƀing Yuđa laih anŭn wơ̆t kơ ƀing Grek mơ̆n. 
but glory and honour and peace to every one that works good, both to Jew first and to Greek: @ Samơ̆ či hmâo tơlơi ư-ang, tơlơi pơpŭ, laih anŭn tơlơi rơnŭk rơnua kơ rĭm čô mơnuih ngă tơlơi hiam, blŭng hlâo kơ ƀing Yuđa, tơdơi anŭn kơ ƀing Grek. 
for there is no acceptance of persons with God. @ Yua kơ Ơi Adai ƀu lăng mơnuih phara phara ôh.
For as many as have sinned without law shall perish also without law; and as many as have sinned under law shall be judged by law, @ Abih bang hlơi pô ngă soh gah rơngiao kơ tơlơi juăt, gơñu ăt či răm rơngiă gah rơngiao tơlơi juăt mơ̆n. Laih anŭn abih bang hlơi pô ngă soh gah yŭ tơlơi juăt, tơlơi juăt anŭn či phat kơđi kơ gơñu. 
(for not the hearers of the law [are] just before God, but the doers of the law shall be justified. @ Yua kơ ƀu djơ̆ ôh ƀing hmư̆ tơlơi juăt jing tơpă ƀơi anăp Ơi Adai, samơ̆ ƀing ngă tui tơlơi juăt či hmâo tơlơi yap tơpă. 
For when [those of the] nations, which have no law, practise by nature the things of the law, these, having no law, are a law to themselves; @ Ƀing djuai tuai ƀu hmâo tơlơi juăt hơđăp amơĭ, samơ̆ gơñu juăt ngă tui tơlơi juăt pơtă, gơñu pơjing kơ tơlơi juăt kơ gơñu pô yơh, wơ̆t dah gơñu ƀu hmâo tơlơi juăt tŭ mơ̆n. 
who shew the work of the law written in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witness, and their thoughts accusing or else excusing themselves between themselves;) @ Gơñu pơrơđah hơgĕt bruă tơlơi juăt pơtă hmâo čih laih amăng pran jua gơñu, pran jua tơpă hiam gơñu ăt pơsĭt brơi tơlơi anŭn mơ̆n, laih anŭn tơlơi pơmĭn gơñu tăp năng kơčut ƀuah gơñu tăp năng pơgăl pơgang brơi gơñu. 
in [the] day when God shall judge the secrets of men, according to my glad tidings, by Jesus Christ. @ Tơlơi anŭn či pơrơđah brơi ƀơi hrơi Ơi Adai phat kơđi mơ̆ng Yêsu Krist abih bang bruă hơgơ̆m mơnuih ngă, tui hăng Tơlơi Phrâo Hiam kâo hmâo pơtô.
But if *thou* art named a Jew, and restest in the law, and makest thy boast in God, @ Samơ̆ tơdah ih yap ih pô jing mơnuih Yuđa, ih hơ-ĭn kơnang kơ tơlơi juăt, pơ-ư kơ ih pô yua kơ Ơi Adai ih, 
and knowest the will, and discerningly approvest the things that are more excellent, being instructed out of the law; @ thâo hluh tơlơi Ñu kiăng, laih anŭn thâo ruah mă hơgĕt jing hiam, yua kơ tơlơi juăt hmâo pơhrăm ih laih, 
and hast confidence that thou thyself art a leader of the blind, a light of those who [are] in darkness, @ laih anŭn tơdah ih thâo sĭt ih jing pô ba jơlan kơ ƀing bum mơta, jing tơlơi bơngač kơ ƀing dŏ amăng tơlơi kơnăm mơmŏt, 
an instructor of the foolish, a teacher of babes, having the form of knowledge and of truth in the law: @ pô pơhrăm ƀing mlŭk, nai pơtô kơ ƀing mơnuih ƀu thâo phe pho, amăng tơlơi juăt ih hmâo abih tơlơi čih kơ tơlơi thâo hluh laih anŭn tơlơi sĭt. 
thou then that teachest another, dost thou not teach thyself? thou that preachest not to steal, dost thou steal? @ Tui anŭn, Ơ pô pơtô kơ arăng, yua hơgĕt ih ƀu pơtô kơ ih pô lĕ? Ih pơtô kơ arăng anăm klĕ dŏp ôh, samơ̆ hyư̆m ih pô klĕ dŏp? 
thou that sayest [man should] not commit adultery, dost thou commit adultery? thou that abhorrest idols, dost thou commit sacrilege? @ Ih pơtô kơ arăng anăm klĕ pyu ôh, samơ̆ hyư̆m ih pô klĕ pyu? Ih bơrơmŭt kơ rup trah, samơ̆ hyư̆m ih pô klĕ mă gơnam tam mơ̆ng sang kơkuh pơpŭ? 
thou who boastest in law, dost thou by transgression of the law dishonour God? @ Ih pơ-ư pơang kơ ih pô yua kơ tơlơi juăt, samơ̆ hyư̆m ih pô ngă pơmlâo Ơi Adai hăng tơlơi ih ngă gao tơlơi juăt? 
For the name of God is blasphemed on your account among the nations, according as it is written. @ Kar hăng tơlơi hmâo čih laih: “Yua kơ ƀing gih yơh ƀing djuai tuai pơhiăp ƀrưh hmiah kơ anăn Ơi Adai.”
For circumcision indeed profits if thou keep [the] law; but if thou be a law-transgressor, thy circumcision is become uncircumcision. @ Tơdah ih gưt kơ tơlơi juăt, tơlơi khăt klĭ jing yom; samơ̆ tơdah ih ngă gao tơlơi juăt, tơlơi khăt klĭ ih anŭn jing kar hăng ƀu khăt klĭ ôh. 
If therefore the uncircumcision keep the requirements of the law, shall not his uncircumcision be reckoned for circumcision, @ Tui anŭn tơdah mơnuih ƀu tŭ khăt klĭ ôh samơ̆ ñu gưt hơgĕt tơlơi juăt pơtă pơtăn, ƀu djơ̆ ôh hă Ơi Adai či yap tơlơi ñu ƀu khăt klĭ anŭn kar hăng khăt klĭ laih? 
and uncircumcision by nature, fulfilling the law, judge thee, who, with letter and circumcision, [art] a law-transgressor? @ Tui anŭn ƀing mơnuih ƀu hmâo khăt klĭ tui hăng asar đeh samơ̆ gưt tơlơi juăt či phat kơđi ih, pô hmâo hră tơlơi juăt laih anŭn khăt klĭ samơ̆ ngă gao tơlơi juăt. 
For he is not a Jew who [is] one outwardly, neither that circumcision which is outward in flesh; @ Yua kơ sa čô mơnuih kơnơ̆ng gah rơngiao đôč jing mơnuih Yuđa, ñu anŭn ƀu djơ̆ mơnuih Yuđa sĭt ôh, bơ kơ tơlơi khăt klĭ gah kơ asar đeh gah rơngiao, ñu ƀu djơ̆ tơlơi khăt klĭ sĭt ôh.
